ADOPTING ORDINANCES
ORDINANCE NO. 13-1994
   AN ORDINANCE REVISING, REFORMATTING AND ADOPTING THE 1994 EDITION OF THE
CRAWFORDSVILLE CITY CODE
         WHEREAS, the City of Crawfordsville, Indiana (City), has heretofore
adopted and from time to time amended the Municipal Code of the City of
Crawfordsville, Indiana Code; and,
         WHEREAS, it is prudent and desirable to revise and reprint the Code in
order to incorporate amendments made to this present date of June 13, 1994; and
         WHEREAS, this revision does not require publication of notice and may
become effective immediately upon passage,
         NOW THEREFORE, BE IT HEREBY ESTABLISHED AND ORDAINED by the Common
Council of the City of Crawfordsville, Indiana, that:
         1. That at the direction of the Common Council all amendments to the
Municipal Code of the City of Crawfordsville, Indiana since March 1985 have
been included in a newly printed and reformatted edition of the Municipal Code
of the City of Crawfordsville, Indiana, which printed and reformatted revision
is hereby adopted as the official City Code of the City of Crawfordsville,
Indiana including Chapter 23 of the 1985 Code edition which was amended and
adopted by the Common Council on April 11, 1994 but which has yet to be printed
and included in this revised edition and which is hereby designated as Title
XV, Chapter 150 of this revised edition.
         2. That the Clerk-Treasurer of the City is directed to deliver this
latest revision, to the following: Circuit Court of Montgomery County, Indiana;
Superior Court of Montgomery County, Indiana and County Court of Montgomery
County, Indiana; Crawfordsville Public Library, Crawfordsville, Montgomery
County, Indiana; Wabash College Library, Crawfordsville, Montgomery County,
Indiana; Crawfordsville High School Library, Crawfordsville, Montgomery County,
Indiana; Tuttle Junior High School, Crawfordsville, Montgomery County, Indiana;
all elected City officials and all appointed heads of departments of the City
of Crawfordsville; not less than two (2) copies to the City of Crawfordsville
Clerk-Treasurer.
         3. The Clerk-Treasurer is authorized and directed to cause such
additional copies of the Code to be prepared as she shall deem prudent, to be
retained in the office of the Clerk-Treasurer for sale and delivery to
individual purchasers upon request, for the sum of $45.00 per copy or such
higher price as the publisher may hereinafter establish. Individual chapters
may be copied at the rate of $.25 per page, not to exceed $25.00 per chapter.
         ADOPTED BY THE COMMON COUNCIL of the City of Crawfordsville, Indiana
is the 11th day of July, 1994.
                  Philip Q. Michal /s/
                  Mayor
                  Presiding Officer
         Presented by me to the Mayor of the City of Crawfordsville, Indiana,
this 11th day of July 1994.
                  Nellie Thompson /s/
                  Clerk-Treasurer
         This Ordinance approved and signed by me this 11th day of July, 1994.
                  Philip Q. Michal /s/
                  Mayor
ATTEST:
   Nellie Thompson /s/
   Clerk-Treasurer
ORDINANCE NO. 3-1996
   AN ORDINANCE ENACTING AND ADOPTING A SUPPLEMENT TO THE CODE OF ORDINANCES OF
THE CITY OF CRAWFORDSVILLE
   BE IT HEREBY ESTABLISHED AND ORDAINED by the Common Council of the City of
Crawfordsville, Indiana, that:
   WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio has
completed the 1995 Supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City of
Crawfordsville, which supplement contains all ordinances of a general nature
enacted since the prior supplement to the Code of Ordinances of this
municipality; and
   WHEREAS, said American Legal Publishing Corporation has recommended the
revision or addition of certain sections of the Code of Ordinances which are
based on or make references to sections of the Indiana Code; and
   WHEREAS, it is the intent of Council to accept these updated sections in
accordance with the changes of the law of the State of Indiana;
   NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the Common Council of the City of
Crawfordsville, State of Indiana:
   Section 1. That the 1995 Supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City of
Crawfordsville, Indiana as submitted by American Legal Publishing Corporation
of Cincinnati, and as attached hereto, be and the same is hereby adopted by
reference as if set out in its entirety.
   Section 2. That this ordinance shall take effect and be in force from and
after its date of passage.
   ADOPTION BY THE COMMON COUNCIL of the City of Crawfordsville, Indiana is the
12th day of February, 1996.
                                    Philip Q. Michal /s/
                                    Philip Q. Michal, Mayor
                                    Presiding Officer
   Presented by me to the Mayor of the City of Crawfordsville, Indiana, this
12th day of February, 1996.
                                    Nellie Thompson /s/
                                    Nellie Thompson, Clerk-Treasurer
   This Ordinance approved and signed by me this 12th day of February, 1996.
                                    Philip Q. Michal /s/
                                    Philip Q. Michal, Mayor
ATTEST:
Nellie Thompson /s/
Nellie Thompson, Clerk-Treasurer

after its date of passage.

ORDINANCE NO. 8-2009
   AN ORDINANCE ENACTING AND ADOPTING THE 2008 SUPPLEMENT TO THE CODE OF
ORDINANCES OF THE CITY OF CRAWFORDSVILLE, INDIANA
   WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio has
completed the 2008 Supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City of
Crawfordsville, Indiana, which supplement contains all ordinances of a general
nature enacted by the Crawfordsville Common Council since the prior supplement
to the Code of Ordinances of this municipality, through calendar year 2008; and
   WHEREAS, said American Legal Publishing Corporation has recommended the
revision or addition of certain sections of the Code of Ordinances which are
based on or make references to sections of the Indiana Code that have been
changed or added by prior sessions of the Indiana General Assembly; and
   WHEREAS, it is the intent of Common Council to accept these updated sections
in accordance with the changes of the law of the State of Indiana;
   NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the Common Council of the City of
Crawfordsville, Indiana, that:
   Section 1. The 2008 Supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City of
Crawfordsville, Indiana as submitted by American Legal Publishing Corporation
of Cincinnati, and as attached hereto, be and the same is hereby adopted by
reference as if set out in its entirety.
   Section 2. This ordinance shall take effect and be in force from and after
its date of passage.
   ADOPTED BY THE COMMON COUNCIL of the City of Crawfordsville, Indiana this
13th day of April, 2009.

TITLE I: GENERAL PROVISIONS
   Chapter
      
10.   GENERAL PROVISIONS
CHAPTER 10: GENERAL PROVISIONS
Section
   
10.01   Title of code
   
10.02   Interpretation
   
10.03   Application to future ordinances
   
10.04   Captions
   
10.05   Definitions
   
10.06   Rules of interpretation
   
10.07   Severability
   
10.08   Reference to other sections
   
10.09   Reference to offices
   
10.10   Errors and omissions
   
10.11   Official time
   
10.12   Reasonable time
   
10.13   Ordinances repealed
   
10.14   Ordinances unaffected
   
10.15   Effective date of ordinances
   
10.16   Repeal or modification of ordinance
   
10.17   Ordinances which amend or supplement code
   
10.18   Section histories; statutory references
 
   
10.99   General penalty
§ 10.01 TITLE OF CODE.
   This codification of ordinances by and for the city of Crawfordsville shall
be designated as the Code of Crawfordsville and may be so cited.
§ 10.02 INTERPRETATION.
   Unless otherwise provided herein, or by law or implication required, the
same rules of construction, definition, and application shall govern the
interpretation of this code as those governing the interpretation of state law.
§ 10.03 APPLICATION TO FUTURE ORDINANCES.
   All provisions of Title I compatible with future legislation, shall apply to
ordinances hereafter adopted amending or supplementing this code unless
otherwise specifically provided.
§ 10.04 CAPTIONS.
   Headings and captions used in this code other than the title, chapter, and
section numbers are employed for reference purposes only and shall not be
deemed a part of the text of any section.
§ 10.05 DEFINITIONS.
   (A)   General rule. Words and phrases shall be taken in their plain, or
ordinary and usual sense. However, technical words and phrases having a
peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be understood according to their
technical import.
   (B)   For the purpose of this code, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CITY, MUNICIPAL CORPORATION  or MUNICIPALITY. The City of Crawfordsville,
Indiana.
   CODE, THIS CODE or THIS CODE OF ORDINANCES. This municipal code as modified
by amendment, revision, and adoption of new titles, chapters, or sections.
   COMMON COUNCIL or COUNCIL. The legislative body of the city.
   COUNTY. Montgomery County, Indiana.
   MAY. The act referred to is permissive.
   MONTH. A calendar month.
   OATH. An affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be
substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words SWEAR and SWORN shall be
equivalent to the words AFFIRM and AFFIRMED.
   OFFICER, OFFICE, EMPLOYEE, COMMISSION, or DEPARTMENT. An officer, office,
employee, commission, or department of this municipality unless the context
clearly requires otherwise.
   PERSON. Extends to and includes person, persons, firm, corporation,
copartnership, trustee, lessee, or receiver. Whenever used in any clause
prescribing and imposing a penalty, the terms PERSON or WHOEVER as applied to
any unincorporated entity shall mean the partners or members thereof, and as
applied to corporations, the officers or agents thereof.
   PRECEDING or FOLLOWING. Next before or next after, respectively.
   SHALL. The act referred to is mandatory.
   SIGNATURE or SUBSCRIPTION. Includes a mark when the person cannot write.
   STATE. The State of Indiana.
   SUBCHAPTER. A division of a chapter, designated in this code by a heading in
the chapter analysis and a capitalized heading in the body of the chapter,
setting apart a group of sections related by the subject matter of the heading.
Not all chapters have subchapters.
   WRITTEN. Any representation of words, letters, or figures, whether by
printing or otherwise.
   YEAR. A calendar year, unless otherwise expressed; equivalent to the words
YEAR OF OUR LORD.
§ 10.06 RULES OF INTERPRETATION.
   The construction of all ordinances of this municipality shall be by the
following rules, unless such construction is plainly repugnant to the intent of
the Common Council or of the context of the same ordinance:
   (A)   AND or OR. Either conjunction shall include the other as if written
“and/or,” if the sense requires it.
   (B)   Acts by assistants. When a statute or ordinance requires an act to be
done which, by law, an agent or deputy as well may do as the principal, such
requisition shall be satisfied by the performance of such act by an authorized
agent or deputy.
   (C)   Gender; singular and plural; tenses. Words denoting the masculine
gender shall be deemed to include the feminine and neuter genders; words in the
singular shall include the plural, and words in the plural shall include the
singular; the use of a verb in the present tense shall include the future, if
applicable.
   (D)   General term. A general term following specific enumeration of terms
is not to be limited to the class enumerated unless expressly so limited.
§ 10.07 SEVERABILITY.
   If any provision of this code as now or later amended or its application to
any person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity does not affect
other provisions that can be given effect without the invalid provision or
application.
§ 10.08 REFERENCE TO OTHER SECTIONS.
   Whenever in one section reference is made to another section hereof, such
reference shall extend and apply to the section referred to as subsequently
amended, revised, recodified, or renumbered unless the subject matter is
changed or materially altered by the amendment or revision.
§ 10.09 REFERENCE TO OFFICES.
   Reference to a public office or officer shall be deemed to apply to any
office, officer, or employee of this municipality exercising the powers,
duties, or functions contemplated in the provision, irrespective of any
transfer of functions or change in the official title of the functionary.
§ 10.10 ERRORS AND OMISSIONS.
   If a manifest error is discovered, consisting of the misspelling of any
words; the omission of any word or words necessary to express the intention of
the provisions affected; the use of a word or words to which no meaning can be
attached; or the use of a word or words when another word or words was clearly
intended to express such intent, such spelling shall be corrected and such word
or words supplied, omitted, or substituted as will conform with the manifest
intention, and the provisions shall have the same effect as though the correct
words were contained in the text as originally published. No alteration shall
be made or permitted if any question exists regarding the nature or extent of
such error.
§ 10.11 OFFICIAL TIME.
   The official time, as established by applicable state/federal laws, shall be
the official time within this municipality for the transaction of all municipal
business.
§ 10.12 REASONABLE TIME.
   (A)   In all cases where an ordinance requires an act to be done in a
reasonable time or requires reasonable notice to be given, reasonable time or
notice shall be deemed to mean the time which is necessary for a prompt
performance of such act or the giving of such notice.
   (B)   The time within which an act is to be done, as herein provided, shall
be computed by excluding the first day and including the last. If the last day
be Sunday, it shall be excluded.
§ 10.13 ORDINANCES REPEALED.
   This code, from and after its effective date, shall contain all of the
provisions of a general nature pertaining to the subjects herein enumerated and
embraced. All prior ordinances pertaining to the subjects treated by this code
shall be deemed repealed from and after the effective date of this code.
§ 10.14 ORDINANCES UNAFFECTED.
   All ordinances of a temporary or special nature and all other ordinances
pertaining to subjects not embraced in this code shall remain in full force and
effect unless herein repealed expressly or by necessary implication.
§ 10.15 EFFECTIVE DATE OF ORDINANCES.
   All ordinances passed by the Common Council requiring publication shall take
effect from and after the due publication thereof, unless otherwise expressly
provided. Ordinances not requiring publication shall take effect from their
passage, unless otherwise expressly provided.
§ 10.16 REPEAL OR MODIFICATION OF ORDINANCE.
   (A)   Whenever any ordinance or part of an ordinance shall be repealed or
modified by a subsequent ordinance, the ordinance or part of an ordinance thus
repealed or modified shall continue in force until the due publication of the
ordinance repealing or modifying it when publication is required to give effect
thereto, unless otherwise expressly provided.
   (B)   No suit, proceedings, right, fine, forfeiture, or penalty instituted,
created, given, secured, or accrued under any ordinance previous to its repeal
shall in any way be affected, released, or discharged, but may be prosecuted,
enjoyed, and recovered as fully as if the ordinance had continued in force
unless it is otherwise expressly provided.
   (C)   When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause, or provision
shall be itself repealed, the repeal shall not be construed to revive the
former ordinance, clause, or provision, unless it is expressly provided.
§ 10.17 ORDINANCES WHICH AMEND OR SUPPLEMENT CODE.
   (A)   If the Common Council shall desire to amend any existing chapter or
section of this code, the chapter or section shall be specifically repealed and
a new chapter or section, containing the desired amendment, substituted in its
place.
   (B)   Any ordinance which is proposed to add to the existing code a new
chapter or section shall indicate, with reference to the arrangement of this
code, the proper number of such chapter or section. In addition to such
indication thereof as may appear in the text of the proposed ordinance, a
caption or title shall be shown in concise form above the ordinance.
§ 10.18 SECTION HISTORIES; STATUTORY REFERENCES.
   (A)   As histories for the code sections, the specific number and passage
date of the original ordinance, and the most recent three amending ordinances,
if any, are listed following the text of the code section. Example: (Ord. 10,
passed 5-13-60; Am. Ord. 15, passed 1-1-70; Am. Ord. 20, passed 1-1-80; Am.
Ord. 25, passed 1-1-85)
   (B)   (1)   If a statutory cite is included in the history, this indicates
that the text of the section reads substantially the same as the statute.
Example: (IC 36-4-5-3) (Ord. 10, passed 1-17-80; Am. Ord. 20, passed 1-1-85).
      (2)   If a statutory cite is set forth as a “statutory reference”
following the text of the section, this indicates that the reader should refer
to that statute for further information. For Example:
   § 31.10 MAYOR.
      The Mayor shall preside at all meetings of the Common Council.
   (Ord. 10, passed 1-1-80)
   Statutory reference:
      For the powers and duties of the Mayor, see IC 36-4-5-3
§ 10.99 GENERAL PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person, firm, or corporation who violates any provision of this
code for which another penalty is not specifically provided shall, upon
conviction, be subject to a fine not exceeding $2,500. A separate offense shall
be deemed committed upon each day during which a violation occurs or continues.
      (1)   Any person adjudged guilty of violating any provision of this code
of ordinances may also be adjudged to pay the costs of prosecution.
      (2)   Any person adjudged guilty of violating this code, who fails to pay
the fine and costs, shall be subject to further penalties as provided by this
code and by the laws of the State of Indiana. If applicable laws of the state
and ordinances of the city permit, such person adjudged guilty of violating
this code who has failed to pay fines and costs, if physically able, shall
perform manual labor for the city, and a reasonable amount shall be allowed for
such labor until such fines and costs are paid and the defendant released, or
until his term has expired under such penalty provisions.
      (3)   Failure of a city officer to perform a duty prescribed by this code
shall not subject such officer to any penalty under this code, unless a penalty
is specifically provided.
      (4)   Each penalty clause or provision of the code shall include all of
the provisions of this section, by reference hereto, which shall be included in
each penalty section of the code.
('85 Code, § 1.06) (Ord. 21-1982, passed - -82)
   (B)   Notwithstanding the provisions of any section of this code setting
forth a penalty, the maximum penalty which may be imposed for any violation
shall not be less than the penalty prescribed by statutes for the same offense.
('85 Code, § 1.07)
   (C)   Reference to any section of this code includes the penalty section
relating thereto, unless otherwise expressly provided. In case of the amendment
of this code, any penalty provided in this code shall be held to relate to the
amendment whether reenacted in the amendatory ordinance or not, unless such
penalty is specifically repealed or amended therein. ('85 Code, § 1.08)
Cross-reference:
   Ordinance Violations Bureau, see
Ch. 36
   Schedule of Violations, see §
36.03

CHAPTER 30: CITY GOVERNMENT ORGANIZATION
Section
   
30.01   Crawfordsville city government to consist of four branches
   
30.02   Executive branch
   
30.03   Legislative branch
   
30.04   Fiscal branch
   
30.05   Statutory boards and commissions
§ 30.01 CRAWFORDSVILLE CITY GOVERNMENT TO CONSIST OF FOUR BRANCHES.
   The government of the city shall consist of four branches, those being:
   (A)   Executive Branch (IC 36-4-5);
   (B)   Legislative Branch (IC 36-4-6);
   (C)   Fiscal Branch (IC 36-4-10);
   (D)   Statutory Boards and Commissions.
(Ord. 3-2024, passed 2-13-24)
§ 30.02 EXECUTIVE BRANCH.
   (A)   Mayor. The Mayor is the city executive and head of the Executive
Branch. He or she shall faithfully perform the duties and responsibilities
contained in IC 36-4-5 and any other statutes of the state, and also in
accordance with the ordinances of the city as may be applicable.
      (1)   The Mayor must be elected under IC 3-10-6.
      (2)   He or she must be eligible to serve as the city executive under IC
3-8-1-26.
   (B)   Deputy Mayor. In accordance with IC 36-4-9-7, whenever the Mayor is
going to be absent from the city, ill, injured, or otherwise incapable of
discharging his or her duties, he or she may designate a person to fill the
position of Deputy Mayor, and after such appointment and certification, as
hereafter provided, the Deputy Mayor shall have the full power of the office of
the Mayor. The following provisions shall apply:
      (1)   The Mayor shall certify, in writing, to the Common Council and
Clerk-Treasurer the appointment including a specific duration of time to
include the time taking effect and time of expiration.
      (2)   The designee shall reside within the city.
   (C)   Director of Operations and Community Development. The Director of
Operations and Community Development will be responsible for fostering a
community development plan that promotes efficiency, growth, economic vitality,
and an enhanced quality of life in the City of Crawfordsville. This includes
overseeing the implementation of strategic projects, and initiatives, designed
to achieve the community development plan and further improving quality of
place, and quality of life, for all residents and businesses.
      (1)   The Director of Operations and Community Development shall be
appointed by the Mayor, shall serve at his or her pleasure, and shall be a
direct report to the Mayor in accordance with IC 36-4-9-4.
      (2)   The Director of Operations and Community Development shall have
full authority to represent the Mayor, and act on the Mayor's behalf in
administration of the duties of the Executive Branch.
      (3)   Department leaders may be assigned to report to Director of
Operations and Community Development when designated by the Mayor, or in the
Mayor's absence.
   (D)   Board of Public Works and Safety.  
      (1)   There is hereby established a Board of Public Works and Safety
within the Executive Branch. The Board of Works shall be comprised of the
Mayor, who also serves as presiding officer, and two other residents of the
city appointed by the Mayor in accordance with IC 36-4-9-5 and 36-4-9-8.
      (2)   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall serve as the chief
administrative body of the city, and shall oversee matters related to
regulatory compliance, personnel, and agreements or contracts related to the
following departments, not otherwise excluded:
         (a)   Fire Department;
         (b)   Police Department;
         (c)   Code Enforcement Department;
         (d)   Waste Water Utility;
         (e)   Street and Sanitation Department;
         (f)   Central Garage and Vehicle Fleet Maintenance Utility; and
         (g)   Clerk-Treasurer Department.
   (E)   Department of Law. There is hereby established a Department of Law
pursuant to IC 36- 4-9-4 with the powers and duties as set forth in IC 36-4-9-
12. The Department of Law shall also be governed by applicable ordinances of
the city as set out in this code of ordinances which are not in conflict
herewith.
      (1)   The Department of Law shall be overseen by the City Attorney.
      (2)   The City Attorney shall be licensed to practice law in the State of
Indiana in accordance with IC 36-4-9-11.
      (3)   The City Attorney shall be appointed by the Mayor and serve at his
or her pleasure pursuant to IC 36-4-9-8.
   (F)   City Engineer. A City Engineer shall be appointed to review all
proposed development plans within the city, and to serve as a professional
technical advisor to city departments.
      (1)   The City Engineer may be a direct employee of the city, or may be a
contractual employee of the city.
      (2)   The City Engineer shall be a licensed engineer in the State of
Indiana.
      (3)   The City Engineer shall be appointed by the Mayor, and shall serve
at his or her pleasure in accordance with IC 36-4-9-6.
   (G)   Department of Planning and Building Services. The Department of
Planning and Building Services is established for the purpose of ensuring
orderly development and construction within the city, in compliance with
ordinances, state laws and regulations. The department shall provide staff
liaison and advisory assistance to the Redevelopment Authority, Plan
Commission, Board of Zoning Appeals, Historic Preservation Commission, and
Economic Development Commission
      (1)   The Department of Planning and Building Services shall be overseen
by the Director of Planning and Building Services.
      (2)   The Director of Planning and Building Services shall be appointed
by the Mayor, and
shall serve at his or her pleasure in accordance with IC 36-4-9-4.
   (H)   Economic Development Department. The Economic Development Department
is established for the purpose of promoting private investment and job growth
within the city.
      (1)   The Economic Development Department shall be overseen by the
Economic Development Director.
      (2)   The Economic Development Director may be a direct employee of the
city, or may be
a contractual employee of the city.
      (3)   The Economic Development Director shall be appointed by the Mayor,
and shall serve at his or her pleasure in accordance with IC 36-4-9-4.
   (I)   Communications Department. The Communications Department is
established for the purpose of ensuring that information is relayed to the
public in a timely, accurate manner, in accordance with the city's brand, and
as directed by the Mayor or his or her designee.
      (1)   The Communications Department shall be overseen by the
Communications Director.
      (2)   The Communications Director shall be appointed by the Mayor, and
shall serve at his or her pleasure in accordance with IC 36-4-9-4.
   (J)   Police Department. The Police Department is established for the
purpose of enforcing local ordinances, the laws of the State of Indiana, and to
protect the general safety, security, peace and welfare of the city.
      (1)   The Police Department shall be overseen by the Chief of the Police
Department.
      (2)   The Chief of the Police Department shall be appointed by the Mayor,
and serve at his or her pleasure in accordance with IC 36-4-9-8.
      (3)   The Metropolitan Board of Police Commissioners shall oversee
personnel matters related to sworn officers of the Police Department who are
members of the Indiana Police and Fire Pension. This excludes:
         (a)   Chief of Police;
         (b)   Assistant Chief of Police;
         (c)   Civilian Parking Enforcement staff; and
         (d)   Civilian Police Department Staff.
   (K)   Fire Department. The Fire Department is established for the purpose of
enforcing fire and building safety ordinances and regulations of the State of
Indiana, to protect the general safety, health and welfare of the city.
      (1)   The Fire Department shall be overseen by the Fire Chief.
      (2)   The Fire Chief shall be appointed by the Mayor, and serve at his or
her pleasure in accordance with IC 36-4-9-8.
      (3)   The Board of Fire Commissioners shall oversee personnel matters
related to sworn members of the Fire Department who are members of the Indiana
Police and Fire Pension. This excludes:
         (a)   Fire Chief;
         (b)   Deputy Fire Chief;
         (c)   Battalion Chief;
         (d)   Civilian Emergency Medical Services (EMS) staff; and
         (e)   Civilian Fire Department staff.
   (L)   Streets and Sanitation Department. The Streets and Sanitation
Department is established for the purpose of ensuring the safety and
maintenance of city streets, and operation of the city's solid waste, trash and
recycling programs.
      (1)   The Streets and Sanitation Department shall be overseen by the
Street Commissioner.
      (2)   The Street Commissioner shall be appointed by the Mayor, and shall
serve at his or her pleasure in accordance with IC 36-4-9-4.
   (M)   Code Enforcement Department. The Code Enforcement Department is
established to enforce ordinances and state laws related to unkept properties,
abandoned vehicles, situations that threaten the health and safety of the
community.
      (1)   The Code Enforcement Department shall be overseen by the Code
Enforcement Officer.
      (2)   The Code Enforcement Officer shall be appointed by the Mayor, and
shall serve at his or her pleasure in accordance with IC 36-4-9-4.
   (N)   Parks and Recreation Department. The Parks and Recreation Department
is established pursuant to IC 36-10-3-3 for the purpose of developing and
maintain a system of public parks and programs that promote health and fitness
within the city.
      (1)   The Parks and Recreation Department shall be overseen by the
Director of Parks and Recreation.
      (2)   The Director of Parks and Recreation shall be appointed by the
Mayor, and shall serve at his or her pleasure in accordance with IC 36-4-9-2.
      (3)   The Park Board shall oversee matters related to regulatory
compliance, personnel, and agreements or contracts related to the Parks and
Recreation Department.
   (O)   Aviation Department. The Aviation Department is established for the
operation of Crawfordsville Regional Airport.
      (1)   The Aviation Department shall be overseen by Manager of the
Crawfordsville Regional Airport.
      (2)   The Manager of the Crawfordsville Regional Airport shall be
appointed by the Mayor, and shall serve at his or her pleasure in accordance
with IC 36-4-9-2.
      (3)   The Aviation Board shall oversee matters related to regulatory
compliance, personnel, and agreements or contracts related to operation of
Crawfordsville Regional Airport.
   (P)   Waste Water Utility. The Waste Water Utility is established for the
operation of the city's sanitary sewer system, including the collection and
treatment of waste water in a manner that ensures compliance with ordinances,
state laws and regulations and federal laws and regulations.
      (1)   The Waste Water Utility shall be overseen by the Waste Water
Superintendent.
      (2)   The Waste Water Superintendent shall be appointed by the Mayor, and
shall serve at his or her pleasure in accordance with IC 36-4-9-4.
   (Q)   Storm Water Utility. The Storm Water Utility is established for the
operation of the city's storm water collection system and to ensure
effectiveness in properly removing storm runoff in a manner that promotes water
quality and compliance with ordinances, state laws and regulations, and federal
laws and regulations.
      (1)   The Storm Water Utility shall be overseen by the Street
Commissioner.
      (2)   The Street Commissioner may choose to appoint a Storm Water
Superintendent to oversee daily operations and ensure compliance.
   (R)   Central Garage and Vehicle Fleet Maintenance Utility. The Central
Garage and Vehicle Maintenance Utility is established to oversee maintenance of
vehicles in the city fleet to ensure safety, efficiency and cost effectiveness.
      (1)   Participation in Central Garage and Maintenance shall be at the
discretion of department leaders in consultation with the Mayor.
      (2)   The Central Garage and Maintenance Utility shall be overseen by the
Street Commissioner.
   (S)   Electric Utility. Crawfordsville Electric, Light and Power is
established as the electric utility and shall ensure the safe, efficient, and
cost-effective operation and distribution of electrical power to areas within
their service territory.
      (1)   The Electric Utility shall be overseen by the General Manager of
Crawfordsville, Electric, Light and Power.
      (2)   The General Manager of Crawfordsville, Electric, Light and Power
shall be appointed by the Utility Service Board, with concurrence from the
Mayor, in accordance with IC 36-4-9-2.
      (3)   The Utility Service Board shall oversee matters related to
regulatory compliance, personnel, and agreements or contracts related to
operation of Crawfordsville Electric, Light, and Power.
   (T)   Mobile Integrated Health. The Mobile Integrated Health Department is
established to improve overall health conditions for those who live and work in
the community by promoting enhanced interaction with the healthcare system to
promote improved outcomes while lowering costs in a manner that creates good
health for all, creates a vibrant community, promotes social inclusion, and
breaks cycles of disadvantage.
      (1)   The Mobile Integrated Health Department shall be overseen by the
Director of Mobile Integrated Health.
      (2)   The Director of Mobile Integrated Health shall be appointed by the
Mayor, and shall serve at his or her pleasure in accordance with IC 36-4-9-4.
      (3)   The Mobile Integrated Health Department shall be affiliated with
the Crawfordsville Fire Department, EMS Division for activities requiring
medical director oversight and medical control affiliation.
      (4)   The Fire Chief, or his/her designee, shall provide oversight and
coordination with the medical director, medical control, and regulatory
agencies for activities involving the delivery of medical care.
(Ord. 3-2024, passed 2-13-24)
§ 30.03 LEGISLATIVE BRANCH.
   (A)   The Legislative Branch of the city is the Common Council. The Council
shall have exclusive authority to adopt ordinances and appropriate tax moneys
received by the city, and to perform any other necessary and desirable
legislative functions in accordance with IC 36-4-6.
   (B)   The Common Council shall conduct business in accordance with
Chapter 31.
   (C)   The Mayor, or in his or her absence, the President of the Council, who
shall be elected by the Common Council at the first meeting of the Council's
new term, shall be the presiding officer of the Council pursuant to IC 36-4-6-
8 and meetings shall be conducted pursuant to the applicable statutes (IC 36-4-
6-10 through 36-4-6-17) and in accordance with all other pertinent ordinances
of the city heretofore passed by the Common Council which are not in conflict
herewith, which are hereby adopted and affirmed as part of this section.
   (D)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall be the Clerk of the Common Council and shall
perform the duties prescribed by IC 36-4-6-9 and such others as the Council may
direct, by ordinance or other official act. The Clerk-Treasurer shall perform
other duties as prescribed by IC 36-4-10-4 and IC 36-4-10-4.5.
   (E)   Ward Boundaries. The city shall consist of five Council election
districts under I.C. 36-4-6-4 as follows:
      (1)   Ward One.
         (a)   Beginning at the southeast corner of Ward 1, said point being
the intersection of the CSX Railroad right-of-way and West Market Street;
thence westerly, along the centerline of West Market Street to the centerline
of North Grant Avenue; thence northerly along the centerline of North Grant
Avenue to the centerline of North Street; thence westerly, along the centerline
of North Street to the corporate limits of the city; thence northerly, on and
along said corporate limits to the centerline of Covington Street; thence
westerly, along the centerline of Covington Street to the centerline of Bluff
Street; thence southerly along the centerline of Bluff Street to the centerline
of West Market Street; thence easterly along the centerline of West Market
Street to the centerline of Vance Street; thence southerly, along the
centerline of Vance Street, crossing West Main Street and West Pike Street to
the centerline of West Wabash Avenue; thence westerly, along the centerline of
West Wabash Avenue to the intersection with the centerline of Schenck Road;
thence southerly along the centerline of Schenck Road to the northern edge of a
private drive along Schenck Road (85 South Schenck Road); thence westerly, in
back yards; thence southerly, in back yards; thence westerly, in back yards;
thence southerly, in back yards; thence westerly, in back yards; thence
northerly, in back yards; thence westerly, in back yards; thence northerly, in
back yards; thence westerly, in back yards; thence southerly, in back yards
until the intersection with the centerline of Sugar Creek Trail; thence
westerly, along the centerline of Sugar Creek Trail to the intersection with
the corporate limits of the city; thence northerly, on and along said corporate
limits; thence westerly, on and along said corporate limits; thence northerly,
on and along said corporate limits; thence westerly, on and along said
corporate limits to the intersection with the centerline of Country Club Road;
thence northerly, along the centerline of Country Club Road to the intersection
with the corporate limits of the city; thence westerly, on and along said
corporate limits; thence northerly, on and along said corporate limits; thence
northeasterly, on and along said corporate limits; thence northerly, on and
along said corporate limits; thence easterly, on and along said corporate
limits; thence northeasterly, on and along said corporate limits to the
centerline of Sugar Creek, following the centerline of Sugar Creek, crossing
U.S. 136, and continuing in an easterly direction along the centerline of Sugar
Creek to the intersection of the centerline of Sugar Creek with Lafayette
Avenue; thence northeasterly, along the centerline of Lafayette Avenue for a
short distance; thence northwesterly along the north side of Sugar Creek;
thence northerly, along the corporate limits of the city to the intersection of
the corporate limits of the city with the centerline of Oak Hill Road; thence
southeasterly, along the centerline of Oak Hill Road to the intersection of Oak
Hill Road and Indian Springs Road; thence northeasterly, along the corporate
limits of the city to the intersection of the corporate limits of the city with
the centerline of West Old Oak Hill Road; thence southeasterly, along the
centerline of West Old Oak Hill Road to the intersection of West Old Oak Hill
Road with Lafayette Avenue; thence northerly, along the centerline of Lafayette
Avenue to the intersection of Lafayette Avenue with Lafayette Road (U.S. 231);
thence northerly, along the centerline of Lafayette Road (U.S. 231) to the
intersection of Lafayette Road (U.S. 231) with private driveway located north
of Northridge Drive; thence westerly, along the corporate limits of the city;
thence northerly, along the corporate limits of the city; thence westerly,
along the corporate limits of the city; thence northerly, along the corporate
limits of the city; thence easterly, along the corporate limits of the city to
the intersection with the centerline of CR N 100 W; thence northwesterly, along
the centerline of CR N 100 W to the intersection of the centerline of CR N 100
W with the corporate limits of the city; thence easterly, along the corporate
limits of the city; thence northerly, along the corporate limits of the city to
the intersection of the corporate limits of the city with the centerline of
Industrial Boulevard; thence westerly, along the centerline of Industrial
Boulevard; thence continuing west, along the centerline of Industrial Boulevard
to the intersection with the corporate limits of the city; thence northerly,
along the corporate limits of the city; thence easterly, along the corporate
limits of the city to the intersection of the corporate limits of the city with
the east side of Lafayette Avenue (U.S. 231); thence northerly, along the east
side of Lafayette Avenue (U.S. 231), crossing Interstate 74 to the point of
intersection of the north corporate limits with the right-of-way of the CSX
Railroad (east of U.S. 231); thence southerly, on and along said corporate
limits; thence easterly, along the corporate limits of the city to the
intersection of the corporate limits of the city with the centerline of Concord
Road; thence southwesterly, along the centerline of Concord Road, crossing
Interstate 74 and continuing along the centerline of Concord Road to the
intersection of the centerline of Concord Road with the corporate limits of the
city; thence easterly, along the corporate limits of the city to the western
boundary of the CSX Railroad right-of-way, continuing in a southerly direction,
along said right-of-way and the corporate limits of the city; thence easterly,
to the centerline of Sugar Creek; thence southeasterly, along the centerline of
Sugar Creek, crossing Sugar Creek; thence northeasterly along the corporate
limits of the city; thence southerly, along said corporate limits to the
intersection with the centerline of Sugar Creek; thence easterly, along the
centerline of Sugar Creek to the corporate limits of the city, following said
corporate limits to the intersection of said corporate limits with the
centerline of Memorial Drive; thence westerly, along the centerline of Memorial
Drive to the intersection with the centerline of Whitlock Avenue; thence
southerly, along the centerline of Whitlock Avenue to the intersection with the
centerline of Ohio Street; thence westerly, along the centerline of Ohio Street
to the centerline of Kentucky Street; thence northerly, along the centerline of
Kentucky Street to the intersection with the centerline of an un-named alley
(across from 606 Kentucky Street); thence westerly along the centerline of said
alley and continuing in a westerly direction along the corporate limits of the
city, crossing the CSX Railroad; thence southerly, along said corporate limits
following the western right-of-way of the CSX Railroad to the intersection of
said right-of-way with the centerline of West Market Street (southeast corner
of Ward 1) and being the point of beginning of this description.
         (b)   An exception (gap area) exists between Ward 1 and Ward 2. This
exception is an area beginning along the centerline of Schenck Road to the
northern edge of a private drive along Schenck Road (85 South Schenck Road);
thence westerly, in back yards; thence southerly, in back yards; thence
westerly, in back yards; thence southerly, in back yards; thence westerly, in
back yards; thence northerly, in back yards; thence westerly, in back yards;
thence northerly, in back yards; thence westerly, in back yards; thence
southerly, in back yards until the intersection with the centerline of Sugar
Creek Trail; thence easterly, along the centerline of Sugar Creek Trail to the
intersection with the western property line of a private property (225 South
Schenck Road); thence southerly along said western property line to the
intersection with the southern property line of said property; thence easterly,
along said south property line to the intersection of the southern property
line with the centerline of Schenck Road; thence northerly, along the
centerline of Schenck Road to the northern edge of a private drive along
Schenck Road (85 South Schenck Road), being the point of beginning of this
exception description.
      (2)   Ward Two. Beginning at the northeast corner of Ward 2, said point
being the intersection of West Market Street (U.S. Hwy 136) and Green Street;
thence westerly, along the centerline of West Market Street (U.S. Hwy 136) to
the centerline of North Grant Avenue; thence northerly along the centerline of
North Grant Avenue to the centerline of North Street; thence westerly, along
the centerline of North Street to the property line between 408 West North
Street and 410 West North Street; thence northerly, on the west side of
Harrison Street, continuing in a northerly direction to the centerline of
Covington Street; thence westerly, along the centerline of Covington Street to
the centerline of Bluff Street; thence southerly along the centerline of Bluff
Street to the centerline of West Market Street; thence easterly along the
centerline of West Market Street to the centerline of Vance Street; thence
southerly, along the centerline of Vance Street, crossing West Main Street and
West Pike Street to the centerline of West Wabash Avenue; thence westerly,
along the centerline of West Wabash Avenue to the intersection with the
centerline of Schenck Road; thence southerly along the centerline of Schenck
Road to the intersection with the southern property line of a private property
(225 South Schenck Road); thence westerly, along said southern property line to
the intersection with the western property line of said property; thence
northerly, along said western property line to the intersection with the
centerline of Sugar Creek Trail; thence westerly, along the centerline of Sugar
Creek Trail to the intersection with the corporate limits of the city; thence
southerly, along the corporate limits of the city to the intersection with the
centerline of Big 4 Arch Road; thence easterly, along the centerline of Big 4

§ 30.04 FISCAL BRANCH.
   (A)   The Fiscal Branch of the city is the Common Council. The Council shall
have exclusive authority to appropriate tax moneys received by the city in
accordance with IC 36-4-7.
   (B)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall serve as the fiscal agent for the city in
accordance with 36-4-10, ensuring the proper accounting of all funds,
distributions in accordance with appropriations, and accurate record keeping in
accordance with ordinances and the laws of the State of Indiana.
(Ord. 3-2024, passed 2-13-24)
§ 30.05 STATUTORY BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS.
   The fourth branch of city government shall be comprised of boards and
commissions as defined in
Chapter 33.
(Ord. 3-2024, passed 2-13-24)
CHAPTER 31: COMMON COUNCIL
Section

§ 31.01 QUORUM AND MEETINGS.
   (A)   A majority of the Council constitutes a quorum for the transaction of
business.
   (B)   Except as otherwise provided by statute, the Council shall meet in
regular session at least once per month at six o'clock in the evening on the
second Monday of the month unless changed from time to time by motion. If the
second Monday of any month is a legal holiday or day on which city's offices
are closed, the regular session must be scheduled on the next day that is not a
legal holiday or day on which the city's offices are closed.
(‘85 Code, § 3.01) (Am. Ord. 4-2010, passed 4-13-10; Am. Ord. 28-2019, passed
12-9-19)
§ 31.02 OFFICERS ATTENDING MEETINGS.
   The members of the Council, the Mayor, the Clerk-Treasurer, Chief of Police,
Street Commissioner, City Attorney, City Engineer, City Park Director, City
Planning Director, Sewage Treatment Plant Manager and Chief of the Fire
Department shall be present at each regular meeting of the Council.
(‘85 Code, § 3.08) (Am. Ord. 4-1993)
§ 31.03 (RESERVED).
§ 31.04 COMMITTEE APPOINTMENTS BY MAYOR.
   (A)   The following standing committees of the Council shall be appointed by
the Mayor before the first January meeting of the Council, and annually
thereafter, and shall be composed of no less than three, nor more than four
members each. The Mayor shall designate one member to serve as committee
chairperson. The Mayor is ex officio a member of all committees. Two members
constitute a quorum. The standing committees shall be as follows:
      (1)   Annexation.
      (2)   Fiscal affairs.
      (3)   Ordinances and petitions.
      (4)   Traffic, parking and safety.
   (B)   The Mayor may appoint such special committees as he deems appropriate
and determine the number of members and the Chairperson.
(‘85 Code, § 3.02) (Am. Ord. 29-1995, passed 12-11-95; Am. Ord. 2-2000, passed
3-13-00)
§ 31.05 CONDUCT OF BUSINESS.
   (A)   The Mayor, or in the absence of the Mayor, the President of the
Council shall preside at all meetings of the Council.
   (B)   The Chairperson of each committee will present to the Council business
which has passed through their respective committee meeting prior to the
Council meeting or that which is passed during a “Committee of the Whole
Council”. An agenda of business shall be made available to Council members no
later than three calendar days prior to the Council meeting.
(‘85 Code, § 3.03) (Am. Ord. 29-1995, passed 12-11-95)
§ 31.06 RULES OF PROCEDURE.
   The following rules shall govern the meetings of the Council:
   (A)   Rule 1 — Order of Business. The order of business shall be as follows:
      (1)   Roll call.
      (2)   Reading of minutes.
      (3)   Roll call for questions or suggested additions to the agenda.
      (4)   Reports of standing committees.
         (a)   Finance.
         (b)   Fiscal Affairs.
         (c)   Ordinances and Petitions.
         (d)   Traffic, Parking and Safety.
      (5)   Reports of special committees.
      (6)   Miscellaneous business.
      (7)   Adjournment.
   (B)   Roll call. Roll will be called by the Clerk/Treasurer who will record
whether each member is present or absent. If absent, refer to §
31.03.
   (C)   Rule 3 — Reading of minutes. Minutes of the previous meeting will be
considered for approval. Any additions or corrections may be made at this time
with the approval of a majority of the Council.
   (D)   Rule 4 — Questions or suggested additions. Council members may ask
Department Heads attending the meeting questions pertaining to their respective
departments. Questions shall be of business nature and avoid personality.
Suggested additions to the agenda may be made with the consent of a majority of
the Council. Any suggested addition which proposes an ordinance or resolution
will be referred to the appropriate Standing Committee unless the Council
chooses to meet as a “Committee of the Whole Council”.
   (E)   Rule 5 — Reports of standing committees. Chairpersons of each standing
committee will present to Council items which have been assigned to their
respective committee, have been voted upon, and have been forwarded on to the
Council with one of the following recommendations:
      (1)   Favorable.
      (2)   Unfavorable.
      (3)   No recommendation.
Items previously “laid upon the table” may also be presented at this time.
   (F)   Rule 6 — Report of special committees. Chairpersons of each special
committee may be asked by the Mayor or any Council member questions pertaining
to their respective committee. These questions shall be of business nature and
avoid personality.
   (G)   Rule 7 — Miscellaneous business. Items which do not pertain to
standing or special committees shall be placed under miscellaneous business.
   (H)   Rule 8 — Adjournment. All business will cease with the affirmative
vote of a majority of the Council to adjourn.
(‘85 Code, § 3.04) (Am. Ord. 29-1995, passed 12-11-95)
§ 31.07 PRESENTATION OF BUSINESS.
   (A)   Rule 1 — Ordinances. The title of proposed ordinances shall clearly
set forth the nature of the contents.
      (1)   First reading. A proposed ordinance shall be introduced by its
completed title, a brief summary of its purpose or contents, and the
recommendation of the committee of record, including that committee’s vote on
the ordinance. The ordinance shall be read aloud in its entirety only if
requested by a member of the Council or by a member of the public present at
the meeting.
      (2)   Second reading. Proposed ordinances, which have been passed on
first reading, shall be read by title only and at this time are subject to
amendments. A majority vote of all members is required to amend a proposed
ordinance. A majority vote of all members is required for proposed ordinance,
in its original or amended context, to proceed to third reading or final
passage.
      (3)   Third reading and final passage. Proposed ordinances, which have
been passed on first and second readings, shall be read by title only and may
be amended; but should any member desire, it shall be read through as amended.
A majority vote of all members is required for third reading and final passage.
Failing to receive a majority vote by all members on third reading, the
proposed ordinance is defeated.
   (B)   Rule 2 — Resolutions. A proposed resolution shall be introduced by its
completed title, a brief summary of its purpose or contents, and the
recommendation of the committee of record, including that committee’s vote on
the resolution. The resolution shall be read aloud in its entirety only if
requested by a member of the Council or by a member of the public present at
the meeting.
   (C)   Rule 3 — Ordinances and resolutions. An ordinance once passed may be
amended or repealed by subsequent ordinance; a resolution once passed may be
rescinded by subsequent resolution.
   (D)   Rule 4 — Motions.
      (1)   A motion to adjourn cannot be reconsidered, is not debatable and
cannot be repeated unless other business has intervened between the motions. A
motion to “reconsider” and a motion to “adjourn to a day certain” are
privileged questions and are debatable. A motion to “lay upon the table” is not
debatable and must be voted upon at that time. Business which by law or
necessity must or should be transacted within a certain time is considered a
question of privilege. A motion to “suspend the rules” is a privileged
question, is not debatable, and cannot be amended except with the consent of
the mover.
      (2)   Matter “laid upon the table” may be taken up any time; except a
motion to reconsider once laid on the table may not be taken up again.
      (3)   No matter or proposition on a subject different from that under
discussion shall be admitted under color of an amendment.
      (4)   A majority vote of all Council members is required for passage of
all motions.
   (E)   Rule 5 — General Council Rules.
      (1)   The Robert Rules of Parliamentary Law, so far as applicable, are
the rules of the Council, unless they conflict with the rules herein.
      (2)    A majority of all members of the Council constitutes a quorum for
the transaction of business. Less than a quorum may meet and adjourn.
      (3)   No person not a member of the Council or Administration shall be
permitted to address the Council, unless recognized by the presiding officers
or with the approval of a majority vote of the Council. Upon recognition, the
presiding officer shall instruct the individual of the proper time, place, and
order which they shall take on the meeting agenda.
      (4)   When members desire to address the Council, they shall address the
Mayor as “Mr. or Madam Mayor” and on being recognized may address the Council.
They shall confine themselves to the subject in debate and avoid personality.
The Mayor shall recognize any member unless he or she is not in his or her seat
and seeking recognition in the proper way.
      (5)   When the Mayor or any member is addressing the Council, no member
shall engage in private conversation or walk across or leave the room
unnecessarily.
      (6)   No member shall speak more than twice on the same question without
leave of the Council; nor more than once until every member choosing to speak
shall have spoken. Speeches shall be limited to five minutes unless further
time is granted by the Council; answering questions is not considered a part of
the speaker’s time.
      (7)   Every member must vote upon every question unless disqualified by
law or excused by the Council. Any member may change his or her vote before the
announcement of the result by the Mayor.
      (8)   If any member violates these rules, the Mayor, or any member, shall
call him or her to order. In case of a call to order, the member in control of
the floor will yield until the point of order has been decided. Wilful or
repeated transgressions constitute an offense against the Council and are
punishable by reprimand or removal of office.
      (9)   Any of these rules may be amended or repealed by a majority vote of
all members of the Council. No vote to amend or repeal shall be taken until at
least two weeks notice of such intention has been given.
(Ord. 29-1995, passed 12-11-95; Am. Res. 4-2000, passed 3-13-00; Am. Ord. 7-
2004, passed 6-14-04)
§ 31.08 STANDING COMMITTEES.
   (A)   Meeting times. The standing committees of the Council shall meet at
least once per month at six o'clock in the evening on the first Monday of the
month unless changed from time to time by motion. If the first Monday of any
month is a legal holiday or day on which the city's offices are closed, the
committee session must be scheduled on the next day that is not a legal holiday
or day on which the city's offices are closed.
   (B)   Rules of business.
      (1)   All items for business shall be assigned to the proper committee by
the Mayor without debate, or may be presented to the committee Chairperson by
member or that committee. If presented to the committee Chairperson, that
committee Chairperson will in turn inform the Mayor of the nature of the
business no later than three days prior to the meeting of the committee.
      (2)   All items for business, either handwritten or typed, shall be made
available to all committee members no later than three calendar days prior to
the meeting of the committee unless unanimously agreed upon by the committee
members.
      (3)   All items of business shall be forwarded to the Council at its next
meeting with one of the following recommendations:
         (a)   Favorable.
         (b)   Unfavorable.
         (c)   No recommendation.
      (4)   The Robert’s Rules of order, so far as applicable, are the rules of
standing committees, unless they conflict with the rules herein.
(Ord. 29-1995, passed 12-11-95; Am. Ord. 3-2000, passed 3-13-00; Am. Ord. 4-
2010, passed 4-13-10; Am. Ord. 5-2013, passed 2-11-13; Am. Ord. 28-2019, passed
12-9-19)
§ 31.09 OFFENSES OF CITY OFFICERS.
   (A)   Offenses of city officers are:
      (1)   Any violation of the criminal laws of the state;
      (2)   Gross immoral conduct; incompetency;
      (3)   Corruption in office;
      (4)   Failure to discharge official duty;
      (5)   Premeditatedly discourteous conduct toward any member of the city
government in official relations;
      (6)   The refusal of any city officer required by law to give official
bond or other security to his bond, when the same is required by order of the
Council; or
      (7)   The refusal, neglect or failure to obey any orders made by the
Mayor and Council.
   (B)   Any city officer guilty of any offenses herein enumerated may be
removed from office by a two-thirds vote of the Council upon conviction as
hereinafter set forth, or he may be reprimanded, or both.
(‘85 Code, § 3.05)
§ 31.10 TRIAL OF OFFENDING OFFICERS.
   The Council shall constitute the court for the trial of all officers against
whom charges have been preferred, and shall be the judges of the law and the
evidence. The Mayor shall preside, except when he shall be on trial, in which
case the Council shall choose one of their own number to preside, in whom shall
be vested all the powers of the Mayor for the enforcement of the trial. The
rules of evidence as allowed by the civil courts of the state shall govern.
Charges shall be made in writing, setting forth the offense and the
specifications of the same, and made under oath or affirmation, and shall be
accompanied with a list of witnesses, and each charge when so made shall be
filed with the Clerk-Treasurer and by him shall be referred to the Council for
action at the next meeting thereafter. Upon such reference, the Council shall
fix the time for the trial of the charges and a copy of the charges shall be
regularly served upon the accused by the Chief of Police together with notice
of the day fixed for the hearing thereof. Both the accused and the accuser
shall have the right of process for the attendance of witnesses, which process
shall be served by the proper officer, and both parties shall have the right to
appear before the Council on the trial of the cause in person or by attorney or
by both. Should the accused refuse or neglect to obey the process or fail to
appear before the Council on the day fixed for the hearing as herein set forth,
the Council may hear and determine the same in his absence. After the evidence
and argument shall have been heard, the Council shall go into executive session
and shall make up their verdict, which shall be presented in writing and made
part of the record of the city, along with all other proceedings under these
rules.
(‘85 Code, § 3.06)

§ 32.01 BOND OF CITY OFFICIALS.
   (A)   All city officials and employees who are required to be bonded shall
be bonded in the amounts set forth in state law.
   (B)   In addition, all city officers and employees not specifically covered
by the foregoing statutes shall be subject to a blanket bond in the amount
required by state law.
   (C)   (1)   In light of the foregoing, the following bonding amounts are
hereby adopted for the following officials of the city:
OFFICIAL BOND AMOUNT
OFFICIAL                                      BOND AMOUNT
Clerk-Treasurer                               $300,000
Deputy Clerk-Treasurer                        $25,000
City Attorney                                 $15,000
Chief of Police                               $15,000
Plan Director                                 $15,000
Park & Recreation Director                    $50,000
Street Commissioner                           $15,000
CEL&P Manager                                 $50,000
CEL&P Controller                              $300,000
Blanket Bond (all other employees & officers) $20,000
 
      (2)   Any official or employee not specifically named above shall be
covered by and subject to the blanket bond of the city.
      (3)   In the event that the minimum requirements of state law change in
the future, then those requirements shall become the minimum bonding
requirements of the city, it being the intention of the Common Council that the
amounts set forth in this section be continuously updated to reflect the actual
minimum requirements of state law.
   (D)   Crime insurance policy.
      (1)   In the alternative to individual surety bonds; the city may
purchase a crime insurance policy that provides for the criminal acts or
omissions committed by; endorsed to include faithful performance of all
employees, commission members, and persons acting on behalf of the city,
including but not limited to City Judges and Clerk-Treasurer, Deputy Clerk-
Treasurer, City Attorney, Chief of Police, Plan Director, Park and Recreation
Director, Street Commissioner, CELP Manager, CELP Controller, all other
employees and officers, and employees directed to file an individual bond by
the fiscal body of the city in lieu of surety bond for individuals; and
      (2)   Unless a crime insurance policy is canceled, the policy must
continue in force for the term of office of the individual who files the
policy; and
      (3)   The aggregate liability of the surety or insurer is the amount
specified in the policy;
      (4)   It is the policy of the city to comply with all provisions of the
Indiana Code. If a policy of the city and a provision of the Indiana Code
regarding crime-insurance policies under IC 5-4-1-18 conflict, the Indiana Code
will be deemed to be the policy of the city and will be enforceable as if
specifically written in this policy.
(‘85 Code, § 4.13) (Am. Res. 25-1995, passed 9-11-95; Am. Ord. 16-2004, passed
7-12-04; Am. Ord. 27-2009, passed 12-14-09; Am. Ord. 26-2019, passed 12-9-19)
Statutory reference:
   Individual surety bonds and blanket bonds for city employees, see I.C. 5-4-
1-18 and 5-4-1-19
§ 32.02 INDEMNIFICATION OF OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES.
   (A)   Under the circumstances hereinafter set out, the city does hereby
agree to hold harmless and indemnify all elected officials and employees from
any and all liability that may arise out of and in the course of the
performance of the duties of such elected officials and employees for and on
behalf of the city.
   (B)   Such agreement of indemnification shall extend not only to the payment
of money judgments and compensatory damages, but also to punitive damages,
attorney fees, miscellaneous costs of defense and the like.
   (C)   As a condition of this indemnification agreement and its validity for
the benefit of the elected officials and employees, the city reserves the right
to choose and select the attorney to provide the defense against any such claim
for damages on behalf of the elected official, appointed official or employee
to be indemnified; further that, nothing herein contained shall prevent the
elected official, appointed official or employee from securing counsel of his
own choosing, but he or she shall do so at his or her own expense.
   (D)   This agreement of indemnification shall extend to and for the benefit
of each elected official, appointed official and employee of the town so long
as the claim or lawsuit presented or filed against such elected official,
appointed official or employee shall arise out of and in the course of the
performance of official duties on behalf of the city by the elected official,
appointed official or employee, and at the time of the committing of the
alleged acts, such elected official, appointed official or employee shall in
good faith believe he or she acted within the scope of his or her authority on
behalf of the city and consistent with the policy thereof. Even though acts
alleged to have been committed by the elected official, appointed official or
employee may constitute a violation of IC Chapter 35, this shall not act as an
absolute bar to the effectiveness of this indemnification agreement, but if
such acts are proven to be a violation of IC Chapter 35, that shall be prima
facie evidence that such elected official, appointed official or employee was
not acting in good faith within the scope of his or her duties and
responsibilities for the city, which is, of course, rebuttable by the elected
official, appointed official or employee.
   (E)   If an elected official, appointed official or employee shall be
required to employ an attorney or incur other litigation expenses in the course
of successfully securing an indemnification hereunder, the city shall further
be liable for such attorney fees and litigation expenses of the elected
official, appointed official or employee.
(‘85 Code, § 4.23) (Ord. 31-1984, passed - -84)
§ 32.03 PAYMENT OF SALARIES.
   The salaries and wages of the city officers and employees shall be paid
biweekly at the end of the pay period.

§ 32.04 PAYMENT OF MILEAGE.
   (A)   Officers and employees of the city who use their personal vehicles for
city business within the scope of their employment shall be reimbursed by the
city at the federal mileage reimbursement rate prevailing at the time of use of
their vehicles.
   (B)   The Clerk-Treasurer is authorized and directed to pay to any officer
or employee of the city, for travel performed for and on behalf of the city,
the federal mileage reimbursement rate for such mileage, upon proper voucher
for such travel, submitted and processed as all other vouchers of the city for
money due.
(‘85 Code, § 4.21) (Ord. 29-1984, passed - -84; Am. Ord. 25-2005, passed 10-11-
05)
§ 32.05 INSURANCE FOR RETIREES.
   (A)   Coverage under the city’s group health insurance plan will be
available to retired full-time employees of the city, under the following
conditions:
      (1)   For persons in retirement status as of August 1, 1986, to September
30, 1986, providing all of the following criteria are met:
         (a)   The retiree has at least ten years of continuous full-time
employment with the city;
         (b)   The sum of the retiree’s number of years of qualifying service
at retirement and his/her age on September 30, 1986, is equal to or greater
than 65;
         (c)   The retiree’s application for coverage on a form designated by
the city insurance carrier reaches the insurance carrier on or before September
30, 1986;
         (d)   The insurance carrier finds that the retiree is in sufficiently
good health to be considered insurable. Insurability will be determined solely
by the insurance carrier; and
         (e)   The retiree is not eligible for Medicare.
      (2)   For persons who retire after August 1, 1986, coverage will be
available for a period of 60 days. If coverage required under the Consolidated
Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act (COBRA) of 1985 is elected, the 60 days will
start on the date COBRA coverage ceases. If COBRA coverage is not elected, the
60 days will start on the date of retirement. All of the following criteria
must be met:
         (a)   The retiree has at least ten years of continuous full-time
employment with the city;
         (b)   The retiree’s application for coverage, on a form designated by
the city’s group insurance carrier, reaches the insurance carrier on or before
the expiration of the previously mentioned 60-day enrollment period; and,
         (c)   The retiree is not eligible for Medicare.
   (B)   A covered employee may cover any persons who are his/her dependents
according to the city’s group health insurance contract. However, dependents of
persons described in division (A)(1) above may be rejected for health reasons
only at the insurance carrier’s sole discretion. Coverage for any person will
cease on the first of the month he or she becomes eligible for Medicare.
Coverage will cease for any retiree and any covered dependents on the first of
any month for which premium payment has not been received by the insurance
carrier within 30 days of the due date.
(Ord. 21-1986, passed 7-28-86)
