§ 32.08 NEPOTISM AND CONTRACTING WITH A UNIT BY A RELATIVE POLICIES ADOPTED.
   (A)   The city finds that it is necessary and desirous to adopt a policy of
conduct with regard to nepotism in the employment with the city and in
contracting with the city in order to continue to be able to provide local
government services to its residents and to comply with the new laws effective
July 1, 2012 known as IC 36-1-20.2 and IC 36-1-21, respectively.
   (B)   On July 1, 2012 the city shall have a nepotism and a contracting with
a unit policy that complies with the minimum requirements of IC 36-1-20.2
(hereinafter “nepotism policy”) and IC 36-1-21 (hereinafter “contracting with a
unit by a relative policy”) and implementation will begin.
   (C)   The city nepotism policy is hereby established effective July 1, 2012
by adopting the minimum requirements provisions of IC 36-1-20.2, and including
all future supplements and amendments thereto which become law from time to
time, and making them a part hereof as if fully set out herein. In addition a
copy of IC 36-1-20.2 (Nepotism) in effect on July 1 is attached to Resolution
No. 15-2012.
   (D)   The city contracting with a unit by a relative policy is hereby
established effective July 1, 2012 by adopting the minimum requirements
provisions of IC 36-1-21, and including all future supplements and amendments
thereto which become law from time to time, and making them a part hereof as if
fully set out herein. In addition a copy of IC 36-1-21 (Contracting with a Unit
by a Relative) in effect on July 1 is attached to Resolution No. 15-2012.
   (E)   The city finds that both IC 36-1-20.2 and IC 36-1-21 specifically
allow a unit to adopt requirements that are more stringent or detailed and that
more detailed are necessary.
   (F)   The city further finds that a single member of the legislative body
cannot act for the body to make work assignments, compensation, grievances,
advancement or a performance evaluation without prior authority of a majority
of the body and therefore without such authority by the majority he or she will
not be in the direct line of supervision. See IC 36-4-6-11 and IC 36-5-2-9.4.
   (G)   The city finds that a single member of governing bodies with authority
over employees in the city cannot act for the governing body to make work
assignments, compensation, grievances, advancement or a performance evaluation
without prior authority of a majority of the body, when a statute provides that
a majority is needed to act, and therefore, without such authority by the
majority the single member will not be in the direct line of supervision.
   (H)   All elected and appointed officials and employees of the city are
hereby directed to cooperate fully in the implementation of the policies
created by this section and demonstrating compliance with these same policies.
   (I)   Failure to abide by or cooperate with the implementation, compliance
and certifications connected with the nepotism policy is a violation and may
result in the discipline, including termination, of an employee or a transfer
from the direct line of supervision or other curative action. An elected or
appointed official of the city who fails to abide by or cooperate with the
implementation, with the compliance and with mandated certifications of either
the nepotism policy or the contracting with a unit by a relative policy may be
subject to action allowed by law.
   (J)   Failure to abide by or cooperate with the implementation, compliance
and certifications connected with the contracting with a unit by a relative
policy is a violation and may result in the discipline, including termination,
of an employee or a curative action. An elected or appointed official of the
city who fails to abide by or cooperate with the implementation, with the
compliance and with mandated certifications of either the nepotism policy or
the contracting with a unit by a relative policy may be subject to action
allowed by law.
   (K)   The polices created by this section are hereby directed to be
implemented by any of the following actions:
      (1)   Posting a copy of Resolution No. 15-2012 in its entirety in at
least one of the locations in the city where it posts employer posters or other
notices to its employees;
      (2)   Providing a copy of Resolution No. 15-2012 to its employees and
elected and appointed officials;
      (3)   Providing or posting a notice of the adoption of Resolution No. 15-
2012; or
      (4)   Any such other action or actions that would communicate the polices
established by this section to its employees and elected and appointed
officials. Upon taking any of these actions these policies are deemed
implemented by the city.
   (L)   A copy of the provisions of IC 36-1-20.2 and IC 36-1-21 effective July
1, 2012 are annexed to Resolution No. 15-2012.
   (M)   Two copies of IC 36-1-20.2 and IC 36-1-21, and as supplemented or
amended, are on file in the Clerk-Treasurer’s office for the city for public
inspection as IC 36-1-5-4 may require.
(Res. 15-2012, passed 6-11-12)
§ 32.09 DRUG FREE WORKPLACE.
   (A)   Overview. The City of Crawfordsville, Indiana makes a commitment to
provide employees a safe working environment, to ensure that employees,
equipment and operating practices comply with health and safety standards, and
to maintain public confidence in the city and its employees. Since the city
values each employee, the city offers employees assistance in dealing with
alcohol and drug abuse problems.
   (B)   Policy.
      (1)   The city requires all employees to report for work in a condition
that allows them to perform their duties in a safe and efficient manner.
Employees will not be permitted to work under the influence of alcohol or with
prohibited drugs in their systems thereby affecting job performance.
      (2)   Violation of any provision of this section will be considered just
cause for disciplinary action up to and including discharge, even for a first
offense. In addition, refusal to adhere to any part of the policy may be
considered an act of insubordination and also may lead to disciplinary action
up to and including discharge.
      (3)   This section and related procedures may be modified by the city at
any time in order to comply with any applicable federal, state or local laws or
to better serve the needs of the city.
   (C)   Prohibited drugs.
      (1)   Prohibited drugs are defined as illegal substances, including
controlled substances as defined in the Controlled Substance Act (21 U.S.C.
8120 and the Code of Federal Regulations (21 C.F.R. 1308.11-1308.15) and
prescription controlled substance which have not been prescribed by a licensed
physician or dentist for specific treatment purposes for the employee. Abuse of
prescription or over-the-counter drugs will also be treated as a substance
abuse problem under this section.
      (2)   This section prohibits the illegal use, sale, transfer,
distribution, possession, or unlawful manufacture of narcotics, drugs, or other
controlled substances while on the job or on city premises (including vehicles
used for city business). These include but are not limited to marijuana,
cocaine, crack, PCP, heroin, LSD, amphetamines, hallucinogens, and
barbiturates. Any illegal substances found on such premises will be turned over
to the state police and may lead to criminal prosecution.
   (D)   Alcohol.
      (1)   The use of alcohol on the job or on city premises is prohibited,
unless such use is non-abusive and is part of an authorized official event held
off city premises. The use of alcohol in vehicles used for city business is
strictly prohibited.
      (2)   Alcohol possession applies to all open or unsealed alcoholic
beverage containers. Such containers are not allowed on the job or on city
premises, unless their possession is part of an authorized, official event.
Possession of such containers in vehicles used for city business is never
authorized.
   (E)   Reporting violations.
      (1)   Employees must as a condition of employment, abide by the terms of
this section and report any conviction to the city under a criminal drug
statute for violations occurring on or off city premises when conducting city
business. Report of a conviction must be made to the city within five business
days after the conviction. The city will then notify the appropriate
contracting officer within ten days after receiving notice from either the
employee or from another source.
      (2)   An employee who is involved with off the job illegal drug activity
may be considered in violation of this section. In determining whether
disciplinary action will be imposed for this activity, the city will consider
the circumstance of each incident, including but not limited to any adverse
effect the employee's actions may have on its customers, other employees, the
public, or the city's reputation and image.
      (3)   Any questions regarding the reporting of violations should be
directed to the Clerk-Treasurer.
   (F)   Employee rehabilitation.
      (1)   Health maintenance is primarily a personal responsibility and it is
the individual's responsibility to correct unsatisfactory job performance or
behavioral problems caused by alcohol or drug abuse. In an effort to assist
employees, the city will provide various means for employees and their family
members to remain aware of the dangers of substance abuse in the workplace and
to overcome drug and alcohol related problems.
      (2)   Employees with a personal, alcohol or drug-related problem are
encouraged to volunteer to participate in a approved rehabilitation program
upon referral from the Employee and Family Assistance Program, before work
performance becomes affected.
      (3)   Participation in a rehabilitation program will not be considered a
barrier to employment nor a cause for disciplinary action. Employees will not
be disciplined merely because of participation in a rehabilitation program or
excused from the disciplinary consequences of conduct which is in violation of
this section or any other city policies or job requirements.
      (4)   Any employee identified through a city investigation as having a
substance abuse problem also may not avoid disciplinary action by requesting to
participate in an approved rehabilitation program.
      (5)   Circumstances in each case will be evaluated to determine the
course of action to be taken (i.e., whether the employee will be offered the
opportunity to participate in a rehabilitation program and/or will be subject
to discipline.)
   (G)   Testing.
      (1)   The city may conduct random alcohol or drug tests at any time with
or without cause or suspicion to assure compliance with its drug-free workplace
policy.
      (2)   Alcohol or drug tests may be required for employees in the
following circumstances:
         (a)   When unsatisfactory job performance or other employee behavior
is reasonably indicative of substance abuse.
         (b)   During and after participation in a drug or alcohol
rehabilitation program for a reasonable period of time as determined by the
city.
         (c)   When required by law.
      (3)   If a supervisor identifies an employee with a behavior pattern and/
or job performance reasonably indicative of substance abuse, the supervisor
(with the concurrence of the next level of supervision) may recommend that the
employee have a fitness for duty examination by a physician designated by the
city. The physician will determine whether a fitness for duty examination is
necessary and whether alcohol or drug tests will be required.
      (4)   Pre-employment drug testing is part of the pre-employment physical.
The method of testing will be determined by the city. Applicants who test
positive for prohibited drugs in their systems will not be offered employment.
Any questions regarding reapplication opportunities should be directed to the
Clerk-Treasurer.
(Ord. 32-2014, passed 12-8-14)
PROVISIONS CONCERNING SPECIFIC CITY OFFICIALS
§ 32.15 MAYOR.
   For provisions concerning the Mayor, see §

§ 32.16 CITY CLERK-TREASURER.
   (A)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall perform the duties of his office as provided
by the laws of the State of Indiana. He shall attend the meetings of the
Council and of the Board of Public Works and Safety and shall serve as
Secretary of the Council and of the Board, and shall keep an official record of
their proceedings. He shall keep and preserve the papers of the city, receive
all monies due and owing the city, and shall make and execute all warrants
disbursing the funds of the city. He shall make an accounting monthly to the
Council of the financial condition of the city.
   (B)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall be the keeper of the official records of the
city.
   (C)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall issue all licenses provided for by this code
and shall collect all license fees therefor, which shall be the property of the
city.
   (D)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall receive such compensation as is provided by
law for his services to the city and in addition thereto shall receive such
compensation as is provided by law for his services to the city’s electric
plant.
   (E)   (1)   The Clerk-Treasurer of the city is hereby directed, during the
first week of each and every year hereafter, to bill any person, organization,
government entity or firm as may owe the city money, for the amount owed to the
city, if unpaid, including but not limited to the following:
         (a)   Communication systems rental.
         (b)   Parking meter rentals.
         (c)   Ambulance and fire protection contracts.
         (d)   Rentals from farm real estate or any other lease contracts.
         (e)   Any and all license fees.
      (2)   All department heads and officers of the city shall assist the
Clerk-Treasurer, upon request, in the preparation of lists of amounts due the
city, and the collection of amounts due the city.
(‘85 Code, § 4.02) (Ord. 44-1983, passed - -83)
Cross-reference:
   Additional duties of Clerk-Treasurer, see §
30.03(D) and
30.04(B)
§ 32.17 CITY ENGINEER.
   (A)   Duties. The City Engineer shall prepare all plans, specifications and
estimates for all public work in the city, and shall establish grades on all
streets and alleys where the same have not been established and he shall
reestablish grades on such streets and alleys as the Council may direct. Such
grades when established shall be reported to the Council and recorded in the
records of the city. The City Engineer shall establish grades and set stakes
for all street and alley improvements in the city, and supervise all
improvements in the city, and shall report to the Council concerning each
public improvement in the city the facts as to whether the improvement has been
done in strict accordance with the plans and specifications thereof. He shall
furnish to the Clerk-Treasurer copies of all proceedings, showing the grades of
streets and alleys now on file in his office, or which may hereafter be ordered
to be made, and the Clerk-Treasurer shall cause the same to be filed and
recorded.
   (B)   Reports and inspections. After the completion of any public work in
the city, the City Engineer shall measure the same in accordance with the
contract for such work and he shall compute the amount due under the contract
on such work and report the same to the Council. In cases where there are any
extras or any compensation claimed by such contractor outside of or beyond the
regular contract price, as per his bid and contract, the City Engineer shall
specifically state in his report the nature of such extras and the price or
amount which he recommends should be allowed therefor. The City Engineer shall
at the time he reports the completion of any street, alley, sidewalk or sewer
improvement file with his report a plat of such work showing on such plat the
total length of such improvement, together with the width and area if it is a
street or sidewalk improvement, and together with a plat of all the lots,
tracts and parcels of land abutting thereon, and together with a plat of all
the lots, tracts and parcels of land, which under the statutes of the State of
Indiana may be assessed for the cost of such improvement, showing the size and
dimensions of each lot, the width of each street and alley and private driveway
intersecting the improved street or alley, together with the names of the
owners of each of these lots, tracts or parcels of land. He shall also inspect
all timber, iron, cement, gravel, stone and other materials used or to be used
in the construction of any public work in the city, and he may reject all such
as may in his opinion be unsafe and unfit for the purpose for which it is
intended to be used and he shall reject any which do not comply with the
specifications for the work. The City Engineer shall be subject to the
directions of the Council.
   (C)   Surveying lots. The City Engineer shall, in surveying for the
ascertainment of lines, corners and dimensions of lots, ascertain precisely the
corner of the square nearest to which the corner of the lot or lots to be
surveyed may lie, and shall measure there from along the streets adjacent
thereto, and give full dimensions to each lot up to the alley running nearest
thereto so that, if there is any deficiency of ground belonging legally to any
lot or lots in such square, such deficiency shall be added to such lot or lots
and taken from the alleys.
   (D)   Recording surveys. The City Engineer shall cause all public surveys,
maps, charts, drafts, plans or other documents made by himself or his assistant
to be recorded in books which shall be provided at the expense of the city, and
which the Engineer shall carefully preserve in his office. The City Engineer
shall designate to any person holding franchises in the city the location of
any telegraph or telephone poles and he shall designate the digging of any
trench for the laying of any main, and his decision in such matters shall be
final. He shall superintend all connections made with the storm sewers or
sanitary sewers of the city. The City Engineer shall also superintend the
numbering of houses and buildings of the city.
   (E)   Map of public improvements. The City Engineer shall prepare and
furnish to the Council a map, showing the exact length and dimensions of any
public improvement constructed in the city, the area of such improvement, by
sections of not more than one-half block, and the dimensions and location of
all street and alley intersections, corners, and private driveways when
improved under contract.
(‘85 Code, § 4.03)
§ 32.18 STREET COMMISSIONER.
   (A)   Powers and duties. The powers and duties of the Street Commissioner
are as follows:
      (1)   He shall remove or cause to be removed all obstructions to free
passage along any of the streets, alleys or sidewalks of the city. He shall, on
view or complaint, give notice to any person who may be obstructing any of the
streets, alleys or sidewalks, or violating any ordinance of the city
prohibiting obstructions in the same, to forthwith remove such obstructions;
and on failure of such person to do so, he shall make immediate complaint to
the Mayor.
      (2)   He shall exercise a careful supervision over all the streets,
alleys and sidewalks, and at each regular meeting of the Council report thereto
in writing such improvements, alterations or repairs as may appear necessary to
be made in the city.
      (3)   He shall see that all laws, ordinances, resolutions and contracts
passed or entered into by the Council regulating or repairing the streets,
alleys, or sidewalks, gutters, culverts, or bridges of the city are strictly
enforced.
      (4)   He shall have supervision over the cleaning of the streets and
sidewalks of the city.
   (B)   Reports. The Street Commissioner shall at each regular meeting of the
Council make a general report of all the work done by his department since the
last regular meeting of the Council. At the first regular meeting of the
Council in January of each year he shall make a full and complete report of all
the work done in his department during the previous year, the amount of money
expended, and the nature and character of the work done.
(‘85 Code, § 4.04)
§ 32.19 CITY HEALTH OFFICER.
   [Reserved]
§ 32.20 CITY SANITARIAN.
   There shall be appointed from time to time, as the Council may see fit, a
City Sanitarian whose duty it is to execute the orders of the Board of Health
and look after the sanitary condition of the city. The Sanitarian has all the
powers of the Board of Health with reference to the entering upon private
property to make examinations for insanitary conditions.
(‘85 Code, § 6.03)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 33.001 INVENTORY RECORDS.
   (A)   Each department of the city government shall maintain records of the
current inventory of the following equipment, supplies, materials, and
furniture in its possession:
      (1)   All capital equipment of an estimated replacement cost in excess of
$500.
      (2)   Furniture utilized in the department office or work areas.
      (3)   Office equipment utilized in the department operations.
      (4)   Any other items as designated by the Mayor or Board of Works.
   (B)   Such inventory records as are herein required shall be updated by each
department annually during the first quarter of each calendar year and shall be
available for inspection by the Mayor, the Board of Public Works and Safety,
and the members of the Common Council or the public no later than May 1 of each
year.
   (C)   Records required by this section shall be filed in the office of the
Clerk-Treasurer and available for public inspection.
(Ord. 18-1988, passed 5-9-88)
§ 33.002 MEETING LOCATION.
   (A)   With the exception of the Board of Aviation Commissioners, each board,
commission or authority established under this chapter must hold its regular
meeting, special meetings or executive sessions in the City Building's Council
Chambers, located at 300 East Pike Street, Crawfordsville, Indiana.
   (B)   Upon not less than a 48-hour advanced notice, subject to the mayor's
approval at his or her discretion, the location of any regular meeting, special
meeting or executive session maybe changed by the board, commission or
authority to another place in a public building located in the city.
(Ord. 4-2013, passed 2-11-13)
BOARD OF AVIATION COMMISSIONERS
§ 33.015 CREATION.
   There is hereby created a Board of Aviation Commissioners which shall be
appointed and have duties and functions as prescribed by IC 8-22-2-1. Pursuant
to IC 8-22-2-1(g), the Board of Aviation Commissioners shall consist of five
members. The City Engineer shall be an ex-officio non-voting member of the
Board of Aviation Commissioners and shall act as Secretary thereof. He shall
receive no additional compensation for these services.
(‘85 Code, § 4.11) (Am. Res. 12-207, passed 6-11-07)
BOARD OF HEALTH
§ 33.025 APPOINTMENT; POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Board of Health shall be appointed in the manner set forth in IC 16-20-
1-1 et seq. and amendments thereto, and shall possess the powers and perform
the duties prescribed therein as well as any additional powers and duties set
forth in this code.
(‘85 Code, § 6.01)
COMMISSION ON THE STATUS OF WOMEN
§ 33.045 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of the Commission on the Status of Women is to see that women
who reside or work within the city have full opportunity to serve in every
capacity as equal participants in the economy, in the system of justice, and in
all other aspects of community life. To this purpose, the Commission shall
gather and distribute information, make recommendations for legislative action,
and act as a referral center for cases of alleged discrimination practices.
(‘85 Code, § 13.01(a)) (Ord. 45-1976, passed - -76)
§ 33.046 CREATION AND MEMBERSHIP.
   (A)   The Commission on the Status of Women shall consist of seven members.
The members shall be appointed by the Mayor initially within 60 days from the
effective date of this subchapter. All appointees must be approved by a
majority of the Common Council. Of the seven members first appointed, three
shall be appointed to serve until January 1, 1978; two until January 1, 1979;
and two until January 1, 1980. Thereafter each appointment to the Commission
shall be for a term of three years. No more than four appointments shall be
from the same political party. In the event of the death or resignation of any
member, the successor shall be appointed by the Mayor within 30 days from the
date of such vacancy, to serve the unexpired term for which such resigning
member had been appointed.
   (B)   It is recommended that at least four of the members of the Commission
be women.
   (C)   The Mayor shall call the first meeting of the Commission, at which
time a Chairperson shall be selected by and from the members.
(‘85 Code, § 13.01(b)) (Ord. 45-1976, passed - -76)
§ 33.047 ANNUAL REPORT.
   The Commission on the Status of Women shall submit a written report of its
activities and recommendations to the Common Council on or before December 31
of each year.
(‘85 Code, § 13.01(c)) (Ord. 45-1976, passed - -76)
DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION
§ 33.060 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established for the city a single Department of Parks and
Recreation as provided in the Park and Recreation Law, IC 36-10-3-1 et seq.
(‘85 Code, § 4.07(a))
§ 33.061 MEMBERS.
   In addition to the four members of the Board of Parks and Recreation there
shall be two ex-officio members, one from the Board of School Trustees and one
from the Library Board.
(‘85 Code, § 4.07(b))
§ 33.062 ADVISORY COUNCIL.
   The Board of Parks and Recreation is directed to appoint an Advisory Council
and Special Committees in compliance with IC 36-10-3-17. Such Advisory Council
shall, among other representation, contain representation of the city’s
historical and literary interests. There shall also be established a special
“Lew Wallace Study” committee which will consist initially of the present
membership of the Lew Wallace Study Board. Such special committee shall advise
the Board of Parks and Recreation concerning the control and management of the
Lew Wallace Study.
(‘85 Code, § 4.07(c))
§ 33.063 TRANSFER OF DUTIES AND POWERS OF MUNICIPAL GOLF COURSE INTO DEPARTMENT
OF PARKS AND RECREATION.
   Besides the powers and duties that the Department of Parks and Recreation
have under Indiana Statute, the powers and duties previously vested in the
Municipal Golf Course Authority pertaining to the Municipal Golf Course are
transferred to the Department of Parks and Recreation. Control of all non-
reverting funds dedicated to the operation of the golf course or accounts
pertaining solely to the golf course are transferred from the Municipal Golf
Course Authority to the Parks and Recreation Board. Any leases, contracts, and
other obligations concerning the Municipal Golf Course heretofore entered into
by the Municipal Golf Course Authority are transferred and assigned to the
Parks and Recreation Board, subject to any necessary approvals required within
those leases and contracts.
(Ord. 2-2016, passed 2-22-16)
PLAN COMMISSION
§ 33.075 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The City Plan Commission shall have the rights, powers, and privileges as
provided by IC 36-7-4-201 et seq., and all acts amendatory thereto.
(‘85 Code, § 4.06(a))
§ 33.076 MEMBERS.
   The City Plan Commission shall be composed of nine members, five of whom
shall be citizens of the city, qualified by knowledge or experience to act in
matters pertaining to the development of a city plan and who do not hold any
other office in the city government and who shall be appointed by the Mayor,
one of whom shall be appointed for two years, two of whom shall be appointed
for three years, and two of whom shall be appointed for four years, from and
after January 1 of the year of their appointment; and at the expiration of the
original appointments shall be appointed for terms of four years. The other
four members of the Commission shall be composed of one member of the Council
selected by it, one member of the Board of Park Commissioners selected by it,
the President of the Board of Public Works, and the City Engineer.
(‘85 Code, § 4.06(b))
UTILITY SERVICE BOARD
§ 33.090 CITY ELECTRIC UTILITY TO BE OPERATED BY BOARD.
   The Crawfordsville Electric Light & Power Utility shall be operated by a
Utility Service Board, pursuant to statute, now governed by IC 8-1.5-3-1 et
seq., as now existing or as hereafter amended.
(‘85 Code, § 4.12) (Ord. 23-1960, passed - -60)
§ 33.091 MEMBERS.
   (A)   The Utility Service Board shall consist of five members, all of whom
shall be residents of the city.
   (B)   All members hereafter appointed to fill expired terms of members of
the Utility Service Board shall be for a four-year term. The appointment shall
be made by the authority that appointed the member whose term has expired.
   (C)   Any vacancy in the membership of the Utility Service Board shall be
filled by appointment for the unexpired term of the vacating member. Upon
expiration of term, death of member, resignation of member or vacancy for any
reason, such vacancy shall be filled by appointment by the authority which
appointed the vacating member of the Utility Service Board.
   (D)   The Common Council, with approval of the Mayor, shall have the power
to expel any member of the Board for violation of official duty, or may expel a
member for reasons of disability.
   (E)   The Common Council shall have the power to hold hearings to determine
if such cause exists for the termination of a member’s appointment to the
Utility Service Board.
   (F)   The President of the Utility Service Board shall receive a salary of
$260.00 per month for the year 1998; all other members of the Utility Service
Board shall receive a salary of $208.00 per month for the year 1998; thereafter
the President and members may receive annual salary increases equal in
percentage to the increases awarded by the Common Council to the elected
officials of the city.
   (G)   One liaison member of the Council shall be appointed by the Mayor to
serve as an ex-officio member of the Board without power to vote and without
additional remuneration.
(‘85 Code, § 4.12(a)-(f)) (Ord. 23-1960, passed - -60; Am. Ord. 48-1976, passed
- -76; Am. Ord. 7-1994, passed 4-11-94; Am. Ord. 9-1994, passed 5-9-94; Am.
Ord. 25-1996, passed 12-9-96; Am. Ord. 21-1997, passed 11-10-97)
§ 33.092 CONFLICTING REGULATIONS.
   In any event in which this subchapter or any other sections of the city’s
code shall conflict with the Indiana Code in reference to the powers, duties,
rights or obligations of the Utility Service Board, the Indiana Code shall be
deemed to prevail as the governing law.
(‘85 Code, § 4.12(g))
§ 33.093 COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS.
   The Utility Service Board or its designee shall be, and hereby is,
authorized, empowered and directed, on behalf of the city, to take any actions
as such officer deems necessary or desirable to maintain and control portions
of the communication system CEL&P continues to own and operate as approved
under the city’s and the Board’s agreements with Metronet for the city’s or
CEL&P’s exclusive benefit.
(Ord. 7-2015, passed 4-13-15)
DEPARTMENT OF REDEVELOPMENT
§ 33.100 CREATED.
   There is hereby created the City Department of Redevelopment, which shall be
entitled to exercise all the rights, powers, privileges and immunities accorded
to such departments as amended under IC 36-7-14 (“the Act”).
(Ord. 24-1994, passed 10-10-94)
§ 33.101 MEMBERS; APPOINTMENTS.
   (A)   The City Department of Redevelopment shall be under the control of a
Board of five members to be known as the City Redevelopment Commission.
   (B)   There is hereby created a Board to be known as the City Redevelopment
Commission. Three of the commissioners shall be appointed by the Mayor, and two
shall be appointed by the Common Council. The nominations made by the Common
Council shall be transmitted to the Mayor in writing within ten days after the
final passage of this chapter. Each Redevelopment Commissioner shall serve for
one year from the first day of January after his appointment and until his or
her successor is appointed and has qualified, except that the original
commissioners shall serve from the date of their appointment until the first
day of January in the second year after their appointment. If a vacancy occurs,
a successor shall be appointed in the same manner as the original commissioner
and the successor shall serve for the remainder of the vacated term.
(Ord. 24-1994, passed 10-10-94)
§ 33.102 OATH OF OFFICE.
   Each Redevelopment Commissioner, before beginning his or her duties, shall
take and subscribe an oath of office in the form presented by law, to be
endorsed on the certificate of his or her appointment, which shall be promptly
filed with the City Clerk-Treasurer.
(Ord. 24-1994, passed 10-10-94)
§ 33.103 BOND.
   Each Redevelopment Commissioner, before beginning his or her duties, shall
execute a bond payable to the state, with surety to be approved by the Mayor.
The bond must be in a penal sum of $15,000 and must be conditioned on the
faithful performance of the duties of his or her office and the accounting for
all monies and property that may come into his or her hands or under his or her
control. The cost of the bond shall be paid by the special taxing district.
(Ord. 24-1994, passed 10-10-94)
§ 33.104 QUALIFICATIONS.
   Such commissioners shall have the qualifications prescribed by the laws of
the state as from time to time amended and shall qualify as therein provided;
and shall exercise and enjoy the rights and powers and assume the duties and
obligations conferred and imposed by said Act, including but not limited to the
following qualifications:
   (A)    A Redevelopment Commissioner must be at least 18 years of age and
must be a resident of the city. If a commissioner ceases to be qualified under
this section, he or she forfeits his or her office.
   (B)   No City Redevelopment Commissioner shall receive a salary; but such
Redevelopment Commissioners are entitled to reimbursement for expense
necessarily incurred in the performance of their duties.
   (C)   A Redevelopment Commissioner may not have a pecuniary interest in any
contract, employment, purchase or sale made under the provisions of this
chapter and the underlying statutes. However, any property required for
redevelopment purposes in which a Commissioner has a pecuniary interest may be
acquired, but only by gift or condemnation. A transaction made in violation of
this section is void.
(Ord. 24-1994, passed 10-10-94)
§ 33.105 CLERK-TREASURER.
   The Clerk-Treasurer or the city charged by law for the performance of duties
in respect to the funds and accounts of the city, shall perform the same duties
with respect to the funds and accounts of the Department of Redevelopment,
except as otherwise provided for in the Act.
(Ord. 24-1994, passed 10-10-94)
§ 33.106 RATIFICATION OF BONDS REQUIRED.
   The Common Council must ratify the issuance of any bonds proposed by the
Commission.
(Ord. 24-1994, passed 10-10-94)
PURCHASING AGENCY
§ 33.110 ESTABLISHMENT.
   Pursuant to the provisions of IC 5-22 et seq., the Board of Public Works and
Safety of the city is the purchasing agency for the city government. Each
department head is designated as an additional purchasing agent for the
department and the Board of Public Works and Safety may designate in writing
additional deputy purchasing agents as are necessary.
§ 33.111 PURCHASING PROCEDURES.
   (A)    The requirements set forth herein shall apply to all purchases of
equipment materials, goods and supplies (or any other expenditure governed by
IC 5-22) by any city department, utility or sanitary sewer department. The
purchasing agency and all purchasing agents may purchase services in whatever
manner the purchaser determines to be reasonable to the extent provided by law.
   (B)   All purchases over $150,000 shall be by invitation to bid under the
provisions of IC 5-22 and shall be approved by the purchasing agency.
   (C)   All purchases between $50,000 and $150,000 shall be made by requesting
at least three written quotes under the provisions of IC 5-22-8 and requires
purchasing agency approval.
   (D)   All purchases of at least $5,000 but less than $50,000 shall also be
made by requesting at least three quotes and must be approved by the purchasing
agency. Strict compliance with IC 5-22-8 is not required; quotes are not
required to be in writing and the purchasing agency is not required to give
parties seven days to submit quotes; the purchasing agent must document and
maintain all solicitations and quotes.
   (E)   Purchasing agents may make all purchases less than $5,000 on the open
market without inviting or receiving quotes or bids.
   (F)   Under the circumstances allowable by IC 5-22-10 (i.e. existence of
emergency conditions, unique opportunity to obtain supplies at a substantial
savings) purchases may be made without soliciting bids or quotes, provided that
the purchase is made with such competition as is practical under the
circumstances and the purchasing agency documents the applicable special
circumstances as required by IC 5-22-10.
   (G)   If a purchasing agency makes a written determination that the use of
the competitive bidding or quote procedures is either not practicable or not
advantageous to the city, the purchasing agency may make the purchase by
utilizing the Request for Proposal procedures set forth in IC 5-22-9.
   (H)   All purchases shall further be made in accordance with the preferences
set forth in IC 5-22-11 (Dept. of Corrections), IC 5-22-12 (Rehabilitation
Center), IC 5-22-13 (Qualified Nonprofit Agencies for Persons with Severe
Disabilities), IC 5-22-15 (Supplies Manufactured in the U.S., Coal Mined in
Indiana, Recycled or Post-Consumer Materials, etc.), and any other preferences
established under Indiana law.
   (I)    No purchase shall be made by any purchasing agency or agent except
upon sufficient appropriation made by the fiscal body.
(Am. Ord. 7-2013, passed 3-11-13)
§ 33.112 SUPPLIES SPECIFIED FOR PURCHASE.
   The purchasing agents shall purchase supplies manufactured in the United
States unless any of the following applies:
   (A)   The supplies are not manufactured in the United States in reasonably
available quantities.
   (B)   The price of the supplies manufactured in the United States exceeds by
an unreasonable amount the price of available and comparable supplies
manufactured outside the United States.
   (C)   The quality of the supplies is substantially less than the quality of
comparably priced available supplies manufactured outside the United States.
   (D)   The purchase of supplies manufactured in the United States is not in
the public interest.
(Ord. 14-1998, passed 7-20-98)
DOWNTOWN REVITALIZATION ADVISORY COMMISSION
§ 33.120 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established a Downtown Revitalization Advisory Commission
for the purpose of studying, investigating and recommending to the
administration of the city programs or projects for the redevelopment and
improvement of the Central Business District and surrounding areas.
(Res. 5-2000, passed 4-10-00)
§ 33.121 MEMBERS.
   The Commission shall consist of no more than 15 members appointed by and
serving at the pleasure of the Mayor of the city. After appointment the members
shall serve until their successors are duly appointed. The Commission shall
have representation from the following categories: large business, small
business, industry, professional, residential and city government.
(Res. 5-2000, passed 4-10-00)
DEPARTMENT OF STORMWATER MANAGEMENT
§ 33.140 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby created in and for the city a Department of Stormwater
Management with the powers and duties set forth in I.C. 8-1.5-5 and any other
statute or regulation applicable to Indiana stormwater municipal utilities.
(Ord. 31-2004, passed 9-13-04; Am. Ord. 22-2013, passed 7-8-13)
§ 33.141 POWERS AND DUTIES
   (A)   All existing property, accounts, and facilities of the Wastewater
Department of the city which are dedicated solely for the collection and
disposal of stormwater shall be and hereby are transferred to the Department of
Stormwater Management.
   (B)   The Department of Stormwater Management ("the Department") shall be
controlled by the Board of Public Works and Safety. The Board of Public Works
and Safety has exclusive jurisdiction over the collection and disposal of
stormwater within the District.
(Ord. 31-2004, passed 9-13-04; Am. Ord. 22-2013, passed 7-8-13)
§ 33.142 STORMWATER SPECIAL TAXING DISTRICT.
   There is also created a Stormwater Special Taxing District (“the District”),
consisting of all territory within the corporate boundaries of the city, and to
include such additional area as may lawfully be annexed to the city from time
to time. The District exists to provide for the collection and disposal of
stormwater in and from the District in a manner that protects the public health
and welfare and to levy special benefit taxes and/or user fees for purposes of
stormwater collection and disposal. The District shall be funded through one or
more means available to stormwater utilities set forth in I.C. 8-1.5-5.
(Ord. 31-2004, passed 9-13-04)
DEPARTMENT OF PLANNING AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT
§ 33.150 ESTABLISHMENT.
   (A)   A Department of Planning and Community Development is hereby created
and so named, and this department shall henceforth have responsibility for
zoning, planning, economic and community development, and such other functions
as may be given to it from time to time by the Mayor of the city.
   (B)   All references to the Planning Department or variations thereof in the
Code of Ordinances shall be amended to substitute the Department of Planning
and Community Development, where applicable in each provision.
(Ord. 20-2004, passed 8-9-04)
SUGAR CREEK NATURE PARK ADVISORY COMMITTEE
§ 33.170 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby created the Sugar Creek Nature Park Advisory Committee which
exists to advise the Board of Directors of the Storm Water Department and other
city officials concerning any and all matters pertaining to the Sugar Creek
Nature Park.
(Res. 25-2010, passed 9-20-10)
§ 33.171 MEETINGS.
   The Committee shall meet at such times and places as its members may from
time to time decide.
(Res. 25-2010, passed 9-20-10)
§ 33.172 PUBLIC ACCESS.
   As a governmental body, the Committee is subject to the Indiana public
access laws (Open Door Law and Access to Public Records Law) and shall comply
therewith.
(Res. 25-2010, passed 9-20-10)
§ 33.173 MEMBERSHIP.
   The Committee shall consist of no more than seven members, all appointed by
the Mayor without regard to political party and serving at the pleasure of the
Mayor. At least one member shall be a teacher or other employee of the
Crawfordsville Community School Corporation. At least one member shall be
appointed with the advice and consent of the Friends of Sugar Creek. By virtue
of their positions, the Mayor and Superintendents of the Storm Water Department
and of the Park Department shall be members of the Committee, with voting
privileges.
(Res. 25-2010, passed 9-20-10)
§ 33.174 COMPENSATION.
   Members of the Committee shall receive no compensation for their service on
the Committee, but reasonable expenses of the Committee and its various members
may be paid or reimbursed by the Board of Directors of the Storm Water
Department upon approval by that Board pursuant to law.
(Res. 25-2010, passed 9-20-10)
REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY
§ 33.180 ESTABLISHMENT.
   (A)   The Common Council of the City of Crawfordsville, Indiana (the
Council) now deems it to be in the best interest of Crawfordsville, Indiana
(the city) and its citizens to afford a maximum opportunity for rehabilitation,
redevelopment, or economic development of areas within the city by establishing
a redevelopment authority.
   (B)   The Council hereby establishes the Crawfordsville Redevelopment
Authority.
(Ord. 32-2011, passed 12-12-11)
BICYCLE AND PEDESTRIAN CITIZEN ADVISORY COMMITTEE
§ 33.190 BICYCLE AND PEDESTRIAN CITIZEN ADVISORY COMMITTEE.
   (A)   The Crawfordsville Bicycle and Pedestrian and Citizen Advisory
Committee is hereby created.
   (B)   The purpose of the Crawfordsville Bicycle and Pedestrian Citizen
Advisory Committee is to promote and encourage bicycling, walking and running
in a safe and efficient manner in the City of Crawfordsville for the purpose of
health, recreation and transportation.
(Ord. 31-2018, passed 12-10-18)
§ 33.191 APPOINTMENTS, TERMS, VACANCIES.
   (A)   The Committee shall consist of eleven members, appointed by the Mayor:
      (1)   One designee of the Director of the Department of Planning and
Community Development serving as the City's Bicycle and Pedestrian Coordinator
and Crawfordville Bicycle and pedestrian Citizen Advisory Committee's staff
support;
      (2)   One member of the Crawfordsville Common Council;
      (3)   One citizen interested/engaged in recreational-cycling;
      (4)   One citizen interested/engaged in recreational running;
      (5)   One citizen interested/engaged in recreational walking;
      (6)   Two members of the Mayor's Youth Council; and
      (7)   Four additional appointments of Crawfordsville or Montgomery County
residents who are interested in serving as a member of the Committee.
   (B)   The initial terms of the members will be staggered. All subsequent
terms will be for two years.
   (C)   Any vacancies will be filled by an appointee of the Mayor for the
balance of the term.
(Ord. 31-2018, passed 12-10-18)
§ 33.192 MEETINGS.
   The Committee will meet at times and places as agreed on by the Committee.
The Committee must advertise all meeting times and places under Indiana law. In
any event, the Committee must meet no less than six times per calendar year on
a bi-monthly basis. The Committee will organize and begin meeting January 2019.
(Ord. 31-2018, passed 12-10-18)
§ 33.193 DUTIES.
   The duties of this Committee will be:
   (A)   To serve as a citizen's forum for discussion and recommendation of
improvements to existing facilities and planning of new projects concerning
safe access for cyclists, pedestrians and runners;
   (B)   To prepare reports and recommendations to the Mayor, Common Council
and Board of Public Works and Safety as needed, concerning the needs of
cyclists, pedestrians and runners within the city;
   (C)   To foster and promote safety programs, events, and education for all
forms of transportation and users; and
   (D)   To encourage implementation of recommendations in the Crawfordsville
Parks Master Plan (adopted by Park Board Resolution 2-2014) and the
Crawfordsville Bike and Pedestrian Master Plan (adopted by Council Resolution
21-2014).
(Ord. 31-2018, passed 12-10-18)

POLICE DEPARTMENT
§ 34.01 BOARD OF METROPOLITAN POLICE COMMISSIONERS.
   (A)   There is hereby established within and for the city a Board of
Metropolitan Police Commissioners to consist of three members to be appointed
by the Mayor. The Commissioners to be so appointed shall be of good moral
character who are citizens of the State of Indiana and residents of the city.
The appointments shall be for such term as the Mayor shall deem appropriate and
shall in no event be appointed for a term beyond the term that the appointing
Mayor has in office. Each of the Commissioners shall be subject to removal by
the Mayor for cause which the Mayor may deem sufficient. Such cause shall be in
writing and filed with the City Council at the time of such dismissal. Each of
the Commissioners, before entering upon their duties, shall take and subscribe
to an oath of office with the Clerk-Treasurer and shall also take and subscribe
before the Clerk, the further oath or affirmation that in any and every
appointment or removal to be made by them, to or from the Police Force of the
city, they shall in no case and under no pretext, appoint or remove any police
officer, officer, police or other person because of any political feeling held
by such police officer, officer or other person, or for any cause or reason
other than that of fitness or unfitness of such person, in the best judgment of
the Commissioners and as prescribed by Indiana law. Such oath or affirmation
shall be recorded in the records of the Clerk-Treasurer’s office of the city,
and the Police Commissioner shall also give bond, payable to the State of
Indiana, conditioned for the faithful and honest discharge of their duties,
which bond shall be approved by the Common Council. The salary of the Board of
Metropolitan Police Commissioners shall be fixed by the Common Council, such
salary to be budgeted by the Metropolitan Police Board and as approved by the
Common Council, all on dates and times as prescribed by Indiana law.
   (B)   The Commissioners shall appoint one of their members to act as
President, who shall conduct the meetings of the Board. Other officers may be
appointed by the Metropolitan Police Commissioners, as vice-commissioners, as
deemed appropriate. The Board shall appoint a Secretary and Property Clerk, who
shall give bond to the Commissioners in an amount in which such surety may be
approved by them, conditioned for the safekeeping by said Secretary of the
records of the Board, and also of any property under the Secretary’s control.
   (C)   The Mayor shall appoint the Chief of Police for the city and for the
Police Force of the city. The Board shall otherwise establish a budget and
operate the Police Department, including the hiring or dismissal of other
department personnel in any disciplinary action as may be required as provided
by law, all of which shall be subject to the appropriation of funds by the
Common Council.
   (D)   All laws of the state applicable to the Police Force and Board of
Metropolitan Police Commissioners, and all ordinances of the city not in
conflict herewith as are applicable to the Police Force and to the Metropolitan
Police Board shall continue in full force and effect as they apply.
(‘85 Code, § 4.10) (Ord. 23-1982, passed - -82)
§ 34.02 POLICE PENSION BOARD.
   There is hereby established a Board of Trustees of the Police Fund which
shall be governed by the provisions of IC 36-8-6-1(a), 36-8-6-2, 36-8-6-3, 36-
8-6-4, and 36-8-6-5. The Board shall perform certain duties prescribed by IC
36-8-6 and 36-8-8 concerning the statutory pensions of city police. The Board
shall be governed by the appropriate state laws and appropriate ordinances of
the city not in conflict herewith.
(‘85 Code, §§ 4.14, 13.03(a))
§ 34.03 POLICE DEPARTMENT COPY AND ACCIDENT REPORT FEES.
   (A)   The following fees are authorized to be charged by the Police
Department for copy fee, unless Indiana law prohibits otherwise:
ITEM FEE
ITEM                                   FEE
Photographs                            $0.31 per photograph
Audio recording                        $5 per audio recording
Incident report                        $0.10 per page
Accident report and duplicates         $10 per report
Reports over 50 pages                  $0.04 per page
Fingerprints                           $5 per card
Vehicle identification check           $5
Criminal history check                 $7
Notary service                         $2
Other copying or document reproduction $0.10
Law enforcement recordings             $150 per copy
 
   (B)   These fees shall be deposited as follows:
      (1)   Police Copy Fee Fund (Fund 208). The Police Copy Fee Fund is
established, which is a non-reverting fund. All fees charged for photographs,
audio tape, incident reports, reports over 50 pages, fingerprints, criminal
history check, notary services and other copying not related to law enforcement
recordings must be deposited into the Police Copy Fee Fund. These funds must be
used to pay for supplies, charges, services and equipment used to provide these
services.
      (2)   Local Law Enforcement Continuing Education Fund (Fund 270). All
fees charged for accident reports and vehicle identification checks, received
from administering local law enforcement continuing education programs, and
funds derived from traffic ordinance deferral agreements must be deposited into
the Local Law Enforcement Continuing Education Fund. These funds shall be used
for education and training of law enforcement officers as provided by Indiana
law. This is a non-reverting fund.
      (3)   Fund 211 Law Enforcement Recording Copy Fee Fund. All fees for
copies of law enforcement recordings will be deposited into the Law Enforcement
Recording Fee Fund. These funds will be used to pay the costs of the
recordings, the labor necessary to administer the management, storage and
retrieval of such recordings, the equipment necessary to comply, with the legal
requirements of the law, and other costs associated with providing these
copies. These funds may be used without appropriation. This is a non-reverting
fund.
(Ord. 39-1990, passed 9-10-90; Am. Ord. 12-2013, passed 5-13-13; Am. Ord. 3-
2015, passed 3-9-15; Am. Ord. 22-2016, passed 10-17-16)
§ 34.04 POLICE RESERVES.
   The city shall have a police reserve consisting of members to assist the
Police Department in their regular duties, and such police reserve is hereby
established as follows:
   (A)   The police reserve unit shall consist of a maximum of 27 members, such
members to be either citizens of the city or live in Montgomery County, in an
area not more than 15 miles distance from the city.
   (B)   Police reserves shall be persons of good moral character and shall
live in the areas described in division (A) above and shall be appointed by the
Chief of Police of the city subject to the approval of the Metropolitan Board
of Police Commissioners. Upon appointment, each member shall qualify by taking
oath stating that he will faithfully carry out the duties of a reserve officer
of the city and shall thereafter become an active member of that police
reserve.
   (C)   Police reserves shall not be members of the regular Police Department,
but upon entering any specific duty as a reserve to the Police Department, each
member shall have the same police powers as the regular department, subject,
however, to the laws of the state, and any rule the Police Department may adopt
to limit the authority of police reserve.
   (D)   Police reserves, upon entering any duty for the city in their capacity
as a police reserve, shall sign a register kept and maintained by the Chief of
Police, and upon signing such register indicating that such police reserves
enter on active duty in assistance of the Police Department, then such police
reserve shall have the power as herein designated.
   (E)   The police reserve shall receive such benefits and compensation from
their office, as members of such police reserve, as may be prescribed by the
laws of the state and by ordinances of the city and also by the rules and
regulations for the police reserve of the city.
   (F)   The police reserve shall be entitled to such other benefits as the
city may provide specifically for such purpose and shall be entitled to such
training as the rules of the Police Department may allow.
(‘85 Code, § 4.24) (Ord. 14-1983, passed - -83)
§ 34.05 FIREARMS TRAINING FUND.
   (A)   Handgun permit fees. The following fees are authorized for handgun
permits:
 
ITEM                        FEE
Four-year license           $10
Lifetime license            $50
Lifetime with valid license $40
   (B)   Firearms Training Fund (Fund 209). The Firearms Training Fund is
established, which is a non-reverting fund. All fees charged for handgun
registration must be deposited into the Firearms Training Fund. These funds
must be used for the purpose of firearms, ammunition, training supplies and
body armor.
(Ord. 12-2013, passed 5-13-13)
FIRE DEPARTMENT
§ 34.20 FIRE DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby established a Fire Department in the city which shall be
under the control of the Board of Public Works and Safety. The Fire Department
shall be composed of a Chief, an Assistant Chief and firefighters hired with
the approval of the Board of Public Works and Safety. The Fire Department shall
respond to any emergency situation requiring the training, equipment, knowledge
or manpower of that Department.
(Ord. 51-1990, passed 11-13-90)
§ 34.21 FIRE CHIEF; ASSISTANT CHIEF.
   (A)   The Chief of the Fire Department is in charge of all fire fighting
apparatus belonging to the city, and is responsible for the safekeeping and
care of the same. He shall have command and control of the entire department
when in active service at fires and the general supervision of the members of
the department at all times, he shall be responsible for their conduct under
the rules of the Board of Public Works and Safety. He shall see that all
provisions of this code for the prevention of fires and the protection of
property against fires are enforced. He shall see that all property and
apparatus for extinguishing fires are kept in good order.
   (B)   In the absence of the Chief of the Fire Department, the Assistant
Chief shall have full charge of the Department to perform all duties of the
Chief. In the absence of the Chief and the Assistant Chief, the next senior
officer of the Department shall perform the duties of the Chief.
(Ord. 51-1990, passed 11-13-90)
§ 34.22 POLICE POWERS OF FIRE DEPARTMENT.
   Whenever deemed necessary during the continuance of any fire or other
emergency response by the Fire Department, the Chief of the Department or his
Assistant may appoint suitable persons to guard and protect any property in or
removed from any building or enclosure and such persons so appointed shall have
all the powers of a police officer to arrest and commit any person plundering
or attempting to plunder, or unlawfully carrying away any property. The Chief
of the Fire Department and each member thereof, shall have all the powers of
police officers when having responded to the scene of any fire, hazardous
material accident or incident or other emergency condition threatening to life,
property or the environment within the city and it’s jurisdictional area.
(Ord. 51-1990, passed 11-13-90)
§ 34.23 REPORTS.
   The Chief of the Fire Department shall report to the Board of Public Works
and Safety any severe violation by any member of the Fire or Ambulance
departments of any rule or regulation adopted by the Board for the government
of either department. Such reports shall be in writing signed by the Chief. The
Board shall hear the evidence of such charges and, if such charges are found to
be true, the offending member may be subject to disciplinary action or
discharge.
(Ord. 51-1990, passed 11-13-90)
§ 34.24 FIRE PREVENTION DIVISION.
   There is hereby established within the Fire Department a Fire Prevention
Division under the direction of the Fire Chief, Chief Inspector and other fire
inspectors. The function of this division shall be to perform fire prevention
inspections and other duties related to the insurance of life and fire safety,
as provided for in IC 36-8-17. The Chief may assign personnel to the division
to assist the inspector in the administration of the city’s Fire Code and other
applicable state and local codes.
(Ord. 51-1990, passed 11-13-90)
§ 34.25 ARSON INVESTIGATION DIVISION.
   There is hereby established within the Fire Department an Arson
Investigation Division under the direction of the Fire Chief. The function of
this division shall be to investigate any and all fires of suspicious nature
with the intent of determining cause and origin, as provided for in IC 36-8-17-
7. The division shall be comprised of those qualified personnel assigned by the
Fire Chief from within the Department. The Chief may assign, or request the
assistance of, other local and state offices in the course of any
investigation.
(Ord. 51-1990, passed 11-13-90)
§ 34.26 TRAINING DIVISION.
   There is hereby established within the Fire Department a Training Division
under the direction of the Fire Chief. The Chief shall appoint a Training
Instructor who shall be, or will become in a time specified by the Chief, a
First Class Instructor as certified by the State of Indiana. It shall be the
responsibility of the Training Instructor to develop course outlines, tests,
prepare lesson plans and maintain training records on all fire and ambulance
personnel, as prescribed in NFPA 1041, Fire Service Instructor Professional
Qualifications and NFPA 1401, Fire Service Training Reports and Records.
(Ord. 51-1990, passed 11-13-90)
§ 34.27 AMBULANCE DIVISION.
   There is hereby established within the city an Ambulance Division under the
direction of the Fire Chief. This division shall be considered a “Department”
separate from the Fire Department in respect to pension, benefits and wages.
This department shall be a branch of the Fire Department with its members
performing all applicable emergency medical duties as required by the State
Emergency Medical Commission and local policies. They shall have no involvement
with interior fire suppression activities but may be used in the capacity of
support. All ambulance “department” personnel shall be on the city’s P.E.R.F.
program and not the Firefighters Pension Fund unless otherwise directed by the
Board of Public Works and Safety.
(Ord. 51-1990, passed 11-13-90)
§ 34.28 PERSONNEL STANDARDS; LAWFUL ORDERS.
   (A)   All members of the Fire Department and Ambulance Department shall
adhere to the standards and rules set forth in the most currently adopted copy
of the Fire Department Rules and Regulations handbook.
   (B)   All members of the Fire Department and Ambulance Department shall,
while in an on duty status or in being present at any emergency, be subject to
obey any and all lawful orders given by the Fire Chief, his assistant or
officer in charge at the scene of the emergency.
(Ord. 51-1990, passed 11-13-90)
§ 34.29 FIREFIGHTERS PENSION FUND; FIRE PENSION BOARD.
   (A)   There is hereby established a Board of Trustees and Firefighters
Pension Fund with the powers and duties as provided for in IC 36-8-7-1. (Ord.
51-1990, passed 11-13-90)
   (B)   There is hereby established a Firefighters Pension Board of Trustees
to perform certain duties prescribed by IC 36-8-7 and 36-8-8 concerning the
statutory pensions of city firefighters. The Board shall be governed by the
appropriate state laws and appropriate ordinances of the city not in conflict
herewith. (‘85 Code, § 13.03(b))
§ 34.30 FIRE DEPARTMENT AMBULANCE AND RESCUE SERVICE.
   (A)   For the purpose of this section, MEMBERS OF IMMEDIATE FAMILIES shall
mean the wife or husband and children of the employee or retiree who lives in
the same household and is a dependent as defined by the Internal Revenue Code.
   (B)   The Fire Department Ambulance and Rescue Service of the city may
furnish free basic Emergency Medical Care (ambulance) to employees and former
employees of the city and others, as herein provided.
   (C)   This service shall be for members, widows and dependents of the Police
Officers and Firefighters Pension Fund, all full-time employees of all city
departments, including Crawfordsville Electric Light and Power. All city
employees and retirees, as defined by the Public Employees Retirement Funds are
also eligible for such service, including their immediate families if such
employees were employed by the city full time for ten years, or a member, widow
or dependent of a member of the Police Officer or Firefighter Pension Funds or
of current full-time employees.
   (D)   All elected city officials shall also be eligible for such service,
but only during their term of office. This section shall include elected
officials of any township government with which the city has a contract to
provide emergency medical and rescue service in force at the time service is
required.
   (E)   Any firefighter, emergency medical responder or law enforcement
officer (police) who is injured in the line of duty whether they are a city
employee or not may be eligible for such service.
(Ord. 7-1991, passed - -91)
§ 34.31 STAND-BY CHARGES.
   (A)   If a private person or entity requests the presence of an ambulance,
fire truck, public safety personnel and/or special equipment of the city at an
event, then that person or entity shall be responsible for the following
charges for the same:
      (1)   $35 per person per hour or fraction thereof; and
      (2)   $50 per motor vehicle mobilization charge.
   (B)   These charges shall be billed by the Fire Department or the Clerk-
Treasurer to the person or entity requesting said service, and if unpaid shall
be collectible by the city as any other debt owed.
   (C)   Monies received from charges for personnel shall be deposited into
Fire Department Account #115, Salaries-Overtime, and monies received from
charges for vehicle mobilization shall be deposited into Fire Department
Account #220, Fuel and Oil.
(Ord. 10-2008, passed 6-10-08)
§ 34.32 HAZARDOUS MATERIAL CLEANUP CHARGES.
   (A)   Definitions. The definitions set forth in IC 38-8-12.2 are hereby
incorporated into this section as if fully set forth herein.
   (B)   Fees and charges imposed. 
      (1)   The city hereby imposes the fees and charges authorized by IC 36-8-
12.2 upon any and all responsible parties.
      (2)   Pursuant to said statute, the specific fees and charges to be
charged are contained in the State Fire Marshal’s schedule of service charges
issued under IC 36-8-12-16(e), as may be amended from time to time.
      (3)   Said schedule of service charges, as may be amended from time to
time, is hereby incorporated by reference into this section as if fully set
forth herein.
   (C)   The billing and collection of these fees and charges shall likewise be
done pursuant to the procedures set forth in IC 36-8-12.2.
   (D)   As required by IC 36-8-12.2, monies collected pursuant to this section
shall be deposited in the Hazardous Materials Response Fund of the city.
(Ord. 11-2008, passed 6-10-08)
§ 34.33 FIRE MERIT SYSTEM.
   (A)   The Fire Merit System is amended under the authority of IC 36-1-4-14.
   (B)   The Fire Merit Commission is established and its members appointed as
IC 36-8- 3.5-6 requires. The Commissioners are:
      (1)   Two persons appointed by the Mayor;
      (2)   One person appointed by the Common Council; and
      (3)   Two persons elected by the Fire Department’s active members.
   (C)   The Fire Merit System will be governed by the terms and provisions of
the model merit system as stated in IC 36-8-3.5 and in effect on the effective
date of this section, with the exception of that the minimum age to be
considered for appointment to the Department requires an applicant to be at
least 18 years of age, but under 36 years of age.
   (D)   The amended Fire Merit System will take effect July 15, 2019.
   (E)   All components of the city's Fire Merit System not amended by this
section remain in full effect.
   (F)   No current Department member's rank or other standing as of the date
of adoption of the amendment of this section will be affected by the
amendment's passage and adoption.
(Ord. 13-2013, passed 5-13-13; Am. Ord. 17-2019, passed 7-8-19)
§ 34.34 COMMUNITY PARAMEDIC ENTERPRISE.
   (A)   Definitions.
      (1)   For the purpose of this chapter, definitions will be added as
deemed necessary to describe the programs, cost centers and objects of expense
for the program. Planned programs are:
         (a)   Heart Failure Program.
         (b)   Newborn/Infant Mortality Program.
         (c)   Chronic Disease Management Program.
      (2)   Each program will have a corresponding cost center departmentalized
in the Community Paramedic Operating Fund.
      (3)   Revenues of the enterprise will consist of objects or revenue for
intergovernmental revenues, charges for services, licenses and permits, fines
and fees, and other financing sources as deemed necessary by the city's fiscal
officer.
      (4)   Each cost-center department will have objects of expense for
personal services, supplies, debt service, other services and charges, capital
outlays and other financing uses as deemed necessary by the city's fiscal
officer.
   (B)   Revenue sources. Anticipated revenue sources may include but are not
limited to:
      (1)   Indiana State Department of Health.
      (2)   Center for Disease Control.
      (3)   American Heart Association.
      (4)   Operating Grants.
      (5)   Capital Grants.
      (6)   Insurance carrier reimbursements.
      (7)   Interest income.
   (C)   Authorized expenditures. Anticipated expenditures may include and are
not limited to:
      (1)   Personal services to include salaries and related benefits.
      (2)   Supplies for operations and maintenance.
      (3)   Debt service for leases, bonds and other forms of debt.
      (4)   Other services and charges for professional fees, insurance,
contracted support and other services.
      (5)   Capital outlays for replacements and improvements.
   (D)   Life of Fund. The Community Paramedic Enterprise shall remain in
effect until terminated by action of the Council. The Fund balance(s) of the
Enterprise are non-reverting.
   (E)   Disposition of Fund on termination. Upon termination, remaining
balances in the Enterprise Fund(s) shall be transferred to the city's Rainy-Day
Fund or General Fund.
(Ord. 31-2017, passed 12-11-17)
Cross-reference:
   Community Paramedics Operating Fund, see §
