GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 35.01 DISBURSEMENTS OF MONEY.
   (A)   Disbursements of money in advance of approval by board.
      (1)   The Clerk-Treasurer is authorized to make disbursements of money on
a claim submitted for lawful city purposes in advance of approval by the board
having jurisdiction over the allowance of claims, if:
         (a)   The board having jurisdiction over the allowance of claims has
given its prior written approval for advance payment of such type expense.
         (b)   The claim is for one of the following types of expenses:
            1.   Property or services purchased or leased from the United
States Government, its agencies, or its political subdivision.
            2.   License or permit fees.
            3.   Insurance premiums.
            4.   Utility payments or utility connection charges.
            5.   General grant programs where advance funding is not prohibited
and the contracting party posts sufficient security to cover the amount
advanced.
            6.   Grants of state funds authorized by statute.
            7.   Maintenance or service agreements.
            8.   Leases or rental agreements.
            9.   Bond or coupon payments.
            10.   Payroll.
            11.   State, federal, or county taxes.
            12.   Expenses that must be paid because of emergency
circumstances.
            13.   A product or service for which the city governing body has
accepted a bid.
         (c)   Each such payment of expenses under this division (A) is
supported by a fully itemized claim.
      (2)   The board having jurisdiction over the allowance of the claim shall
review and approve the claim at its next regular or special meeting following
the disbursement.
(Ord. 37-1992, passed 11-9-92)
   (B)   Procedure to approve disbursement of certain funds.
      (1)   The Common Council may from time to time choose to fund one or more
accounts under its budget for the purpose of paying legal fees it may incur in
hiring independent legal counsel for the Common Council as a body.
      (2)   No disbursement shall be made however from any such account so
established until a majority of the Common Council has approved the expenditure
and disbursement of money from the account.
      (3)   Any vote to authorize disbursement from such account for such
purpose must be made at a regular or special meeting of the Common Council and
shall be recorded in the minutes of that meeting.
(Ord. 42-1992, passed 12-21-92; Am. Ord. 1-1996, passed 1-8-96)
§ 35.02 ASSESSMENTS FOR WORK PERFORMED BY CITY.
   (A)   Notice of Hearing. Whenever any officer of the city shall perform any
labor or work on any private lot, tract, or parcel of land in the city, or in
any street, alley or public way adjacent thereto, which work or labor is
authorized to be done by any section of this code, the officer shall report
such work together with the cost thereof to the Council at its next regular
meeting after such work has been done. The Council shall thereupon fix its next
regular meeting as a date upon which such report shall be heard and upon which
the owners of such property may be heard with reference to the assessment of
the cost of such work against such property. The Clerk-Treasurer shall prepare
a notice stating the character of such work, the cost of the same and a
description of the property for or on which such work was done and time for
hearing the same, which notice shall be delivered to the Chief of Police by the
Clerk-Treasurer. The Chief of Police shall at least seven days before the date
of such hearing serve such notice on the owner of such property if he is a
resident of the city and known by leaving a copy of such notice with the owner.
If the owner is a nonresident, the Chief of Police shall serve such notice by
sending a copy thereof by registered mail to the owner, if the address of the
owner is known to the Chief of Police. If the owner is a nonresident and his
address unknown, the Chief of Police shall serve the notice by delivering a
copy thereof to the occupant of the real estate described in the notice, and if
such real estate is vacant and unoccupied and the resident of the owner is
unknown, the Chief of Police shall post a copy of the notice on the property in
a conspicuous place, all of which shall be done at least seven days prior to
such hearing. The Chief of Police shall report the service of notice at the
meeting of the Council.
   (B)   Hearing. At its meeting, the Council shall hear any property owner
whose property is liable to be assessed and is described and mentioned in such
report and shall determine the actual cost of the work. If the charge is found
reasonable, the amount so determined shall be assessed against such property
and shall at once attach and become a lien against the property to the same
extent that taxes are a lien, and shall be collected by the Clerk-Treasurer as
herein provided.
   (C)   Assessment Records. The Clerk-Treasurer shall maintain a book known as
the “Special Assessment Duplicate,” and he shall enter therein all such
assessments, together with a description of the property assessed, the name of
the owner, and the nature of the work for which such assessment is made. On the
first day of each month the Clerk-Treasurer shall transcribe all such
assessments from his records on to the “Special Assessment Duplicate.”
   (D)   Lien. Such assessments shall be done and become delinquent at the
times and on the same terms as taxes are now due and become delinquent and the
Clerk-Treasurer shall, if the same are not paid, proceed to advertise and sell
the real estate assessed in the same manner as now provided by law for the sale
of real estate for delinquent taxes by County Treasurers, or the City Attorney
may bring a suit in the name of the city in any court of competent jurisdiction
to foreclose the lien.
(‘85 Code, § 4.18)
§ 35.03 PROCEDURE FOR APPROVING TRANSFERS BETWEEN FUNDS AND ADDITIONAL
APPROPRIATIONS.
   The approval of transfers between funds and additional appropriations shall
be handled in accordance with the following procedure:
   (A)   (1)   Transfers by departments between funds in the same major account
category (i.e. 110 to 120) will not require any action or approval by the
Council.
      (2)   For such transfers the request for transfer will be presented by
the department head to the Clerk-Treasurer and may be made if the appropriated
funds are available.
   (B)   Transfers between major account categories (i.e. 210 to 340)
regardless of the amount must be approved by a majority of the Common Council
and shall be approved by resolution.
   (C)   Any additional appropriations to any department budgets shall be
approved by ordinance after required publication of notice.
(Res. 1-2000, passed 2-14-00)
§ 35.04 ELECTRONIC FUND TRANSFERS.
   The Clerk-Treasurer of the city and all other city personnel duly authorized
to transfer city funds are hereby authorized to make any and all such deposits,
payments and transfers by means of electronic funds transfer (EFT) wherever
required by law or state or county rule or whenever expeditious to the
management of municipal funds.
(Res. 5-2006, passed 2-13-06)
§ 35.05 CREDIT CARDS/PROCUREMENT CARDS.
   (A)   Generally. The City of Crawfordsville, Indiana, by ordinance, has
adopted this credit card and procurement card policy to control, regulate, and
effectively evaluate the use of city issued credit card and procurement cards
for the purchasing of items necessary and beneficial to further the City of
Crawfordsville’s business. It is the intent of this policy to comply with the
minimum standards set forth in the State Board of Accounts Uniform Compliance
Guidelines. Should any provision of this policy conflict with those guidelines,
the State Board of Accounts Uniform Compliance Guidelines is controlling and is
deemed to be the policy of the City of Crawfordsville as expressly written.
   (B)   Use of cards. Credit cards/procurement cards (PCards), which are
issued by the city, are only for business related purchases by city employees.
Departmental credit cards/PCards may be used only for lawful charges of
expenses related to and necessary for the effective operation of that
department. Such uses include but are not limited to:
      (1)   Purchasing supplies and equipment for the use and benefit of the
department;
      (2)   Travel and lodging expenses of department personnel while traveling
on approved municipal business;
      (3)   Meal expenses of departmental personnel while traveling on approved
municipal business, provided that any such expense does not exceed any
authorized per diem for meals. Reasonable tips or gratuities are allowed as
meal expenses if service is provided as part of the meal;
      (4)   Approved training and education costs for departmental personnel;
and
      (5)   Any other use required for the efficient operation of the
department, provided that the use has been approved by the Clerk-Treasurer.
   (C)   Prohibited use. The credit cards/PCards may not be used for the
following:
      (1) Personal use;
      (2)   Purchasing alcohol;
      (3)   Any illegal purpose; or
      (4)   To bypass the city’s accounting system or purchasing policies.
   (D)   General procedures.
      (1)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall be responsible for keeping, maintaining,
and securing any credit card/PCard until it is necessary and proper to
distribute a city issued credit card/PCard for an authorized purpose mentioned
above. The Clerk-Treasurer shall be responsible for maintaining a list of cards
issued and will be responsible for maintaining credit limits and allowed
merchant categories.
      (2)   The city employee desiring to use a city credit card/PCard must
fill out a requisition form and obtain proper approval by the Clerk-Treasurer
before making any purchase.
      (3)   Immediately after making an authorized purchase, the city employee
must return the credit card/PCard to the Clerk-Treasurer.
      (4)   As soon as possible, but no more than seven days after use, the
City employee using the credit card/PCard shall deliver to the Clerk-Treasurer
the following documents:
         (a)   A completed requisition form signed by the purchaser and Clerk-
Treasurer;
         (b)   Original receipts and/or invoices for the charges; and
         (c)   Any other documentation required by the city that supports the
claim.
      (5)   If the employee loses the original receipt and/or invoice, the
employee shall provide a duplicate receipt and/or invoice or an affidavit of
lost receipt.
   (E)   Internal review of claims procedure.
      (1)   The Clerk-Treasurer must maintain an accounting system or log which
contains at least the following:
         (a)   The name of the city employee who requested the credit card/
PCard;
         (b)   The position of the city employee who requested the credit card/
PCard;
         (c)   The estimate amounts for the purchase;
         (d)   The fund and account numbers to be charged;
         (e)   The date the card is issued;
         (f)   The date the card is returned; and
         (g)   All sufficient documentation necessary to assure accuracy and
compliance with this policy.
      (2)   The city shall designate an officer other than the Clerk-Treasurer
to review the transactions listed on the credit card/PCard statement in order
to ensure there is sufficient documentation and inclusion in the claim to the
Legislative Body. This designated official must ensure the card statements and
accounting system or log provides accurate, relevant, and timely information.
The designated official must authorize their review by initialing or signing
the necessary documentation.
      (3)   All claims must be approved by the City of Crawfordsville Board of
Public Works and Safety.
   (F)   Misuse.
      (1)   Any misuse of a city issued credit card/PCard may result in
disciplinary action up to and including termination. A city employee may be
personally liable for reimbursement of charges that do not meet the
requirements of this policy.
      (2)   Any interest, late charges, or other fees resulting from the tardy
submission of proper documentation by any officer or employee shah, be the
personal responsibility of that officer or employee to pay.
      (3)   All credit cards/PCards must be kept in a secure location. Any loss
or theft must be reported to the card issuing bank and the Clerk-Treasurer
immediately.
      (4)   Upon termination of employment, the employee must immediately
surrender the card to the Clerk-Treasurer.
   (G)   City employee training; best practices.
      (1)   The Clerk-Treasurer and designated person assigned to review the
necessary credit card/PCard statements is responsible for the training and
education of employees on the proper use of city credit cards/PCards and the
requirements of this policy.
      (2)   The Clerk-Treasurer and the designated person assigned to review
the necessary credit card/PCard statements must evaluate and adjust these
internal controls and policies on a regular basis for personnel changes, newly
elected officials, financial fluctuations, etc. to ensure the city is complying
with the internal control standards as set forth by the State Board of
Accounts.
(Res. 1-2007, passed 3-7-07; Am. Res. 2-2007, passed 3-19-07; Am. Ord. 4-2016,
passed 4-11-16)

§ 35.07 DISHONORED CHECKS; FEES; PAYMENT.
   (A)   There shall be a fee of $20 added to any check or other negotiable
instrument that is dishonored or returned to any utility or department of the
city by the issuing bank for nonsufficient funds (NSF), in addition to any and
all other charges, penalties and remedies provided by law, including but not
limited to referral to the Montgomery County Prosecutor pursuant to I.C. 36-1-
8-13.
   (B)   Payment of a dishonored check must be made within ten days of
notification to the issuer by the city pursuant to I.C. 26-2-7-3 in the form of
cash, money order, or other certified funds only.
(Ord. 1-2011, passed 1-10-11)
§ 35.08 INTERNAL CONTROL STANDARDS.
   The city’s policy regarding internal controls is the internal control
standards as set forth by the State Board of Accounts Uniform Internal Control
Standards for Indiana Political Subdivisions manual as expressly written.
(Ord. 7-2016, passed 4-11-16)
§ 35.09 MATERIALITY POLICY.
   (A)   Reporting to Clerk-Treasurer. If an elected official, appointed
official or employee discovers any material irregular variances, losses,
shortages, or thefts of cash or other assets, the official or employee will
immediately report the irregularity or theft to the mayor and to the Indiana
State Board of Accounts.
   (B)   Discovery of irregularities by Clerk-Treasurer. If the Clerk-Treasurer
discovers any material irregular variances, losses, shortages, or thefts of
cash or other assets, the Clerk-Treasurer will immediately report the
irregularity or theft to the Mayor and to the Indiana State Board of Accounts.
   (C)   Procedure. Upon receipt of a report of any material irregular
variance, loss, shortage, or theft, the Clerk-Treasurer must:
      (1)   Maintenance of record. Log all reports into a spreadsheet
permanently maintained by the city;
      (2)   Confirmation. Confirm the dollar amount of the variance, loss,
shortage, or theft;
      (3)   Definition of materiality. For this policy, the term MATERIAL means
a variance, loss, shortage, or theft of cash which exceeds $2,000 and a
variance, loss, shortage, or theft of any other (non-cash) asset which exceeds
$2,000;
      (4)   Investigation. Investigate the cause of any variance, loss,
shortage, or theft and document all findings;
      (5)   Corrective action. Document and implement corrective actions or
internal control procedures to correct the causes of the variance, loss,
shortage, or theft; and
      (6)   Record keeping. Maintain copies of all documentation, resolution of
incidents, and any report to the State Board of Accounts in a centralized
folder.
   (D)   Duty of public officials to report misappropriation of public funds.
All public officials with actual knowledge of, or reasonable cause to believe,
there has been a misappropriation of public funds must immediately send written
notice of the misappropriation to the State Board of Accounts and the
prosecuting attorney under I.C. 5-11-1-27(I) and to the Mayor under this
policy.
(Ord. 21-2017, passed 7-10-17)
§ 35.10 INVESTMENT POLICY.
   (A)   In addition to any other statutory powers to make investments, the
Clerk-Treasurer may invest funds in accordance with I.C. 5-13-9 under these
guidelines established by the Crawfordsville Common Council. I.C. 5-13-9-1(a).
   (B)   The funds that may be invested by the Clerk-Treasurer under this
policy include money raised by bonds issued for future specific purposes,
sinking funds, depreciation reserve funds, gift, bequest or endowment, and any
other funds available for investment. I.C. 5-13-9-1(c);
   (C)   The Clerk-Treasurer may invest or reinvest any funds held and
available for investment in any of the following:
      (1)   Securities backed by the full faith and credit of the U.S. Treasury
or fully guaranteed by the U.S. and issued by any of the following:
         (a)   The U.S. Treasury;
         (b)   A Federal agency;
         (c)   A Federal instrumentality; and
         (d)   A Federal government sponsored enterprise.
      (2)   Securities fully guaranteed and issued by any of the following:
         (a)   A Federal agency;
         (b)   A Federal instrumentality;
         (c)   A Federal government sponsored enterprise.
      (3)   Municipal securities issued by an Indiana local government entity,
a quasi-governmental entity related to the state, or any unit of government,
municipal corporation, or special taxing district in Indiana, if:
         (a)   The issuer has not defaulted on any of the issuer's obligations
within the 20 years preceding the date of purchase. I.C. 5-13-9-2; and
         (b)   The Clerk-Treasurer obtains approval from the Mayor and Common
Council.
   (D)   If an investment under division (C) above (I.C. 5-13-9-2(a)) is made
at a cost in excess of the par value of the securities purchased, any premium
paid for the securities purchased shall be deducted from the first interest
received and returned to the fund from which the investment was purchased, and
only the net amount is considered interest income. I.C. 5-13-9-2(b).
   (E)   The Clerk-Treasurer may sell any securities acquired and may do
anything necessary to protect the interests of the funds invested, including
the exercise of exchange privileges which may be granted with respect to
maturing securities in cases where the new securities offered in exchange meet
the requirements for initial investment. I.C. 5-13-9-2(c).
   (F)   The Clerk-Treasurer is the legal custodian of the securities which the
city has invested, and he or she shall accept safekeeping receipts or other
reporting for securities from:
      (1)   A duly designated depository; or
      (2)   A financial institution located either in or out of Indiana having
custody of securities with a combined capital and surplus of a at least
$10,000,000 according to the last statement of condition filed by the financial
institution with its governmental supervisory body. I.C. 5-13-9-2(d).
   (G)   The Clerk-Treasurer may invest funds or reinvest funds that are held
by the Clerk-Treasurer and available for investment in investments commonly
known as money market mutual funds that are in the form of securities of or
interests in an open-end, no-load, management-type investment company or
investment trust registered under the provisions of the Federal Investment
Company Act of 1940, as amended. These investments shall be made through
depositories designated by the state board of finance as depositories for state
deposits under I.C. 5-13-9.5.
      (1)   The portfolio of an investment company or investment trust
described above must be limited to the following:
         (a)   Direct obligation of the United States;
         (b)   Obligations issued by any of the following:
            1.   A Federal agency;
            2.   A Federal instrumentality; and
            3.   A Federal government sponsored enterprise.
         (c)   Repurchase agreements as defined by I.C. 5-13-9-3(a), fully
collateralized by direct obligations of the U.S. or by a Federal agency, a
federal instrumentality, or a federal government sponsored enterprise.
      (2)   The form of securities of or interests in an investment company or
investment trust must be rated as one of the following:
         (a)   AAAM, or its equivalent, by Standard and Poor's Corporation or
its successor;
         (b)   AAA, or its equivalent, by Moody's Investment Service, Inc. or
its successor.
      (3)   The form of securities in an investment company or investment trust
described above is considered to have a stated final maturity of one day. I.C.
5-13-9-2.5.
   (H)   The Clerk-Treasurer may enter into repurchase agreements, as defined
in I.C. 5-13-9-3(a), with any funds that are held by the Clerk-Treasurer and
available for investment, as follows:
      (1)   With depositories designated by the state board of finance as
depositories for state deposits under I.C. 5-13-9.5; and
      (2)   Involving the City's purchase and guaranteed resale of any
interest-bearing obligations issued or fully insured or guaranteed by the
United States, a United States government agency, an instrumentality of the
United States, or a federal government sponsored enterprise.
      (3)   The Clerk-Treasurer may invest in repurchase agreements without
entering into a contract under I.C. 5-13-11 for an investment cash management
system. I.C. 5-13-9-3.
   (I)   The Clerk-Treasurer may invest or reinvest any funds that are held by
the Clerk-Treasurer and available for investment in obligations issued,
assumed, or guaranteed by the International Bank for Reconstruction and
Redevelopment or the African Development Bank. I.C. 5-13-9-3.3.
   (J)   The Clerk-Treasurer may deposit, invest, or reinvest any funds that
are held by the Clerk-Treasurer and available for investment in transaction
accounts issued or offered by a designated depository of the City for the rates
and terms agreed upon periodically by the Clerk-Treasurer and the designated
depository. I.C. 5-13-9-4(a):
      (1)   When making a deposit in a certificate of deposit, the Clerk-
Treasurer shall obtain quotes of the specific rates of interest for the term of
that certificate of deposit that each designated depository will pay on the
certificate of deposit. Quotes maybe solicited and taken by telephone. A
memorandum of all quotes solicited and taken shall be retained by the Clerk-
Treasurer as a public record under I.C. 5-14-3.
      (2)   If the deposit is not placed in the designated depository quoting
the highest rate of interest, the Clerk-Treasurer shall place the deposit in
the depository quoting the second or third highest rate of interest and note
the reason for placing the deposit on the memorandum of quotes.
      (3)   If all of the designated depositories of the city decline to issue
or receive any deposit account, or to issue or receive the deposit account at a
rate of interest equal to the highest rate being offered other investors, the
Clerk-Treasurer may invest in the deposit accounts of any financial institution
designated for state deposits as a depository by the state board of finance
under I.C. 5-13-9.5 and I.C. 5-13-9-4.
   (K)   The Clerk-Treasurer may invest in certificates of deposit of
depositories that have not been designated by the Montgomery City Board of
Finance but have been designated by the Indiana Board of Finance as a
depository for state deposits under I.C. 5-13-9.5. For such investments, the
Clerk-Treasurer shall solicit quotes for the certificate of deposit and follow
the procedures specified in I.C. 5-13-9-5(b) and (c).
   (L)   The Clerk-Treasurer may invest public funds in interest bearing
deposit accounts, as defined by I.C. 5-13-9-5.3(a), in accordance with the
following conditions:
      (1)   The funds are initially invested through a depository that is
selected by the Clerk-Treasurer.
      (2)   The selected depository arranges for the deposit of the funds in
interest bearing deposit accounts in one or more federally insured banks or
savings and loan associations, wherever located, for the city's account.
      (3)   The full amount of the principal and any accrued interest of each
deposit are covered by insurance of any Federal deposit insurance agency.
      (4)   The selected depository acts as a custodian for the city with
respect to the deposits.
      (5)   On the same date that the city's funds are deposited, the selected
depository receives an amount of deposits covered by insurance of any federal
deposit insurance agency from customers of other institutions, wherever
located, at least equal to the amount of the funds invested by the city through
the selected depository.
      (6)   Public funds invested in accordance with this section are not
subject to any security or pledging requirements that may otherwise be
applicable to the deposit or investment of public funds.
      (7)   For purposes of this section, "deposit account" does not include
any interest-bearing account that is authorized to be set up and offered by a
financial institution in the course of its respective business. I.C. 5-13-9-
5.3.
   (M)   The investment of public funds shall be made in accordance with I.C.
5-13-9-5.7 and with the Clerk-Treasurer's approval.
   (N)   The investment of public funds under this Policy shall be limited to
not more than 25% of the total portfolio of public funds invested by the City,
including balances in transaction accounts. I.C. 5-13-9-5.7.
   (O)   Interest derived from investments under this Policy shall be deposited
and receipted in accordance with I.C. 5-13-9-6.
      (1)   The Clerk-Treasurer may invest tax collections under this policy
pending distribution of the collections to political subdivisions. These
investments may not: exceed the amount available after considering taxes that
may need to be advanced to any political subdivision; or be made in deposit
accounts or repurchase agreements, the maturity dates of which are later than
the time when the tax collections are required by law to be distributed to
political subdivisions.
      (2)   The interest received on the investments under division (N)(1)
above shall be receipted to the city general fund or any other fund from which
expenses incurred in the maintenance of city streets maybe paid. The
Crawfordsville Common Council shall determine the allocation of this interest
among the general fund and the various highway funds into which the interest
may be deposited.
      (3)   Interest derived from the investment of the proceeds from bonded
indebtedness or local tax levies maybe applied to the appropriate redemption
bond interest or sinking fund for the bonded indebtedness.
      (4)   If meter deposits of a municipally owned utility are invested, the
interest earned on the investment may be applied to and used in the operation
or depreciation fund of the municipally owned utility as determined by its
governing body.
      (5)   Interest from the investment of the city's public funds may not be
paid personally or for the benefit of any public officer. I.C. 5-13-9-6.
   (P)   (1)   The Clerk-Treasurer maybe required to pay a service charge to
the depository in which funds are deposited, if the depository requires ah
customers to pay the charge for providing the service. However, the service
charge imposed must be considered in the computation of the interest rate for
determining which depositories are entitled to investments as prescribed by
this policy. If the total service charge cannot be computed before the
investment, the Clerk-Treasurer shall estimate the service charge and adjust
'the interest rate based on this estimate. The service charge may be paid:
         (a)   By direct charge to the deposit or other account; or
         (b)   In a manner that subtracts the service charge from interest
earned on the funds in the deposit or other account.
      (2)   If the service charge is paid in the second manner, the Clerk-
Treasurer must report the net interest deposited in the city's financial
records, and the Clerk-Treasurer is not required to report the amount of the
service charge subtracted in the City's financial records. I.C. 5-13-9-8.
   (Q)   Funds deposited in deposit accounts in accordance with I.C. 5-13-9 and
this Policy and interest earned or accrued on the funds are public funds and
are covered by the insurance fund, as defined in I.C. 5-13-4-15 and I.C. 5-13-
9-8.5.
   (R)   The Clerk-Treasurer may not purchase securities on margin or open a
securities margin account for the investment of public funds. I.C. 5-13-9-9.
   (S)   The Clerk-Treasurer and the investing officers of other political
subdivisions located within Montgomery City may establish joint investment
funds by entering into a written master agreement that defines their rights and
obligations, as provided in I.C. 5-13-9-10.
   (T)   The Clerk-Treasurer may pay any funds held by him or her into the
local government investment pool, as defined by I.C. 5-13-9-11(b), for the
purpose of deposit, investment, and reinvestment of the funds by the Treasurer
of the state on behalf of the city in accordance with I.C. 5-13-9-11.
   (U)   This policy will expire four years after it takes effect.
(Ord. 21-2018, passed 9-10-18)

§ 35.15 COMMUNITY PARAMEDIC HIV HEALTH GRANT FUND NO. 711.
   (A)   Safer Grant Fund No. 711 is renamed the Community Paramedic HIV Health
Grand Fund No. 711 and repurposed under this section's terms.

("the Project") will be placed in the Community Paramedic HIV Health Grant Fund

fund.

§ 35.16 CUMULATIVE CAPITAL DEVELOPMENT FUND.
   (A)   There is re-established the Cumulative Capital Development Fund ("the
CCD Fund") within the city.
   (B)   The purposes of the CCD Fund are every approved purpose I.C. 36-9-15.5
provides, as it may be amended from time to time and the city will follow I.C.
36-9-15.5 regarding CCD Fund expenditures. CCD Fund monies, therefore, may be
used for statutory purposes, including:
      (1)   I.C. 8-16-3 allows for certain bridge capital expenditures;
      (2)   I.C. 8-22-3-25 allows for certain airport capital expenditures;
      (3)   I.C. 14-33-14 concerns conservancy district channel improvements,
levees, and water retarding or impoundment structures;
      (4)   I.C. 16-23-1-40 concerns city-owned hospitals;
      (5)   I.C. 36-8-14 allows for certain fire and police capital
expenditures;
      (6)   I.C. 36-9-4-48 concerns public mass transportation;
      (7)   I.C. 36-9-16-2 allows for the following expenditures:
         (a)   To purchase, construct, equip, and maintain buildings for public
purposes;
         (b)   To acquire the land, and any improvements on it, which are
necessary to construct public buildings;
         (c)   To demolish any improvements on land acquired under this
section, and to level, grade and prepare the land for the construction of a
public building;
         (d)   To acquire land or rights-of-way to be a public way or other
means of ingress or egress to land acquired to construct a public building;
         (e)   To improve or construct any public way or other means of ingress
or egress to land acquired to construct a public building;
      (8)   I.C. 36-9-16-3 allows for the following expenditures:
         (a)   To acquire land or rights-of-way to be used for public ways or
sidewalks;
         (b)   To construct and maintain public ways or sidewalks;
         (c)   To acquire land or rights-of-way for the construction of
sanitary or storm sewers, or both;
         (d)   To construct and maintain sanitary or storm sewers, or both;
         (e)   To acquire, by purchase or lease land, buildings, or rights-of-
way for the purchase price of a utility;
         (f)   To purchase or lease land, buildings, or rights-of-way for any
utility that is acquired or operated by the unit;
         (g)   To purchase or acquire land, with or without buildings, for park
or recreation purposes;
         (h)   To purchase, lease, or pay all or part of the purchase price of
motor vehicles for the Police or Fire Department, or both, including ambulances
and firefighting vehicles with equipment, ladders, and hoses;
         (i)   To retire in whole or in part any general obligation bonds of
the unit issued for acquiring or constructing improvements or properties that
would qualify for cumulative capital improvement funds;
         (j)   To purchase or lease equipment and other consumable personal
property needed by the unit for any public transportation use;
         (k)   In a county or a consolidated city, to purchase or lease
equipment to be used to illuminate a public way or sidewalk;
         (l)   For the following purposes:
            1.   To purchase, lease, upgrade, maintain, or repair:
               a.   Computer hardware;
               b.   Computer software;
               c.   Wiring and computer networks;
               d.   Communication access systems used to connect with computer
networks or electronic gateways;
            2.   To pay for the services of full-time or part-time maintenance
employees; and
            3.   To conduct nonrecurring in-service technology training of unit
employees;
      (9)   I.C. 36-9-16.5 allows acquiring rights-of-way for public ways or
sidewalks or the construction or reconstruction of public ways or sidewalks;
      (10)   I.C. 36-9-17 allows for the construction, repair, or improvement
of streets, alleys, sidewalks, curbs, gutters, and sewers;
      (11)   I.C. 36-9-26 allows for expenditures for storm and sanitary sewer
systems;
      (12)   I.C. 36-9-27-100 allows for expenditures for building, remodeling,
and repairing park and recreation facilities, or purchasing land for these
purposes;
      (13)   I.C. 36-10-4-36 allows for additional park capital expenditures;
or
      (14)   I.C. 36-9-15.5(8)(c) allows for certain emergency expenditures.
   (C)   The tax rate for the CCD Fund will be and may not exceed $.05 per $100
of assessed valuation and shall be levied beginning with taxes assessed in 2024
and due in the year 2025, continuing until reduced or rescinded.
(Ord. 18-1993, passed 6-14-93; Am. Ord. 17-2009, passed 7-13-09; Am. Ord. 8-
2010, passed 8-2-10; Am. Ord. 15-2011, passed 7-25-11; Am. Ord. 15-2014, passed
6-23-14; Am. Ord. 9-2015, passed 6-8-15; Am. Ord. 11-2016, passed 6-13-16; Am.
Ord. 19-2017, passed 7-10-17; Am. Ord. 4-2019, passed 4-8-19; Am. Ord. 2-2020,
passed 6-15-20; Am. Ord. 4-2023, passed 3-13-23; Am. Ord. 12-2024, passed 5-13-
24)
§ 35.17 EMPLOYEE BENEFIT TRUST FUND.
   (A)   A fund is hereby established for the city to be known as the
“Crawfordsville Employee Benefit Trust Fund,” which shall be a nonreverting
fund, except as hereinafter provided for the disposition of the Fund. The Fund
shall be maintained by the Clerk-Treasurer or such other person or organization
as may so be designated by the Common Council.
   (B)   Moneys shall be deposited to the “Crawfordsville Employee Benefit
Trust Fund” as follows:
      (1)   In each calendar year during the existence of this Fund, all moneys
derived by the city from the various budgets of the city as have been provided
for health insurance for employees of the city shall be deposited to such Fund
on a regular basis by the Clerk-Treasurer.
      (2)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall also deposit in the Fund all such fees
and moneys which are withheld from the wages and salaries of the employees of
the city for the purpose of payment of health insurance premiums.
   (C)   The moneys in the Fund shall be paid out by the Clerk-Treasurer as
provided by all rules and regulations heretofore made which are applicable to
the Fund, and all rules and regulations which may be hereafter adopted by the
Common Council or by such other persons who may be designated to have control
of the Fund.
   (D)   It is understood that this Fund is to provide the funds necessary to
cover the payment of premiums for health insurance for the city and its
employees, which has been previously provided by Blue Cross-Blue Shield
Insurance, prior to the effective date of transfer of such obligation to this
Fund.
   (E)   The Board of Public Works and Safety is hereby authorized to negotiate
an agreement for health care insurance coverage for the employees of the city,
and report the results of said negotiations to the Common Council for its
consideration and approval, and that such agreement shall be consistent with
this section, and shall also provide for health care services to the employees
of the city of at least equal value as the Blue Cross-Blue Shield health care
services previously provided. Representatives of the Crawfordsville Electric
Light and Power Utility shall be invited to join the Board of Public Works and
Safety in the above negotiations.
   (F)   Any excess funds remaining in the “Crawfordsville Employee Benefit
Trust Fund” in a given year, after payment of all expenses, shall remain in
such Fund and shall become non-reverting and shall always be available for the
funding of health care coverage for the employees of the city; however, the
Common Council, if it deems that a surplus exists in such Fund that may not be
necessary to fund the health care services, may, after declaring that such a
surplus exists, consider reducing premiums of both the city and employees
during the next fiscal year, or increasing benefits to both, or appropriate
such surplus moneys to the General Fund of the city.
(Ord. 2-1986, passed 1-13-1986)

   (A)   The nonreverting Fund for the Benefit of Child and Adult Victims of

that the City Clerk-Treasurer will maintain for the Police Department.
      (2)   Funding. This Fund will be funded by donations and grants received
by the Police Department for such purposes.
      (3)   Use. This Fund will be used exclusively or the purposes set out
above or at the discretion of the Chief of Police.
      (4)   This is a non-reverting fund.

§ 35.21 WASTE TRANSFER STATION AND LANDFILL NONREVERTING FUND.
   (A)   A fund to be known as the Crawfordsville Waste Transfer Station and
Landfill Nonreverting Fund is hereby established.
   (B)   Monies collected by the operator of the Crawfordsville Waste Transfer
Station and paid to the city shall be deposited in this fund and be held by the
city until expenditures are authorized by the Board of Public Works and Safety.
   (C)   Expenditures from this fund may include but not be limited to the
following:
      (1)   Reimbursement for or direct payment to, persons performing closing
or post closing services, labor, material or equipment at the Crawfordsville
Waste Transfer Station site or at any landfill site where refuse from the city
waste transfer station has been deposited.
      (2)   Paid over to any fund established by any agency of the federal,
state or local government for the use of a particular landfill operator who
operates a landfill in which has been received waste from the waste transfer
station since 1989 to be used to pay closure or post closure costs at the
landfill.
      (3)   For any purpose which the Board of Public Works and Safety deems to
directly relate to duties imposed on the city as a result of the disposal of
its solid waste.
(Ord. 52-1990, passed 11-5-90)

§ 35.23 POLICE DEPARTMENT CHILD VICTIM FUND.

Department Child Victim Fund”.
   (B)   Money in this fund shall come only from donations made to the city
specifically for said fund.
   (C)   Money may be withdrawn upon authorization of the Police Chief or the
police “Child Abuse Liaison” officer designated by the Chief of Police of the
city.
   (D)   Money withdrawn from the fund may be used to purchase toys to be given
to child abuse, neglect or accident victims, by the Police Department to ease

such temporary support appropriate.

§ 35.25 DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION SPECIAL NON-REVERTING CAPITAL
IMPROVEMENTS FUND.
   (A)   A fund is hereby established, within the various funds of the City of
Crawfordsville, Indiana, to be known as the “Department of Parks and Recreation
Special Non-Reverting Capital Improvement Fund” (sometimes hereinafter referred
to as “Parks CIP Fund”), which fund shall be maintained by the Clerk-Treasurer
of the City of Crawfordsville, Indiana.
   (B)   Moneys shall be deposited to the Non-Reverting Capital Improvement
Fund as follows: In each calendar year, during the existence of the Non-
Reverting Capital Improvement Fund, all moneys derived from daily use fees or
season fee passes to the Crawfordsville Swimming Pool in excess of the annual
average of such fees and charges collected for the calendar years 2016 and
2017, shall be deposited in the Parks CIP Fund.
   (C)   Moneys in the Non-Reverting Capital Improvement Fund shall be
maintained by the Clerk Treasurer and paid out only as may be appropriated by
the Crawfordsville Board of Parks and Recreation.
   (D)   In any given calendar year, moneys In or deposited to the Parks CIP
Fund may be expended for any capital improvement or other expense related to
Parks and Recreation Department protects as the Board of Parks and Recreations
may approve.
(Ord. 13-2018, passed 6-11-18)
§ 35.26 COMMERCIAL HISTORIC DISTRICT CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT NON-REVERTING FUND.
   (A)   Utilizing either Urban Development Action Grant (UDAG) or Rehab Loan
Program monies, a fund is hereby established to be known as the “Crawfordsville
Commercial Historic District Capital Improvement Non-reverting Fund,” to be
maintained by the Clerk-Treasurer of the city. The purpose of said fund is to
make available as an incentive to property owners in the Commercial Historic
District monies in the form of grants and low interest loans to improve and
rehabilitate buildings in said district. The fund amount will be $300,000. For
the rehabilitation of a downtown building, grants at 50% of the cost of said
rehabilitation up to $10,000, and additional low interest (2%) loans of
$10,000, with a seven-year pay back period, will be made available per
property. Historic facade restoration will have priority for the $20,000 grant/
loan awards.
   (B)   From and after the passage of this section, all sums paid to the city
in repayment of monies loaned or advanced to property owners in the Commercial
Historic District for the rehabilitation or improvement of buildings; plus any
interest charged to property owners on said loans from this fund shall be paid
into this fund, the same to be maintained as a non-reverting fund solely for
the purposes herein set out.
   (C)   To the extent of the availability of monies in this said fund, the
Board of Works and Safety, upon prior review and approval of the City Council,
may make, from time to time, grants and loans therefrom to property owners in
this Commercial Historic District of the city, in accordance with the terms as
set forth by this section, to assist property owners in the rehabilitation or
improvement of buildings in the Commercial Historic District.
(Ord. 33-2002, passed 11-12-2002)

§ 35.28 RIVERBOAT REVENUE SHARING FUND.
   (A)   A fund is hereby established, within the various funds of the city, to
be known as the Riverboat Revenue Sharing Fund, which fund shall be maintained
by the Clerk-Treasurer.
   (B)   Moneys shall be deposited to the fund as follows: In each calendar
year, during the existence of the Riverboat Sharing Fund, all moneys received
from the State Treasurer of revenue sharing wagering taxes shall be deposited
in the fund.
   (C)   Moneys in the fund shall be maintained by the Clerk-Treasurer and paid
out only as may be appropriated by the fiscal body of the city.
   (D)   Moneys from this fund may be appropriated by the city fiscal body for
the following purposes:
      (1)   To reduce the property tax levy of the city, for a particular year
(a property tax reduction under this subdivision does not reduce the maximum
levy of the city under IC 6-1.1-18.5);
      (2)   For deposit in a special fund or allocation fund created under IC
8-22-3.5, IC 36-7-14, IC 36-7-14.5, IC 36-7-15.1 and IC 36-7-30 to provide
funding for additional credits for property tax replacement in property tax
increment allocation areas or debt repayment;
      (3)   To fund sewer and water projects, including storm management
projects;
      (4)   For police and fire pensions;
      (5)   To carry out any government purpose for which the money is
appropriated by the fiscal body of the city. Money used under this subdivision
does not reduce the property tax levy of the city, town or county for a
particular year or reduce the maximum levy of the city under IC 6-1.1-18.5.
(Ord. 14-2003, passed 8-11-03)
§ 35.29 AMBULANCE AND MAJOR RESCUE EQUIPMENT REPLACEMENT FUND.
   (A)   A fund is hereby established, to be known as the Ambulance and Major
Rescue Equipment Replacement Fund, which shall be a separate fund and shall be
maintained by the Clerk-Treasurer.
   (B)   From and after December 31, 2016, the Clerk-Treasurer must deposit all
funds received, from whatever source, payable to the city for ambulance runs
and rescue service, as follows:
      (1)   One-third to the Ambulance and Major Rescue Equipment Replacement
Fund;
      (2)   Two-thirds to the city’s general fund.
   (C)   In addition thereto, from July 1, 1981, to and including June 30,
1982, those funds as are received by the city for ambulance runs and rescue
service which have previously been credited to Union and Franklin Townships, by
the city’s agreement with said townships dated December 30, 1974, shall also be
deposited in the Ambulance and Major Rescue Equipment Replacement Fund, by the
Clerk-Treasurer.
   (D)   The money received into the Ambulance and Major Rescue Equipment
Replacement Fund shall be used by the city for the purchase of new ambulances
and major rescue equipment; the Board of Public Works and Safety is hereby
authorized to purchase ambulances and major rescue equipment as may be needed
by the city, as funds become available therefor, using the moneys received into
the Ambulance and Major Equipment Replacement Fund to pay for such equipment.
   (E)   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall cause to be drawn proper
specifications for any new major equipment or ambulances to be purchased, and
advertise for bids when required, and shall submit the proper vouchers and
warrants to the Clerk-Treasurer for purchases made pursuant to this section.
(Ord. 16-1981, passed 7-13-81; Am. Ord. 19-2004, passed 8-9-04; Am. Ord. 27-
2014, passed 10-13-14; Am. Ord. 7-2017, passed 4-10-17)
§ 35.30 DOWNTOWN STREETSCAPE AND SIDEWALK FUND.
   (A)   There is hereby created the Downtown Streetscape and Sidewalk Fund
(the “Fund”) within the City of Crawfordsville.
   (B)   The purpose of the Fund is to make loans or grants to owners of
property located within the Downtown Crawfordsville Commercial District and
other entities responsible for compliance with
Chapter 155, in order to encourage compliance with the
Chapter 155, as well as to make direct expenditures for the city’s own fiscal
obligations created by
Chapter 155.
   (C)   The Board of Public Works and Safety of the city shall be responsible
for establishing grant and loan criteria and for creating forms and
requirements for applicants for funding from the fund, and it shall have
primary responsibility for consideration and approval of all grant and loan
applications from the fund, provided that all grants or loans of $1,000 or more
from the fund shall also require approval of the Common Council.
(Ord. 14-2005, passed 6-13-05)

§ 35.31 DOWNTOWN SIDEWALK GRANT FUND.
   (A)   There is hereby created the Downtown Sidewalk Grant Fund (the “Fund”)
within the city, which shall be funded with Community Development Block Grant
monies received from the State of Indiana for the downtown sidewalk improvement
project scheduled for 2007, plus matching funds of the city committed for this
project and such other revenues as the Common Council may allow by ordinance,
from time to time in the future.
   (B)   The purpose of the Fund is to pay all expenses of the foregoing
downtown sidewalk project and such other lawful expenses as may be authorized
by state law and city ordinance.
   (C)   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall be the body which approves
expenses from this fund, and which signs claims from the Fund to be submitted
to the Clerk-Treasurer.
(Ord. 23-2006, passed 12-11-06)
§ 35.32 UNSAFE BUILDING FUND.
   (A)   There is hereby created the Unsafe Building Fund (the “Fund”) within
the Department of Planning and Community Development of the city, which shall
be funded with:
      (1)   The revenue sources set forth in IC 36-7-9-14(b);
      (2)   Such other monies as the Common Council may appropriate by
ordinance from time to time;
      (3)   Such other monies that the Mayor may secure or apply for
the purposes of the Fund from time to time, including any designated Urban
Development Action Grant (UDAG) monies; and
      (4)   To the extent allowed by law, net revenues of the sale of various
parcels of surplus real estate owned by the city.
   (B)   The purposes of the Fund are those set forth by IC 36-7-9-14(c).
   (C)   Any Urban Development Action Grant (UDAG) Fund monies placed in the
Unsafe Building Fund and used for purposes set forth in IC 36-7-9-14(c) shall
be reimbursed to the UDAG Fund from the Unsafe Building Fund when and if the
city receives reimbursement, proceeds of payment with respect to any unsafe
property for which UDAG monies were so used.
   (D)   The Director of the Department of Planning and Community Development
shall be the official who approves expenses from this Fund, and who signs
claims from the Fund to be submitted to the Board of Public Works and Safety
for its review, as any other claim from the other funds subject to its
jurisdiction.
(Ord. 24-2006, passed 12-11-06)
§ 35.33 GOLF COURSE FUND.
   (A)   Municipal Golf Course Fund No. 204.015 (“Golf Course Fund”) is
established under this section’s terms.
   (B)   The Golf Course Fund will be funded by revenues of the municipal golf
course and other revenues as the Common Council or Board of Parks and
Recreation dedicates.
   (C)   The Golf Course Fund will pay all golf course expenses under state and
local law.
   (D)   The Board of Parks and Recreation will be the body that approves
expenses from this Fund and executes Fund claims submitted to the Clerk-
Treasurer.
   (E)   The city will keep proper books of record and account, in which
complete entries will be made showing all monies received and deposited in this
Fund, all disbursements made from the Fund, and all other financial
transactions relating to this Fund.
   (F)   The Golf Course Fund is a general appropriated fund.
(Ord. 22-2006, passed 12-11-06; Am. Ord. 2-2016, passed 2-22-16; Am. Ord. 1-
2017, passed 1-9-17)
§ 35.34 CUMULATIVE COMMUNICATIONS CENTER SUPPORT FUND.
   (A)   There is hereby created the Cumulative Communications Center Fund (the
“Fund”) within the city.
   (B)   The purposes of the Fund are as follows:
      (1)   To pay for communications center dispatcher training and uniforms
as needed;
      (2)   To pay for non-communications equipment, including but not limited
to office furniture and furnishings; and
      (3)   To pay for non-recurring expenses of the center not otherwise paid
for by the other sources of funding of the center; but
      (4)   The Fund shall not be used to pay dispatcher salaries or any other
recurring operating expenses of the center, it being the intention of the
Council that the Fund support non-recurring expenses of the center not
otherwise provided for in the Police Department’s annual budget.
   (B)   The Chief of Police shall be the official who approves expenses from
this fund, and who signs claims from the Fund to be submitted to the Board of
Public Works and Safety for its review, as any other claim from other fund
subject to its jurisdiction.
(Ord. 6-2006, passed 4-17-06)
§ 35.35 GOLF COURSE PETTY CASH FUND.
   (A)   There is hereby created the Golf Course Petty Cash Fund (the “Fund”)
within the city, which shall consist of an amount of cash (currency and coin)
not to exceed $100.
   (B)   The purpose of the Fund is to pay for various small purchases as
necessary for the efficient operation of the municipal golf course and its pro
shop, and such other lawful expenses as may be authorized by state law and city
ordinance.
   (C)   The Department of Parks and Recreation shall be the body which
approves expenses from this Fund and which signs claims from the Fund to be
submitted to the Clerk-Treasurer. The Director of Parks and Recreation and any
person or persons designated by the Department of Parks and Recreation Board
shall be the persons authorized to make day-to-day expenditures from the Fund
on behalf of the Authority and to maintain adequate cash in the Fund. A record
and receipts of all transactions from the Fund shall be maintained and
presented in summary form to the Park Board for its monthly approval.
(Ord. 9-1007, passed 2-12-07; Am. Ord. 2-2016, passed 2-22-16)
§ 35.36 ABANDONED VEHICLE FUND.
   Pursuant to IC 9-22-1-27 and 9-22-1-30(b), there is hereby established an
Abandoned Vehicle Fund in the city. Pursuant to IC 9-22-1-27(d), that Fund
shall be a nonreverting fund. Pursuant to IC 9- 22-1-27, all proceeds from the
sale of abandoned vehicles or parts shall be deposited with the Clerk-
Treasurer and placed in the Fund and the costs of administering IC 9-22-1 shall
be paid from that Fund.
(Ord. 25-2006, passed 12-11-06; Am. Ord. 10-2007, passed 2-12-07)
§ 35.37 CLEARANCE ACCOUNT FOR CEL & P ELECTRICAL INSPECTION FEES.
   (A)   There is hereby created the Clearing Account - CEL & P Inspection Fees
(the “Account”) within the city.
   (B)   The purpose of the Account is for deposit of any and all CEL & P
electrical inspection fees received by the Planning Department and any such
fees received shall then be promptly remitted to CEL & P from the Account,
without the need for an appropriation.
(Ord. 16-2007, passed 5-14-07)
§ 35.38 GOLF COURSE IMPROVEMENT FUND.
   (A)   There is hereby created the Golf Course Improvement Fund (the “Fund”),
a nonreverting fund within the city which shall consist of such user fees as
the Department of Parks and Recreation shall impose and designate toward the
Fund, as well as any other monies that the Department of Parks and Recreation
may receive from time to time from any source for the purpose of making
improvements and repairs to the golf course and its related structures and
facilities, whether through appropriation, donation, fees or other charges.
   (B)   The purpose of the Fund is to provide for expenditures for
improvements and repairs to the Crawfordsville Municipal Golf Course and its
related structures and facilities, and such other lawful expenses as may be
authorized by state law and city ordinance for a fund of this nature.
   (C)   The Department of Parks and Recreation shall be the body which
approves expenses from the Fund and which signs claims from the Fund to be
submitted to the Clerk-Treasurer.
(Ord. 1-2008, passed 2-11-08; Am. Ord. 2-2016, passed 2-22-16)
§ 35.39 AVIATION GRANT FUND.
   (A)   There is hereby created the Aviation Grant Fund, a nonreverting fund
within the Department of Aviation of the city which shall consist of any and
all grant monies that the Board of Aviation Commissioners may receive from all
sources, including but not limited to the Federal Aviation Administration.
   (B)   The purpose of the Fund is to provide for expenditures in accord with
the purposes for which said grants were received, as well as any and all other
lawful expenses as may be authorized by state law and city ordinances for a
fund of this nature.
   (C)   The Crawfordsville Board of Aviation Commissioners shall be the body
which approves expenses from this Fund and which signs claims from this Fund to
be submitted to the Clerk- Treasurer.

sources, including borrowing, other than grants and hangar rents.
   (B)   The purpose of this Fund is to provide for expenditures for capital
improvements and construction projects, as well as any and all other lawful

which approves expenses from this Fund and which signs claims from this Fund to
be submitted to the Clerk- Treasurer.

§ 35.41 JOBS AND INVESTMENT CREATION FUND 225.
   (A)   Established. The Economic Development Incentives Fund is created that
the City Clerk-Treasurer will maintain for the city.
   (B)   Funding. This fund will be funded by all revenues the city receives
regarding the sale or disposition of Crawfordsville Commerce Park or other city
real-property interests.
   (C)   Use. The fund will be used exclusively at the mayor's discretion for
economic incentives to attract or retain businesses and development in the
Commerce Park and in the city. The fund may also be used to pay principal and
interest balances of the Commerce Park Bond.
   (D)   Non-reverting fund. This is a non-reverting fund.

§ 35.42 HAZARDOUS MATERIALS RESPONSE FUND.
   (A)   Pursuant to IC 36-8-12.2-8.1, there is hereby created a Hazardous
Materials Response Fund, a nonreverting fund within the Fire Department of the
city which shall consist of any and all monies that the Department may receive
from emergency action reimbursement charges, all of which shall be and hereby
is done pursuant to IC 36-8-12.2-8.
   (B)   The purposes of this Fund are as set forth in IC 36-8-12.2-8.
   (C)   The Board of Public Works and Safety, as the body that oversees the
Fire Department budget, shall be the body which approves expenses from this
Fund and which approves claims from this Fund to be submitted to the Clerk-
Treasurer.
(Res. 9-2008, passed 6-9-08)
§ 35.43 RAINY DAY FUND.
   (A)   A “Rainy Day Fund” is established in and for the city.
   (B)   (1)   The Rainy Day Fund may receive transfers of unused and
unencumbered funds under I.C. 36-1-8-5 in respect to funds raised by general or
special tax levies.
      (2)   Whenever the purposes of a general or special tax levy on all
taxable property of the city have been fulfilled and an unused and unencumbered
balance remains in the that fund, the Common Council may order the balance of
that fund to be transferred to the Rainy Day Fund.
      (3)   In any fiscal year, the Common Council may transfer not more than
10% of the city’s annual budget for the fiscal year, as adopted under I.C. 6-
1.1-17, the Rainy Day Fund.
   (C)   Supplemental distributions of the County Option Income Tax pursuant to
state law and supplemental distributions of the County Economic Development
Income Tax pursuant to state law shall be deposited by the Clerk-Treasurer into
the Rainy Day Fund. Any receipts from those income taxes currently deposited in
the General Fund of the city out of necessity shall be transferred to the Rainy
Day Fund.
   (D)   The Common Council may designate such other sources as it may from
time to time determine are appropriate to be deposited or transferred to the
Rainy Day Fund.
   (E)   The purpose of the Rainy Day Fund shall be to provide such funding as
may be determined reasonable and necessary by the Common Council for the uses
and purposes for which funds from the General Fund, the County Option Income
Tax, and County Economic Development Income Tax may otherwise be expended.
   (F)   The Rainy Day Fund is subject to the same appropriation process as
other funds that receive tax money. Before making an appropriation, the Common
Council shall make a finding that the proposed use of the Rainy Day Fund is
consistent with the intent of the fund as required by I.C. 36-1-8-5.1(b).
   (G)   Interest earned on monies in the Rainy Day Fund shall be retained by
the Rainy Day Fund.
(Ord. 3-2009, passed 3-9-09)
§ 35.44 STORM WATER UTILITY OPERATING AND MAINTENANCE FUND.
   (A)   There is hereby created a Storm Water Utility Operating and
Maintenance Fund, Fund #618, for and within the Storm Water Utility of the
city, which shall consist of any and all monies that said utility may receive
from any source, including but not limited to user fees and penalties, grants,
donations, and appropriations, to be spent for the purpose of improving,
maintaining and operating the Storm Water Utility.
   (B)   The Board of Directors of the Storm Water Utility, as the body that
oversees said utility, shall be the body which approves expenses from this fund
and which approves claims from this fund to be submitted to the Clerk-
Treasurer.
(Res. 20-2009, passed 12-14-09)
§ 35.45 CUMULATIVE FIRE FUND.
   (A)   The Cumulative Building or Remodeling, Firefighting, and Police Radio

14, and the city shall follow I.C. 36-8-14 requirements in funding and
administering the Fire Fund.
   (C)   The Fire Fund tax rate is and may not exceed $0.0333 per $100 of

§ 35.46 EPA BROWNFIELD GRANT FUND.
   (A)   The obsolete COPS Grant Fund No. 712 is repurposed under the terms of
this section and renamed the EPA Brownfield Grant Fund No. 712 to hold and
dispense the funds received by the city from the U.S. Environmental Protection
Agency for the city's Brownfield remediation project (the "project").
   (B)   Any funds in the COPS Grant Fund will revert to the Crawfordsville
General Fund.
   (C)   The grant funds received because of the project will be placed in the
EPA Brownfield Grant Fund and may be expended only for the project's purposes
under the grant's terms, federal law, and Indiana law.
   (D)   The EPA Brownfield Grant Fund No. 712 will remain in effect until the
Crawfordsville Common Council agrees to liquidate and dissolve the fund.
   (E)   The City Clerk-Treasurer will keep proper books of record and account,
in which complete entries will be made showing all monies received and
deposited in this fund, all disbursements made from the fund, and all other
financial transactions relating to this fund.
   (F)   The EPA Brownfield Grant Fund will be a nonreverting fund.
(Ord. 19-2020, passed 12-14-20)

§ 35.49 IVY TECH BOND PROCEEDS FUND.

§ 35.50 AVIATION FUEL NON-REVERTING FUND.
   (A)   Established. Under I.C. § 8-22-2-7(c) the Aviation Fuel Non-Reverting
Fund 240 ("Fuel Fund") is created that the City Clerk-Treasurer will maintain
for the BOAC.
   (B)   Funding. This Fuel Fund will be funded by separate appropriations or
transfers as authorized from time to time by the Crawfordsville Common Council,
as the city's fiscal body.
   (C)   Use. The Fuel Fund will be used exclusively by the BOAC for the
purchase of fuels and lubricants to be sold to the general public in the
operation of the Crawfordsville Municipal Airport; and paying the costs of
personnel, supplies, and equipment necessary for the operation and maintenance
of the airport fueling system.
   (D)   Discretionary transfers. Notwithstanding division (C), the BOAC, in
its discretion, may at any time transfer profits from the sale of fuels and
lubricants to:
      (1)   The aviation fund; or
      (2)   A reserve or depreciation account created for the airport.
   (E)   Accounting. All funds received from the sale of fuels and lubricants
purchased with Fuel Fund monies must be turned over to the City Clerk-Treasurer
at least once a month for deposit into the Fuel Fund. The BOAC will disburse
these funds to purchase fuels and lubricants for sale to the public in the
airport's operation, and paying the cost of personnel, supplies, and equipment
necessary for the operation and maintenance of the airport fueling system, or
make transfers under this chapter.
   (F)   Annual reconciliation. At the end of each fiscal year, the BOAC must
report to the Common Council, as fiscal body, showing the money received and
paid over to the Clerk-Treasurer to the credit of the Fuel Fund, and also
showing the amount and value of fuels and lubricants on hand.
   (G)   Excess funds. If at the end of the fiscal year the accumulated Fuel
Fund balance, plus the value of inventory of fuels and lubricants on hand,
exceeds the total previous year's expenditures by 25%, the excess must be
transferred to the general aviation fund.
   (H)   Non-reverting fund. This is a non-reverting fund.
(Ord. 1-2015, passed 2-9-15; Am. Ord. 19-2018, passed 8-13-18)
§ 35.51 MAYOR’S PROMOTIONS AND SPONSORSHIP FUND.
   (A)   Established. Under I.C. 36-7-2-7 and I.C. 36-1-3 et. seq., the Mayor’s
Promotions and Sponsorship Fund 430 (“Promotions Fund”) is created that the
City Clerk-Treasurer will maintain for the Mayor.
   (B)   Funding. This Promotions Fund will be funded by separate
appropriations or donations as received from time to time by the Mayor or other
city officials, employees, or agents.
   (C)   Use. The Promotions Fund will be used exclusively by the mayor to pay
for expenses to promote the city, which expenses include, but are not limited
to:
      (1)   Expenses incurred in the promotion of city activities and
opportunities, including meeting room rental, decorations, meals, travel,
memorabilia, awards, expenses incurred in interviewing job applicants and
expenses incurred in developing relations with other units of government;
      (2)   Flowers or other appropriate items, for the purpose of
demonstrating the concern sympathy, or support of city officials or employees,
or both, in response to an individual’s death, illness, hospitalization, or
other similar circumstance;
      (3)   Food, beverages, tableware, decorations, entertainment, or other
items in connection with a city-sponsored event or program, or with work by
employees outside of normal work hours; and
      (4)   Any other expenses of a civic or governmental nature the mayor
deems to be in the city’s best interest.
   (D)   Non-Reverting fund. This is a nonreverting fund.
   (E)   Transfer of funds. Any funds currently in the Police Building Bonds 99
Fund 430 will revert to the Crawfordsville General Fund, and the Police
Building Bonds 99 Fund 430 is renamed and repurposed as set out in this
section.
(Ord. 2-2015, passed 3-9-15)

§ 35.61 SIDEWALK MAINTENANCE AND IMPROVEMENT NON-REVERTING FUND.
   (A)   A fund is hereby established to be known as the “Sidewalk Maintenance
and Improvement Non-Reverting Fund”, to be maintained by the Clerk-Treasurer of
the city.
   (B)   From and after the passage of this section, all sums paid to the city
in repayment of monies loaned or advanced to property owners for the
installation or improvement of sidewalks shall be paid into this Fund, the same
to be maintained as a non-reverting fund solely for the purposes herein set
out.
   (C)   To the extent of the availability of monies in this said Fund, the
Board of Public Works and Safety is hereby empowered, at its discretion, from
time to time, to make loans therefrom to residential property owners of the
city who also live in the same residential property, upon such terms and
conditions as shall be deemed appropriate by the Board of Public Works and
Safety, to assist owner-occupied property owners in the maintenance or
improvement of sidewalks utilized by public pedestrian traffic and abutting a
city street of the city.
   (D)   Said Fund shall be kept separate and may be invested by the Clerk-
Treasurer of the city in interest bearing accounts and all accumulations
thereon shall also be deposited in this said Fund.
(Ord. 8-2017, passed 4-10-17)

§ 35.63 FUSION 54 NON-REVERTING FUND.
   (A)   Established. The Fusion 54 Non-reverting Fund is created that the City
Clerk-Treasurer will maintain for the city.
   (B)   Funding. This Fund will be funded by all rents and income the city
receives for the property at 101 West Main Street, Crawfordsville, Indiana (the
“property’).
   (C)   Use. The Fund will be used exclusively for any expenses related to
maintenance of the land, buildings, or any improvements on the property.
   (D)   Non-reverting fund. This is a non-reverting fund.
(Ord. 13-2017, passed 6-12-17)
§ 35.64 CONFIDENTIAL MONEY FUND.
   (A)   Established. The Police Confidential Money Fund (“Confidential Money
Fund”) is created that the City Clerk-Treasurer will maintain for the Police
Department.
   (B)   Funding. The Confidential Money Fund may be funded by separate
appropriations or transfers as authorized from time to time by the Common
Council, as the city’s fiscal body, or with money the Police Department
receives as its share of state or federal civil forfeiture proceedings, or
both.
   (C)   Use and management. The Confidential Money Fund will be used
exclusively by the Police Department and managed by the senior narcotics
officer, as directed by the Police Chief, subject to the policies and
procedures the Police Department Policy Manual prescribes under Section
50.03.060 Confidential Fund Money, or as the Department’s standard operating
procedures may be amended regarding confidential fund money.
   (D)   Reverting fund. This is a reverting fund.
(Ord. 17-2017, passed 7-10-17)
§ 35.65 RURAL HEALTH OUTREACH GRANT FUND 281.
   (A)   Established. IHCDA Fund 281 is renamed the Rural Health Outreach Grant
Fund 281 and repurposed under this section’s terms.
   (B)   Funding. Any remaining IHCDA Grant Fund 281 funds will be distributed
under the IHCDA’s Grant terms.
   (C)   Use. The funds the city receives from the Indiana Department of Health
regarding the Rural Health Outreach and Rural Network Development Program will
be placed in the Rural Health Outreach Grant Fund 281 to be held and
administered under terms the Indiana Department of Health and United States
Department of Health and Human Services establish, and state and federal law.
   (D)   Rural Health Outreach Grant Fund 281 will remain in effect until the
Crawfordsville Common Council agrees to liquidate and dissolve the Fund.
   (E)   Record keeping. The City Clerk-Treasurer will keep proper books of
record and account, in which complete entries will be made showing all monies
received and deposited in this Fund, all disbursements made from the Fund, and
all other financial transactions relating to this Fund.

§ 35.70 PARK AND RECREATION NON-REVERTING OPERATING FUND.
   (A)   Established. The Park and Recreation Department Non-Reverting Program
Operating Fund 215 ("Program Fund") is created.
   (B)   Funding. This Program Fund will be funded by reasonable fees collected
for certain Park and Recreation Department programs and facilities.
   (C)   Use. This Program Fund will be used exclusively for the purpose of
operating the various programs of the Park and Recreation Department.
   (D)   Annual reconciliation and excess funds. Notwithstanding division (C)
above the Board of Parks and Recreation must annually reconcile the revenues
and expenditures of the Fund and determine at the end of each fiscal year
whether the Fund has an excess balance above the estimated required balance
needed to effectively operate the Fund without deficit in the next fiscal year;
and, if there is an excess, the Board is required to transfer the lesser of:
      (1)   The total excess balance; or
      (2)   10% of the Fund to Fund 206 Park and Recreation General.
      (3)   For the end of fiscal year 2019, the Board is required to transfer
$10,000 from the Fund to Fund 206 Park and Recreation General.
   (E)   Non-reverting fund. This is a non-reverting fund.
(Ord. 25-2019, passed 12-9-19)

§ 35.73 CORONAVIRUS RELIEF FUND.
   (A)   Established. Fund 150 Coronavirus Relief Fund is created that the City
Clerk-Treasurer will maintain for the city.
   (B)   Funding. This fund is funded by monies received for COVID-19 that have
been appropriated by Congress and distributed by the Federal Government and
State of Indiana pass through various state offices for emergency purposes.
   (C)   Use. The fund will be used exclusively for any expenses related to the
provision services in response to the Coronavirus Disease 2019 Epidemic (COVID-
19) as dictated by Congress or the State of Indiana, or both.
   (D)   Non-reverting fund. Fund 150 Coronavirus Relief Fund is a non-
reverting fund.
(Res. 21-2020, passed 11-9-20)
§ 35.74 ARP CORONAVIRUS LOCAL FISCAL RECOVERY FUND.
   (A)   Established. The Crawfordsville ARP Coronavirus Local Fiscal Recovery
Fund (the Fund), Fund 176, as required by the ARP for the use of the funds
provided to the city, under a payment made under Section 603 to cover costs
incurred by the city, by December 31, 2024, is hereby established.
   (B)   Purposes. The Fund may be used for the following purposes:
      (1)   To respond to the public health emergency with respect to the
Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) or its negative economic impacts, including
assistance to households, small businesses, and nonprofits, or aid to impacted
industries such as tourism, travel, and hospitality;
      (2)   To respond to workers performing essential work during the COVID-19
public health emergency by providing premium pay to eligible city workers that
are performing such essential work, or by providing grants to eligible
employers that have eligible workers who perform essential work;
      (3)   For the provision of government services to the extent of the
reduction in revenue of such city due to the COVID-19 public health emergency
relative to revenues collected in the most recent full fiscal year of the city
prior to the emergency; or
      (4)   To make necessary investments in water, sewer, or broadband
infrastructure.
   (C)   Fiscal administration. The City Clerk-Treasurer will serve as the
custodian and auditing agent for the Fund and is hereby authorized to oversee
the Fund’s administration.
   (D)   Receipts. Monies deposited to the Fund are intended to be limited to
ARP funds received by the city under Section 9901 of the ARP Coronavirus Local
Fiscal Recovery Fund.
   (E)   Non-reverting fund. All monies in the Fund at the end of the calendar
year shall not revert to another fund, but must remain in said Fund as a
separate non-reverting fund.
   (F)   ARP plan. The Mayor and the Common Council will develop a plan that
will detail the specific uses of the Fund. This section and the plan may be
amended as any other ordinance or plan as long as the amendment complies with
the ARP.
(Ord. 2021-7, passed 5-10-21)

§ 35.77 AIRPORT CORONAVIRUS RESPONSE GRANT PROGRAM FUND 177.
   (A)   Established. The Airport Coronavirus Response Grant Program Fund 177
(the Fund) as ACRGP requires for the use of the funds provided to the
Crawfordsville Regional Airport under the ACRGP is hereby established.
   (B)   Fund purposes. The Fund may be used for the following purposes:
      (1)   Costs related to operations, personnel, cleaning, sanitization,
janitorial services, combating the spread of pathogens at the airport, and debt
service payments;
      (2)   Reimbursement of the airport’s operational and maintenance expenses
or debt service payments in accordance with the limitations prescribed under
the Coronavirus Response and Relief Supplemental Appropriations Act; and
      (3)   Any other purpose consistent with the ACRGP Grant terms and
conditions and federal law.
   (C)   Fiscal administration. The City Clerk-Treasurer will serve as the
custodian and auditing agent for the Fund and is hereby authorized to oversee
the Fund’s administration.
   (D)   Receipts. Monies deposited to the Fund are intended to be limited to
ACRGP Grant funds received by the Crawfordsville Regional Airport.
   (E)   Non-reverting fund. All monies in the Fund at the end of the calendar
year shall not revert to another fund, but must remain in said Fund as a
separate non-reverting fund.
(Ord. 2021-24, passed 10-12-21)

§ 36.01 CREATION OF BUREAU.
   There is hereby created an Ordinance Violations Bureau pursuant to IC 33-36-
2-1 et seq., as amended, for the city.
(Ord. 40-1989, passed 12-11-89)
§ 36.02 VIOLATIONS CLERK; DUTIES.
   (A)   The City Clerk-Treasurer is appointed and shall serve as the
Violations Clerk, who administers the Bureau.
   (B)   The Clerk-Treasurer and her staff, as her agents, shall accept written
appearances, waivers of trial, admissions of violations, and payment of civil
penalties in the amount and for the violations as provided below.
(Ord. 40-1989, passed 12-11-89)

   (B)   The second admission or judgment of a violation of the same ordinance
or code provision of one scheduled above, within a successive 12 month period
of the first admission shall be subject to the penalty set forth above plus $50
as the total civil penalty. Any third admission or judgment of a violation of
the same ordinance or code provision of one scheduled above, within a
successive 12 month period of the first admission shall be subject to the
penalty set forth above plus $75, as the total civil penalty. Any fourth or
subsequent violation of the same ordinance or code provision of one scheduled
above with 12 successive months of the first violation shall not be under the
Ordinance Violation Bureau’s jurisdiction and must be filed in Court and any
civil penalty assessed upon judgment or admission shall be set by the Judge in
accordance with the appropriate general penalty section of this code.
   (C)   Any second or subsequent violation for which the additional penalty
set forth in paragraph (B) would increase the total civil penalty above $100
must be filed in court.

§ 36.04 CIVIL PENALTIES.
   The provisions of this municipal code and the ordinances referred to herein
are hereby amended to provide and declare the civil penalty scheduled with the
said ordinance or code provision to be the specific civil penalty for the
violation of said ordinance or code provision.
(Ord. 40-1989, passed 12-11-89)

Standards for Accessible Design. Copies are available for public inspection in
the office of the City Clerk during normal business hours.
