GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 71.01 AUTHORITY OF EMERGENCY VEHICLES TO DISREGARD REGULATIONS.
   (A)   The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle, when responding to an
emergency call or when in the pursuit of an actual suspected violator of the
law or when responding to but not upon returning from a fire alarm, may
disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified
directions as required by this section.
   (B)   The exemption herein granted to the driver of an authorized emergency
vehicle shall apply only when the driver of the vehicle while in motion sounds
an audible signal by bell, siren, or exhaust whistle as may be reasonably
necessary, and when the vehicle is equipped with at least one lighted lamp
displaying a red light visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a
distance of 500 feet to the front of such vehicle, except that an authorized
emergency vehicle operated as a police vehicle need not be equipped with or
display a red light visible from in front of the vehicle.
   (C)   The foregoing provisions shall not relieve the driver of an authorized
emergency vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all
persons, nor shall such provisions protect the driver from the consequences of
his reckless disregard for the safety of others.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 71.02 ONE-WAY STREETS.
   Upon those streets and parts of streets and in those alleys described in
Chapter 76, Schedule V, vehicular traffic shall move only in the indicated
direction when signs indicating the direction of traffic are erected and
maintained at every intersection where movement in the opposite direction is
prohibited.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 71.03 STREETS CLOSED TO MOTOR VEHICLE TRAFFIC.
   The following streets are closed to motor vehicle operation:
   (A)   Alice Street at the entrance to Milligan Park.
   (B)   Milligan Park exit at the Pennsylvania Railroad.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 71.04 MOTOR VEHICLE OPERATION AND SPEED LIMITS IN PARKS.
   (A)   No person shall operate a motor vehicle in any public playground, park
or golf course in the city other than upon roadways or parking areas provided
for such purpose except for the following:
      (1)   Park maintenance or emergency vehicles.
      (2)   Golf cart vehicles which have been registered with the Park
Department.
   (B)   No person shall operate a motor vehicle in any public park in the city
at a speed in excess of 20 miles per hour nor in excess of any posted speed
limit.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
70.99
INTERSECTIONS AND TURNING MOVEMENTS
§ 71.15 STOP INTERSECTIONS.
   The intersections described in
Chapter 76, Schedule I, are designated stop intersections. When appropriate
signs conforming to the requirements of this Traffic Code are erected at the
entrances to such intersections, the operator of a vehicle approaching any of
the streets where a sign has been erected shall bring such vehicle to a full
and complete stop before entering the intersection, except when directed by a
police officer to do otherwise.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 71.16 MULTI-STOP INTERSECTIONS.
   The intersections described in
Chapter 76, Schedule II, are designated as Multi-Stop intersections and which
may be a four-way stop, a three-way stop or an all-way stop. When appropriate
signs conforming to the requirements of this Traffic Code are erected at the
entrance to such intersections, the operator of a vehicle entering any of the
streets shall bring such vehicle to a full and complete stop before entering
the intersection, except when directed by a police officer to do otherwise.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 71.17 YIELD INTERSECTIONS.
   The intersections described in
Chapter 76, Schedule III, are designated as yield intersections. When
appropriate signs conforming to the requirements of this Traffic Code are
erected at the entrance to such intersections, the operator of a vehicle
approaching any of the streets where a sign has been erected shall slow down
and yield the right-of-way to any vehicle on the cross street, except when
directed by a police officer to do otherwise.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 71.18 SIGNALIZED INTERSECTIONS.
   The intersections described in
Chapter 76, Schedule IV, are designated as signalized intersections. When
appropriate traffic-control signals conforming to the requirements of this
Traffic Code are installed at each intersection, the operator of a vehicle
entering the intersections shall obey the signal displayed as the driver
approaches the intersection, except when directed by a police officer to do
otherwise.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 71.19 RESTRICTED TURN INTERSECTIONS.
   The intersections described in
Chapter 76, Schedule VI, shall have certain turning movements restricted. When
appropriate signs conforming to the requirements of this Traffic Code are
erected that no right or left or U turn is permitted, no driver of a vehicle
shall disobey the direction of any such sign.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 71.20 RESTRICTED TURNS ON RED AT SIGNALIZED INTERSECTIONS.
   The intersections described in
Chapter 76, Schedule VII, shall restrict turns on red at signalized
intersections. When appropriate signs conforming to the requirements of this
Traffic Code are erected that no turn on red may be made at signalized
intersections no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the sign.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
70.99
SPEED REGULATIONS
§ 71.30 STATE SPEED LAWS APPLICABLE.
   The Indiana motor vehicle laws regulating the speed of vehicles shall be
applicable upon the streets within this city, except as this Traffic Code, as
authorized by Indiana motor vehicle law, hereby declares and determines upon
the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation that certain speed
regulations shall be applicable upon specified streets or in certain areas, in
which event it shall be unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle at a speed
in excess of any speed so declared in this Traffic Code when signs are in place
giving notice thereof.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
70.99
Cross-reference:
   Speeds in public parks, see §
71.04
§ 71.31 SCHOOL SPEED ZONES.
   It is hereby determined that school speed zones are established as listed in
Chapter 76, Schedule VIII. When appropriate signs are erected on those streets,
conforming to the requirements of this Traffic Code, no person shall drive a
vehicle at a speed greater than 25 miles per hour, except that the time of such
reduced speed limits are confined to periods when children are present.
   (A)   The reduced speed limit shall be applicable only when children are
present.
   (B)   The school speed zone must be properly signed indicating where the
reduced speed zone begins, the reduced speed limit within the zone and where
the reduced speed zone ends.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84; Am. Ord. 7-2019, passed 4-8-19) Penalty, see §
70.99
PEDESTRIANS
§ 71.45 BLIND PEDESTRIANS.
   (A)   For the purpose of guarding against accidents in traffic on the public
streets it shall be unlawful for any person, except persons wholly or partially
blind, to carry or use on the public streets in the city any canes or walking
sticks which are white in color or white with red end or bottom.
   (B)   Editor’s Note: Driver to yield right-of-way to blind pedestrian, see
IC 9-21-17-21.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
70.99
TRUCKS
§ 71.60 TRUCK PROHIBITIONS; EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   No person shall drive or operate, or cause to be driven or operated
any truck upon the streets, bridges, and culverts within the city, except on
designated and marked city truck routes as hereinafter described. Provided
further that all through trucks must drive or operate only on designated
federal or state numbered highways.
   (B)   As an exception to the prohibitions herein set out, trucks shall be
permitted to operate on streets other than those designated as truck routes for
the sole and only purposes of delivering or picking up goods or property at
places not located on designated truck routes; however, in taking advantage of
this exception, the trucks shall be required to follow the designated truck
route to that point which is nearest to the place of delivery or pick-up, and
then utilize the shortest possible route to the place of delivery or pick-up,
and return to the nearest designated truck route by the shortest possible
route.
   (C)   Any violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of
$2,500.00.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84; Am. Ord. 7-1996, passed 3-11-96; Am. Ord. 8-2020,
passed 9-14-20)
§ 71.61 TRUCK ROUTES.
   (A)   The streets described in
Chapter 76, Schedule IX, are designated as city truck routes when appropriate
signs conforming to the requirements of this Traffic Code are erected on said
streets.
   (B)   Truck route restrictions shall not be applicable to the downtown area,
being that area bounded by and including Market Street and Spring Street on the
north, Water Street on the east, Wabash Avenue on the south and Walnut Street
on the west, provided that said trucks using this area are making necessary
deliveries to businesses located within such area.
   (C)   The Street Department shall post all truck routes the city with
appropriate street signs, to the end that all truck routes are clearly
designated, and shall follow the recommendations of the Common Council where
applicable.
   (D)   Any violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of
$2,500.00.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84; Am. Ord. 8-2020, passed 9-14-20)
§ 71.62 COMPRESSION RELEASE ENGINE BRAKES OR “JAKE BRAKES” PROHIBITED.
   (A)   Definitions. COMPRESSION RELEASE ENGINE BRAKING, commonly known as
Jake Braking, shall mean the use or operation of any mechanical exhaust device
designed to aid in the braking, decompression, or deceleration of any motor
vehicle which results in the excessive, loud, unusual, or explosive noise from
such vehicle.
   (B)   Prohibited acts. It shall be unlawful for the driver of any motor
vehicle to use, or to operate or to cause to be used or operated, at any time
and on any street or road over which the city has jurisdiction, any mechanical
exhaust or decompression device which results in the practice known as
"compression release engine-braking" or commonly known as "jake-braking."
   (C)   Exemptions. The use of compression release engine brakes or "Jake
Brakes" by fire apparatus or other state or local emergency equipment for
emergency purposes is exempt from this section’s application.
   (D)   Posting of signs. The Crawfordsville Street Commissioner is hereby
authorized and directed to post, at reasonable locations within the city, signs
indicating the prohibition of "engine-braking" or "jake- braking," or both.
   (E)   Violations, penalties. Any person violating the provisions of this §
71.62 shall be subject to $250 fine for the first violation, $500 for the
second violation, and $750 for the third and all subsequent violations. These
prescribed penalties notwithstanding, in any prosecution in court seeking to
enforce this §
71.62, the City Attorney shall have the discretion to seek fines and costs
under §
10.99 of the Code of Crawfordsville.
(Ord. 20-2023, passed 7-10-23)
GOLF CARTS
§ 71.70 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   GOLF CART.  A three or four wheeled motor vehicle originally and
specifically designed and intended to transport one or more individuals and
golf clubs for the purpose of playing the game of golf on a golf course.
(Ord. 18-2009, passed 8-10-09)
§ 71.71 REGULATIONS.
   No person shall drive or operate a golf cart on any street, alley, highway,
sidewalk, bicycle path, or other public way within the city, other than on
public ways specifically designated by the Department of Parks and Recreation
or the Municipal Golf Course Authority for golf cart use.
(Ord. 18-2009, passed 8-10-09)
ELECTRIC PERSONAL ASSISTIVE MOBILITY DEVICES
§ 71.80 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ELECTRIC PERSONAL ASSISTIVE MOBILITY DEVICE. Shall have the meaning set
forth in I.C. 9-13-2-49.3, as the same may be amended from time to time.
   OPERATE. To ride in, or on, and control the operation of an electric
personal assistive mobility device.
   RIGHT-OF-WAY. Any street, alley, avenue, or other public drive within the
City of Crawfordsville.
(Ord. 35-2011, passed 12-12-11)
§ 71.81 OPERATION ON PUBLIC PROPERTY.
   (A)   No person shall operate an electric personal assistive mobility device
within the public right-of-way of any street or alley within the city except as
allowed under this section.
   (B)   On city streets and alleys, electric personal assistive mobility
devices shall be operated only:
      (1)   On the shoulder of the roadway or, in the absence of an improved
shoulder, on the right-hand-most portion of the roadway and in the same
direction as the street traffic on that lane of the roadway;
      (2)   While displaying a reflective slow moving vehicle emblem in
accordance with I.C. 9-21-9-3 or a red or amber flashing lamp in accordance
with I.C. 9-21-9-4;
      (3)   At times required by Indiana statute for motorists to use
headlights on motor vehicles, with at least one forward-facing headlight and
one rear-facing taillight in operation and turned on; and
      (4)   In conformity with all state laws and local ordinances, including
all traffic laws that would otherwise apply to motor vehicles.
(Ord. 35-2011, passed 12-12-11) Penalty, see §
70.99

GENERAL PARKING REGULATIONS
§ 72.01 PARKING PROHIBITED AT ALL TIMES.
   No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle at any time for any purpose in
any of the following places, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other
traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police officer or traffic-
control sign or signal:
   (A)   Within an intersection.
   (B)   On a crosswalk.
   (C)   Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within 20 feet of
points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless the
Police Department shall indicate a different length by proper signs.
   (D)   Within 25 feet from the intersection of curb lines.
   (E)   Within 30 feet upon the approach of any flashing beacon, stop sign or
traffic-control signal located at the side of the roadway.
   (F)   Within 20 feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station.
   (G)   Within 15 feet of any fire hydrant.
   (H)   In front of any public or private driveway.
   (I)   On a sidewalk.
   (J)   Alongside of or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when
such stopping, standing, or parking would obstruct traffic.
   (K)   On the roadway side of any parked vehicle, commonly known as “double
parking.”
   (L)   Upon any bridge or under any elevated structure.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.02 STOPPING IN FRONT OF BUILDINGS.
   No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any of the following places
at any time except temporarily during the actual loading or unloading of
passengers or when necessary in obedience to traffic regulations or traffic
signs or signals, or the directions of a police officer: Within a space of 25
feet immediately in front of the entrance of any church, school, hotel, theater
(during actual hours when building is being used as a theater), motion-picture
house, hospital, railway station, bus or interurban station, public meeting
place, or public meeting hall.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84; Am. Ord. 26-1990, passed 6-18-90) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.03 ALLEY PARKING.
   No person shall park any vehicle in any alley except for a period not
exceeding 30 minutes while loading or unloading the vehicle.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.04 PARKING POSITION.
   Except where angle parking is permitted, a vehicle stopped or parked upon a
roadway shall be stopped or parked with the curbside wheels of the vehicle
parallel with and within 12 inches of the curb or edge of the roadway. On a
two-way traffic street, a vehicle shall only be parked on the right side of the
roadway.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.05 ANGLE PARKING.
   Vehicles may be parked at an angle to the curb, as marked on the roadway on
those streets listed in
Chapter 77, Schedule I.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.06 PRIVATE PARKING SIGNS.
   (A)   No person shall place any sign on any street or alley or designate any
place thereon with the intent to regulate or prevent the parking of vehicles on
any street or alley.
   (B)   (1)   All parking is hereby prohibited on the north side of Milligan
Street between Crawford Street and Russell Avenue in the city.
      (2)   The Street Commissioner is hereby authorized and directed to
install the necessary signage or painting, or both, to effectuate this section,
with such markings as state law requires.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84; Am. Ord. 33-2021, passed 12-12-21) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.07 NO PARKING ZONES.
   The streets described in
Chapter 77, Schedule II, are designated no parking zones. When appropriate
signs conforming to the requirements of this Traffic Code are erected no person
shall park a vehicle on the side of the street at the times designated in the
schedule.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.08 LIMITED PARKING ZONES.
   The streets described in Chapter 77, Schedule III, are designated limited
parking zones. When appropriate signs conforming to the requirements of this
Traffic Code are erected no person shall park a vehicle on the side of the
street or for any continuous period of time longer than designated in the
schedule. Such limited parking zones may or may not be regulated by parking
meters as designated in the schedule. (Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty,
see §
72.99
§ 72.09 LOADING ZONES.
   The streets described in
Chapter 77, Schedule IV, are designated as loading zones. When appropriate
signs conforming to the requirements of this Traffic Code are erected no person
shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for a longer period of time than is
necessary for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers, or for the
loading, unloading, delivery or pickup of materials or merchandise, in any
place designated and marked as a loading zone. In no case shall the stop for
loading and unloading of materials exceed a total of 15 minutes.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.10 BUS AND TAXI ZONES.
   The streets described in
Chapter 77, Schedule V, are designated as either a bus zone or a taxi zone.
When appropriate signs conforming to the requirements of this Traffic Code are
erected no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus
zone or a taxi in a taxi zone as so designated in the schedule.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.11 PARKING LIMITED TO OFFICIAL VEHICLES.
   The streets described in
Chapter 77, Schedule VI, are designated as parking for official cars as
specified. When appropriate signs conforming to the requirements of this
Traffic Code are erected no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other
than as specified.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.12 TRUCK PARKING RESTRICTIONS.
   (A)   When appropriate signs conforming to the requirements of this Traffic
Code are erected no person shall park a truck for any purpose between the hours
of 11:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. and the hours from 4:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. from the
last Sunday of April to the last Sunday of October or as altered by the Police
Department if deemed necessary to conform to the times of greatest traffic
condition.
   (B)   This section does not prohibit the parking of trucks on said streets
while parked for the purpose of loading or unloading goods or merchandise for
any store or business establishment located on any such street.
   (C)   No person shall stop, stand or park a truck on any street other than
for the expeditious loading or unloading of freight and in no case shall the
stop exceed 30 minutes.
   (D)   No person shall park a truck in any street for a continuous period of
more than two hours.
   (E)   No person shall park any truck carrying livestock upon any street for
longer than 30 minutes, or for longer than ten minutes if the driver is not
present in or near the truck.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.13 RENTED SPACES.
   (A)   The parking spaces described in
Chapter 77, Schedule VII, are designated as “Rented Space.” When appropriate
signs conforming to the requirements of this Traffic Code are erected no person
shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than the person that has rented the
space.
   (B)   The annual rental rate(s) to be paid to the city for the rental of
parking spaces or renewal of existing rental parking spaces, shall be as
follows:
      (1)   Rental of parking space in a metered, street location shall be $500
per year.
      (2)   Rental of parking space in an off-street 4-hour lot shall be $400
per year.
      (3)   Rental of parking space in an off-street 12-hour lot shall be $300
per year.
      (4)   Rental of the designated CEL&P electric vehicle charging station at
Trail Head Park shall be $1 per hour, subject to all posted CEL&P charging
station rules and regulations.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84; Am. Ord. 39-1986, passed 11-10-86; Am. Ord. 44-
1990, passed 9-10-90; Am. Ord. 13-2006, passed 8-14-06; Am. Ord. 32-2018,
passed 12-10-18) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.14 HANDICAPPED PARKING SPACES.
   (A)   The parking spaces described in
Chapter 77, Schedule VIII, are designated as parking spaces for handicapped
persons, and when so designated by the erection of the appropriate signs, such
spaces may be used by a handicapped person, either as a driver or a passenger
in the vehicle being parked in the space designated; however, such spaces shall
be metered and the two-hour parking limit prescribed in §
72.08 shall apply to such spaces.
   (B)   Any person who parks a vehicle in any space designated as a parking
space for handicapped persons, when in fact the same is not for the benefit of
a handicapped person, shall be subject to the several penalties prescribed in §
72.99.
   (C)   All organized churches upon approval of Board of Works shall hereby be
allowed two parking spaces for the handicapped during their services on each
Sunday of the year, or at other organized church functions, such basis to be
only for the time of the special service or times for the Sunday service. When
so designated by the placing and removal of appropriate signs by the proper
church official, such places shall be used only for handicapped persons. At all
other times, such spaces shall be legal parking spaces.
   (D)   Any person who parks an unauthorized vehicle in a space designated as
a parking space for a handicapped person when so designated by the proper
church officials, shall be subject to the several penalties prescribed in §
72.99.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84; Am. Ord. 11-1989, passed 4-10-89; Am. Ord. 16-
1990, passed 4-9-90) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.15 PRIVATE PARKING LOTS.
   (A)   Definition. For the purpose of this section, the following definition
shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different
meaning.
   PRIVATE PARKING AREA. Any parking lot constructed or maintained by any
church, business establishment, or city agency designed for the purpose of
parking any vehicle while conducting business with the establishment.
   (B)   Operator or owner to post sign.
      (1)   It shall be the duty of owners or agents of owners on the premises
in a conspicuous location one or more signs reading substantially as follows:
         “Cruising in or congregating and lingering outside of a motor vehicle
in unlawful. No unoccupied vehicle may be left on these premises without the
consent of the owner and operator, and the established traffic pattern shall
not be obstructed.”
      (2)   The owner or operator of such private parking areas may request
police assistance in enforcement of this section.
   (C)   Congregation and loitering prohibited. It shall be unlawful for a
group of three or more persons to congregate and linger at any location on the
premises of a private parking area in a legally parked automobile or motor
vehicle. Persons so congregating and lingering shall be guilty of loitering. No
person shall continuously drive a motor vehicle onto a private parking area
without parking the motor vehicle, unless there is no unoccupied space
available on the premises.
   (D)   Vehicles not to be left unoccupied. It shall be unlawful for any
person to leave any unoccupied motor vehicle on any parking lot or private
parking area and to leave the premises thereof except with the knowledge and
consent of the operator of the private parking area.
   (E)   Alcoholic beverage consumption prohibited. It shall be unlawful for
any person on the premises of a private parking area, whether in or out of an
automobile, to drink any intoxicating beverage.
   (F)   Violation. Violations of this section shall be subject to the
jurisdiction of the Ordinance Violations Bureau, see §
36.03.
(Ord. 34-1992, passed 10-12-92; Am. Ord. 31-1993, passed 8-9-93) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.16 MOBILE FOOD VENDORS.
   (A)   Definitions.
      (1)   FOOD. Any raw, cooked, frozen, or processed edible substance or
beverage intended for use in whole or in part for human consumption.
      (2)   MOBILE FOOD VENDOR. A person who sells, serves, offers for sale, or
gives away food or beverages from any mobile unit, independent with respect to
water, sewer, and power utilities, capable of moving or being moved, is meant
to be portable and is not permanently attached to the ground, consisting of an
enclosed truck, trailer, bus, or similar vehicle that contains equipment used
for the sale and/or preparation of food or beverages merchandise and is closed
up when not in operation.
      (3)   SPECIAL EVENT. Any event occurring on a city street with
Crawfordsville Board of Works and Safety approval and approved temporary street
closure.
   (B)   Parking prohibition.
      (1)   Subject to the limited exception described below, mobile food
vendors shall not park and operate in any parking space, alleyway, or any other
public right-of-way located within the following area: north of Wabash Avenue;
west of Water Street, east of Walnut Street, and south of North Street in the
City of Crawfordsville ("Downtown Restricted Area").
      (2)   The public street, right-of-way and parking spaces in the 100 block
of West Pike Street, from Washington Street to Walnut Street, and Pike Place
are excluded from the "Downtown Restricted Area" and all provisions of this
section.
      (3)   Mobile food vendors may operate in the 100 block of West Pike
Street, from Washington Street to Walnut Street, with approval of, and under
conditions set forth by the Board of Works and Public Safety.
      (4)   Mobile food vendors may operate on West Pike Street from Washington
to Walnut Street under the conditions set forth by the Crawfordsville Farmers'
Market during approved market hours.
      (5)   Mobile food vendors may park in the "Downtown Restricted Area" in
the course of a special event, but only on a street within the area that has
been temporarily closed for the special event by the Crawfordsville Board of
Public Works and Safety.
   (C)   Penalties. Any person, partnership, limited liability company, or
corporation that violates any provision of this section shall be subject to the
following penalties:
      (1)   Parking a mobile food vendor unit in the Downtown Restricted Area
first offense--$750 fine;
      (2)   Parking a mobile food vendor unit in the Downtown Restricted Area
second offense within any 12-month period--$1,500 fine;
      (3)   Parking a mobile food vendor unit in the Downtown Restricted Area
third offense, or each thereafter, within any 12-month period--$2,500.
(Ord. 32-2023, passed 10-9-23)
§ 72.17 COMMERCIAL VEHICLES, TRAILERS, BOATS, RECREATIONAL VEHICLES, CAMPERS,
AND TRAVEL TRAILERS PARKING PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   No person shall park any commercial vehicle or trailer, trailer, or
any boat, recreational vehicle, camper, or travel trailer on a public street,
alleyway, road, highway, sidewalk, or street right-of-way.
   (B)   Subdivision (A) shall not be interpreted to prohibit:
      (1)   Commercial vehicles from the temporary loading, unloading, or
delivering of goods and materials to any building or structure where there is a
properly marked loading zone or when there is no place for off-street parking
to unload said commercial vehicles, or when actively engaged in repair,
alteration, remodeling, or construction of any building or structure; nor shall
it apply to any trailer or semi-trailer in the process of being loaded or
unloaded, or when it is disabled in such a manner that it is impossible to
avoid stopping and temporarily leaving the disabled trailer or semi-trailer on
that portion of the public street, alleyway, road, highway, sidewalk or street
right-of-way ordinarily used for public parking; or
      (2)   To prohibit the temporary parking of a recreational vehicle,
camper, or travel trailer on a public street for a period not to exceed 24
hours.
   (C)   As used in this section the term COMMERCIAL VEHICLE shall mean any
vehicle that exceeds a license plate weight of 26,000 pounds.
   (D)   Fines and penalties.
      (1)   Each day a violation remains uncorrected is a distinct and separate
violation subject to an additional citation and fine in the amount prescribed
below.
      (2)   The monetary fine for each violation shall be $50, except that for
repeated violations, the following fines shall apply:
         (a)   Second Citation: $75.
         (b)   Each citation in excess of two: $100.
(Ord. 4-2024, passed 2-13-24)
PARKING METERS
§ 72.25 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   OPERATOR. Any person who operates a vehicle as the owner thereof, or as the
agent, employee or permittee of the owner, or is in actual physical control of
the vehicle.
   PARK or PARKING. The standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, upon
the street otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of, and while actually
engaged in, receiving or discharging passengers or loading or unloading
merchandise or in obedience of traffic regulations, signs or signals or an
involuntary stopping of the vehicle by reason of causes beyond control of the
operator of the vehicle.
   PARKING METER. Any mechanical device or meter not inconsistent with this
subchapter. Each parking meter installed shall indicate by proper legend the
legal parking time established by the city and when operated shall at all times
indicate the balance of the legal parking time, and at the expiration of such
period shall indicate illegal or overtime parking.
   PARKING METER SPACE. Any space within the parking meter zone adjacent to a
parking meter and which is designated for the parking of a single vehicle by
lines painted or otherwise durably marked on the curb or on the surface of the
street adjacent to or adjoining the parking meter.
   PARKING METER ZONES. Any restricted street upon which parking meters are
installed and in operation.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 72.26 PARKING METER ZONES.
   The streets and/or municipal parking lots described in
Chapter 77, Schedule IX, are designated as parking meter zones.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 72.27 DESIGNATION OF PARKING SPACES.
   The Chief of Police shall cause to be marked off individual parking spaces
in the parking meter zones by lines painted or durably marked on the curbing or
surface of the street. At each space so marked off it shall be unlawful to park
any vehicle in such a way that the vehicle is not entirely within the limits of
the space so designated.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.28 INSTALLATION OF PARKING METERS.
   The Chief of Police shall cause parking meters to be installed upon the curb
or sidewalk immediately adjacent to the parking spaces not more than feet from
the curb nor more than four feet from the front line of the parking space as
indicated, and the Chief of Police shall be responsible for the regulation,
control, maintenance, and use of such parking meters. Each device shall be so
set as to display the signal showing legal parking upon the deposit of the
appropriate coin or coins in lawful money. Each device shall be so arranged
that upon the expiration of the lawful time limit it will indicate by a proper
visible signal that the lawful parking period has expired and in such cases the
right of such vehicle to occupy such space shall cease and the operator, owner,
possessor or manager thereof shall be subject to the penalties herein provided.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.29 OPERATION OF PARKING METER.
   (A)   Except in a period of emergency determined by an officer of the Fire
Police Department, or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or
traffic-control sign or signal, when any vehicle is parked in any parking space
alongside or next to which a parking meter is located, the operator of such
vehicle shall, upon entering the parking meter space, immediately deposit or
cause to be deposited in the meter such proper coin as is required by such
parking meter and as is designated by proper directions on the meter, the
operator, after the deposit of the proper coin or coins, shall also set in
operation the timing mechanism of such meter in accordance with the directions
properly appearing thereon. Upon the deposit of such coin (and the setting of
the timing mechanism in operation when so required) the parking space may be
lawfully occupied by such vehicle during the period of time which has been
prescribed for the part of the street in which the parking space is located.
Any person placing a vehicle in a parking meter space adjacent to a meter which
indicates that unused time has been left in the meter by the previous occupant
of the space shall not be required to deposit a coin so long as his occupancy
of the space does not exceed the indicated unused time. If the vehicle remains
parked in any street parking space beyond the parking time limit set for such
parking space, and if the meter indicates such illegal parking, the vehicle
shall be considered parked overtime and in violation of this section.
   (B)   In no event shall any vehicle remain parked in any space beyond the
maximum time as hereinafter established for such space and remaining in such
space for any period next consecutive shall constitute a violation even though
a coin is deposited for such consecutive period.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.30 PARKING TIME LIMITS.
   Between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. Monday through Friday, parking
or standing a vehicle in a designated space shall be lawful only as stated
below. Meters shall not be operated at other times nor on Sundays or holidays
declared as such by the state. Limits and required money deposits are as
follows:
   (A)   Thirty minutes upon deposit of one nickel to a maximum deposit of $.20
in appropriate coins at locations as shown in Parts I, II, and III of
Chapter 77, Schedule IX, except Lot at 102 S. Water.
   (B)   One hour upon deposit of each nickel up to a maximum of four hours, or
$.20, in appropriate coins at locations as shown in Part IV of
Chapter 77, Schedule IX.
   (C)   Two hours upon deposit of each nickel to a maximum of $.25 in
appropriate coins at the locations as shown in Part V of
Chapter 77, Schedule IX.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.31 VIOLATIONS.
   No person shall:
   (A)   Cause, allow, permit, or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of,
or operated by such person to park overtime, or beyond the period of legal
parking time established for any parking meter
zone, or deposit in any parking meter any coin for the purpose of parking
beyond the maximum legal parking time for the particular parking meter zone.
   (B)   Permit any vehicle to remain or be placed in any parking space
adjacent to any parking meter while the meter is displaying a signal indicating
that the vehicle occupying such parking space has already been parked beyond
the period prescribed for such parking space.
   (C)   Park any vehicle across any line or marking of a parking meter space
or in such position that the vehicle shall not be entirely within the area
designated by such lines or markings.
   (D)   Deface, injure, tamper with, open or wilfully break, destroy or impair
the usefulness of any parking meter.
   (E)   Deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter any slugs,
device or metal substance, or other substitute for lawful coins.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.32 ENFORCEMENT.
   (A)   The Police Department shall enforce this subchapter in accordance with
directions of the Board of Public Works and Safety or the Board of Metropolitan
Police Commissioners. When a vehicle is parked in excess of the time limits
herein specified, a notice, numbered envelope, and ticket stub shall be placed
upon such vehicle informing the owner or operator thereof of the violation, the
time of the violation, the license number of the vehicle and such other data
which are necessary to a full understanding of the circumstances of such
violation, with instructions as to the payment of the charges for such
violation. Upon finding such notice and numbered envelope upon his vehicle, the
owner or operator thereof may fully satisfy the requirements of this section by
placing in the numbered envelope the sum stated in such notice and deposit the
same in any meter collection box installed on a parking meter standard, or by
delivering the same to the police station.
   (B)   There shall be installed on each street on which parking meters are
located on the parking meter standard nearest the intersection of an alley with
such street and also at the ends of each row of parking meters in metered
parking lots a meter collection box.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.33 COLLECTIONS; USE OF FUNDS.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to designate some member
of the Police Department to make regular collections of the money deposited in
the parking meters and to deliver such coins to the Clerk-Treasurer.
   (B)   The coins deposited in parking meters shall be used to defray the
expense of proper regulation of traffic upon the public streets of the city; to
provide for the cost of supervision, regulation and control of the parking of
vehicles in parking meter zones; and to cover the cost of purchase,
supervision, protection, inspection, installation, operation, maintenance,
control and the use of parking meters, and to repair and maintain streets.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 72.34 POWER OF CITY TO CHARGE RENTAL FOR PERMANENT STOPS.
   Nothing in this section shall be construed as prohibiting the city from
providing for bus stops, for taxicab stands, and other matters of similar
nature, including the loading and unloading of trucks, vans, or other
commercial vehicles, except that the Board of Public Works and Safety shall
have the power to determine and charge an annual rental for permanent stops or
stands commensurate with the probable income that would be derived from meter
collections if meters were installed at such stands.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
MUNICIPAL PARKING LOTS
§ 72.45 REGULATION FOR TRUCK PARKING LOT.
   On the municipal parking lot in the 300 block of North Washington Street and
such other municipal parking lots as may be designated from time to time as
truck parking lots by the Board of Public Works and Safety the following
parking limitations shall apply:
   (A)   Licensed vehicles only shall use the lot.
   (B)   Only vehicles 16 feet in length or over or tractors designed to tow
trailers of such length (farm tractors excluded) shall use such lot.
   (C)   No person, firm or corporation shall park any vehicle in such lot for
a continuous period of more than 48 hours and shall not, having removed the
same, repark the vehicle within a 24-hour period.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.46 MANNER OF PARKING IN CITY LOTS.
   Vehicles parking at the city parking lots, located at 305 East Main St. and
307 East Main St., shall drive their vehicles in to the marked parking spaces
in the parking lot, and backing vehicles into the parking spaces is hereby
declared to be unlawful.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.47 PROHIBITED TRUCK PARKING.
   It shall be unlawful for any truck to park in any of the metered parking
lots of the city.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
72.99
SNOW EMERGENCIES
§ 72.60 PROMULGATION OF SNOW EMERGENCY.
   (A)   Whenever the Board of Public Works and Safety of the city shall
determine that the presence of snow on streets and alleys of the city shall
unreasonably impede the movement of firefighting equipment, police, ambulance
or other emergency vehicles on such streets and alleys, it is hereby authorized
to promulgate a snow emergency which snow emergency shall continue until the
Board shall determine and declare that such snow emergency has abated.
   (B)   Such snow emergency shall be promulgated by written order which order
shall be disseminated by radio broadcast, newspaper, posting of notice, or such
other means as the Board shall deem advisable.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 72.61 STREETS TO WHICH SNOW EMERGENCY APPLIES.
   Such order shall direct the removal of all parked vehicles from the streets
and alleys from the area bounded within (and including the boundary streets):
Market Street, Water Street, Pike Street, and Walnut Street and such other
streets as may be specifically designated by such order. For the duration of
such emergency there shall be no parking of vehicles on streets and alleys.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.62 VEHICLES IN VIOLATION TO BE TOWED.
   In the event that the owner or operator of any parked vehicle in such
emergency area fails to remove the same within three hours following the
promulgation of such snow emergency, the Police Department of the city shall be
authorized to remove and tow away or cause to be removed and towed away such
vehicle at the expense of the owner of such vehicle. Whenever a vehicle is so
removed and the Police Department is able to ascertain the ownership thereof,
notice of such removal and the reasons for such removal shall be furnished to
the owner as expeditiously as may be reasonable under the circumstances.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 72.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of
this Traffic Code for which no penalty is otherwise provided, upon conviction
thereof, shall be fined for each violation any sum not exceeding $100. In
addition to the foregoing penalty, any police officer, upon discovering any
vehicle parked or stopped, in violation of this Traffic Code, may remove the
vehicle or cause the same to be removed by any city garage or other city
property or any public garage where such vehicle shall be released only upon
payment for the cost of towing such vehicle away from the place where it was
illegally parked or stopped, together with costs of storage.
   (B)   Any person who shall violate §
72.01 by stopping, standing or parking a vehicle on the roadway side of any
parked vehicle, commonly known as double parking, may in lieu of answering
summons and appearing in court on charge of violation, appear at the City
Building within 24 hours thereof and pay the sum of $5.
   (C)   This division applies to
Chapter 77, Schedule IX. If deposited within 48 hours of the time stated in the
notice, the charge for overtime meter parking shall be the sum of $3 if not
deposited or paid within 48 hours, the charge will be $10 ; if not deposited or
paid within 72 hours, the charge will be $15, resulting in a total maximum
payment for overtime meter parking in the sum of $15. The Police Department
shall keep an accurate record of all notices issued and all payments received.
(Am. Ord. 20-2001, passed 11-13-01)
   (D)   Whenever the owner or operator of a vehicle shall willfully cause or
permit such vehicle to be parked on the streets within the designated snow
emergency areas as set forth in §§
72.60 through
72.62 during such prohibited times he shall on conviction be fined in a sum not
to exceed $50.
   (E)   This division applies to §
72.30 and
Chapter 77, Schedule IX. If deposited within 48 hours of the time stated in the
notice, the minimum charge for overtime zone parking (exceeding the various
time limits as prescribed in
Chapter 77, Schedule IX) shall be the sum of $5; if not deposited or paid
within 48 hours the sum of $10 shall be charged; if not paid or deposited
within 72 hours the sum of $15 shall be charged . In addition, overtime meter
parking (expired meter) is subject to the penalties prescribed in division (C)
above. The Police Department shall keep an accurate record of all notices
issued and all payments received. Failure of such owner or operator to make
such payment within five days shall render him subject to the provisions
provided in division (F) below.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84; Am. Ord. 20-2001, passed 11-13-01)
   (F)   This division applies to
Chapter 77, Schedule IX. When an owner or operator has received a parking
violation which has not been paid within the required time limits, the Police
Department shall issue a written notice to such owner or operator, notifying
him of such delinquencies. The amount of the fines stated shall be paid within
ten days of the receipt of such notice: if not paid by the owner or operator
within ten days of the receipt of such notice, a charge of $20 per ticket
(violation) shall be assessed and an additional notice shall be issued to such
operator or owner; if the owner or operator fails to pay the delinquent fines
and penalties within ten days after the mailing of the third notice, an
additional sum of $5 shall be charged. The total penalties for each parking
violation assessed under this section shall not exceed $25
(Ord. 14-1980, passed - -80; Am. Ord. 20-2001, passed 11-13-01)
   (G)   In addition to all other penalties now provided by law, any person,
firm or corporation who shall habitually violate the ordinances of the city as
they pertain to parking meters, shall pay additional penalty as follows:
      (1)   There is hereby established a fine of $25 to be applied to any
person, firm or corporation receiving ten parking violation citations in a 30-
day period within a single calendar year.
      (2)   For a second receipt of ten parking violation citations in a 30-day
period within a single calendar year, there is hereby established a fine of
$50.
      (3)   For a third receipt of ten parking violation citations in a 30-day
period within a single calendar year, there is hereby established a fine of
$100.
(Ord. 39-1986, passed 11-10-86)
   (H)   Any person violating any provision of §
72.15 shall, upon conviction, be fined in any sum not less than $25 nor more
than $50. (Ord. 34-1992, passed 10-12-92)

   For procedures regarding all code and ordinance violations and penalties,
see §

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 73.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BICYCLE. Every device propelled by human power upon which any person may
ride, having any tandem wheels over 18 inches in diameter with tires inflated.
   MOTORIZED BICYCLE.  A two or three wheeled, one-person vehicle powered by an
electric motor or engine with a rating of more than two HP (horsepower) and of
not more than 50 cc (cubic centiliters), with an automatic transmission, and
intended by design not to exceed 25 miles per hour.
   MOTOR SCOOTER. A two wheeled, one-person vehicle powered by an engine or
motor with a seat and not a saddle for the driver and a floorpad for the
driver’s feet.
   SKATEBOARD. Any device propelled by human power upon which one or more
persons may stand or sit, having wheels less than eight inches in diameter.
(‘85 Code, § 10.1(c)) (Ord. 6-1991, passed 1-14-91; Am. Ord. 1-2009, passed 2-
10-09)
OPERATING REGULATIONS
§ 73.15 [RESERVED].
§ 73.16 EMERGING FROM ALLEY OR DRIVEWAY ON BICYCLE.
   The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway, or building
shall upon approaching a sidewalk or the sidewalk area extending across any
alleyway, yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians approaching on the sidewalk
or sidewalk area, and upon entering the roadway shall yield the right-of-way to
all vehicles approaching the roadway.
(‘85 Code, § 10.14) Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.17 [RESERVED].
§ 73.18 [RESERVED].
§ 73.19 SPEED REGULATIONS.
   No person shall operate a bicycle or skateboard at a speed greater than is
reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing.
(‘85 Code, § 10.13) (Am. Ord. 6-1991, passed 11-14-91) Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.20 PARKING.
   No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway
against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or
against a building or at the curb, in such manner as to afford the least
obstruction to pedestrian traffic, and no person operating a skateboard shall
leave the same on any sidewalk or in any street.
(‘85 Code, § 10.16) (Am. Ord. 6-1991, passed 11-14-91) Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.21 OPERATING IN CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT.
   (A)   No person, except for children under the age of 13 accompanied by
their parent or guardian, shall operate a bicycle or skateboard upon a sidewalk
within the central business district as specified in this section and
skateboarding in this specified central business district is prohibited. A map
of this area is attached to Ordinance No. 4-2007 as Appendix One and
incorporated herein by reference. The area encompasses all streets, alleys and
sidewalks, on both sides of the streets in and designating the area, bordered
by the following streets and railroads:
      (1)   Grant Avenue from North Street south to Wabash Avenue.
      (2)   Wabash Avenue east to Washington Street.
      (3)   Washington Street south to Jefferson Street.
      (4)   Jefferson Street east to Green Street.
      (5)   Green Street north to Wabash Avenue.
      (6)   Wabash Avenue east to Wallace Avenue.
      (7)   Wallace Avenue north to Main Street.
      (8)   CSX railroad tracks northwest to North Street.
      (9)   North Street west to Grant Avenue.
   (B)   Whenever any person is riding a bicycle or skateboard upon a sidewalk,
such person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give
audible warning before overtaking and passing such pedestrian.
(‘85 Code, § 10.17) (Am. Ord. 6-1991, passed 11-14-91; Am. Ord. 4-2007, passed
1-8-07) Penalty, see §
73.99
BICYCLE LICENSING PROVISIONS
§ 73.35 REGISTRATION REQUIRED; APPLICATION.
   (A)   No person, who resides within this city, shall ride or propel a
bicycle on any street, sidewalk, park, or other public place or upon any public
path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles unless such bicycle has been
registered and a registration sticker is attached thereto as provided herein.
   (B)   Application for a bicycle registration and registration sticker shall
be made upon a form provided by the city and shall be made to the Chief of
Police. A registration fee of $5 shall be paid to the city before each
registration is granted.
   (C)   No person shall operate or park a motorized bicycle or motor scooter
on any public street in the city unless such motorized bicycle or motor scooter
has been licensed by the Indiana Bureau of Motor Vehicles or a comparable motor
vehicle licencing department of any other state or registered by the city, and
either a valid registration plate or registration sticker is attached thereto
as provided herein.
   (D)   If so required, application for a motorized bicycle or motor scooter
registration sticker shall be made using a form provided by the city and shall
be made to the Chief of Police. A registration fee of $10 shall be paid to the
city before each motorized bicycle or motor scooter registration is granted.
(‘85 Code, §§ 10.2, 10.3) (Am. Ord. 1-2009, passed 2-10-09) Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.36 INSPECTION OF BICYCLES, MOTORIZED BICYCLES AND MOTOR SCOOTERS; ISSUANCE
OF REGISTRATION.
   (A)   The Chief of Police upon receiving a proper application therefor is
authorized to issue a registration for a bicycle, a motorized bicycle or a
motor scooter.
   (B)   The Chief of Police shall not issue a registration for any bicycle,
motorized bicycle or motor scooter when he knows or has reasonable ground to
believe that the applicant is not the owner of or entitled to the possession of
such bicycle, motorized bicycle or motor scooter .
   (C)   The Chief of Police shall keep a record of the number of each
registration, the date issued, the name and address of the person to whom
issued, and the number on the frame of the bicycle or the serial number of the
motorized bicycle or motor scooter for which issued, and a record of all
bicycle, motorized bicycle or motor scooter registration fees collected.
   (D)   The Chief of Police, or a police officer assigned such responsibility,
is authorized to inspect each bicycle, motorized bicycle or motor scooter
before registering the same and may refuse a registration for any bicycle,
motorized bicycle or motor scooter which that officer determines is in unsafe
mechanical condition.
(‘85 Code, §§ 10.4, 10.6) (Am. Ord. 1-2009, passed 2-10-09) Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.37 REGISTRATION STICKER.
   (A)   The Chief of Police upon issuing a bicycle, motorized bicycle or motor
scooter registration shall also issue a registration sticker bearing the
registration number assigned to the bicycle, motorized bicycle or motor
scooter, and the name of the city.
   (B)   Such registration sticker shall be firmly attached to the rear
mudguard or frame of the bicycle, motorized bicycle or motor scooter for which
issued in such position as to be plainly visible from the rear.
   (C)   A registration shall be valid as long as the bicycle, motorized
bicycle or motor scooter remains with the owner who so registered it. Upon
resale or other transfer of the bicycle, motorized bicycle or motor scooter a
new registration and sticker must be obtained by the transferee. Payment of
same fee as upon an original application will be charged the new owner.
(‘85 Code, § 10.5) (Am. Ord. 1-2009, passed 2-10-09) Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.38 TRANSFER OF OWNERSHIP.
   Upon the sale or other transfer of a registered bicycle, motorized bicycle
or motor scooter, the registrant shall notify the Chief of Police of the sale
or transfer and provide the name and address of the buyer or transferee, if
known, so that the affixed sticker may be voided in the Police Department
records and may, upon proper application and payment of appropriate fee, have a
new registration assigned to another bicycle, motorized bicycle or motor
scooter owned by the registrant.
(‘85 Code, § 10.7) (Am. Ord. 1-2009, passed 2-10-09)
§ 73.39 RENTAL AGENCIES.
   A rental agency shall not rent or offer any bicycle, motorized bicycle or
motor scooter for rent unless the bicycle, motorized bicycle or motor scooter
is registered and a registration sticker is attached thereto as provided herein
and such bicycle, motorized bicycle or motor scooter is equipped with the lamps
and other equipment required by law.
(‘85 Code, § 10.8) (Am. Ord. 1-2009, passed 2-10-09) Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Every person found guilty of violation of this chapter shall be fined
the sum of $50 for the first violation and $100 for each violation thereafter.
Owners or operators of non-registered motorized bicycles or motor scooters who
violate the parking or other ordinances of the city are also subject to having
said motorized bicycle or motor scooter impounded. If impoundment occurs, the
owner of the motorized bicycle or motor scooter shall be liable to pay the fees
associated therewith, in addition to any other fines or penalties set forth
under the penalty provisions of the ordinance(s) violated.
   (B)   However, the penalty for any person under 18 years of age as it
applies to bicycles and skateboards shall be as follows:
      (1)   First offense. Traffic officer shall obtain the minor’s name and
address and issue a warning.
      (2)   Second offense. The traffic officer shall seize the bicycle or
skateboard, and the bicycle or skateboard will be released only to the minor’s
parent or guardian.
      (3)   Third offense. The traffic officer shall seize the bicycle or
skateboard, which may be forfeited if ordered by the court in any proceeding
under this chapter, in addition to a fine of $20 and $50 for each violation
thereafter.
(‘85 Code, § 10.99) (Am. Ord. 6-1991, passed 11-14-91; Am. Ord. 4-2007, passed
1-8-07; Am. Ord. 1-2009, passed 2-10-09)

§ 74.01 RAILROAD CROSSING SIGNALS.
   (A)   The Peoria and Eastern Railway Company and its operating company, the
New York Central Railroad Company, shall maintain and operate 24 hours each day
a standard automatic flashlight signal on both sides of the railroad company’s
right-of-way at the intersections of the railway and Mill, Sheridan, John,
Wallace, Elm, Water, Green, Washington, and Walnut Streets.
   (B)   The Chicago, Indianapolis and Louisville Railway Company shall
maintain and operate 24 hours each day a standard flashlight signal on both
sides of the railroad company’s right-of-way at the intersections of the
railway and Market and Main Streets.
   (C)   The Pennsylvania Railroad System and its operating company, if any,
shall maintain and operate 24 hours each day a standard flashlight signal on
both sides of the railroad company’s right-of-way at the intersections of the
railway and Darlington Avenue, Main Street, and Wabash Avenue, and the company
shall maintain and operate 24 hours each day a standard strait automatic
flashlight signal on the railroad right-of-way at the intersection of the
railway and Elmore Street.
(‘85 Code, § 27.01) Penalty, see §
74.99
§ 74.02 SPEED OF TRAINS IN CITY.
   Editor’s note: Municipal train speed ordinances have been preempted by
federal law. Consolidated Rail Corp. v. Smith, 664 F. Supp. 1228 (N.D. Ind.
1987)
§ 74.03 TRAINS BLOCKING STREET.
   No person owning, operating, controlling or running any locomotive engine or
train of cars used for carrying freight shall permit any such train to remain
standing across any public highway, street or alley without immediately cutting
the train and leaving a space of at least the entire width of such highway,
street or alley.
(‘85 Code, § 27.03) Penalty, see §
74.99
§ 74.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be fined in any sum not less than $100 nor more than $2,500.
(‘85 Code, § 27.99) (Am. Ord. 21-2005, passed 7-11-05)

§ 75.01 APPLICATION OF REGULATIONS.
   The regulations herein stated shall apply to all classes of access, herein
described, and shall be entitled “Access Control Rules.”
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 75.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ACCESS POINT. The point of connection of a driveway at the right-of-way line
of the highway with the approach.
   APPROACH. A place improved for vehicular or pedestrian traffic on highway
right-of-way which connects the edge of pavement of a public highway with a
driveway, or pedestrian walkway.
   AUXILIARY LANE. The portion of the roadway adjoining the travelled way for
parking, speed change, turning, storage, weaving, truck climbing or for other
such purposes.
   BOARD. Crawfordsville Board of Public Works and Safety.
   COMMERCIAL ACCESS. An entrance and an approach which connects a street,
alley or thoroughfare with a driveway to private property used for commercial
purposes and with public property which will ordinarily carry a heavy traffic
movement.
   DRIVEWAY. Every way or place not on the right-of-way of any public highway
and which is used for vehicular traffic.
   ENTRANCE. The point of connection of an approach with the travelled portion
of a public highway.
   FIELD ACCESS. An entrance and an approach which is used for a construction
site or which connects a street, alley or thoroughfare with vacant lots, fields
or other unimproved property.
   MEDIAN. The portion of a divided highway separating the travelled ways for
traffic in opposite directions.
   MEDIAN OPENING (CROSSOVER). A gap in the median provided and designated for
crossing and turning traffic.
   PRIVATE ACCESS. An entrance and an approach which connects a highway with a
driveway to a residence, barn, private garage, or other improved property and
ordinarily used by the owner or occupant of the premises, his guests and
necessary service vehicles.
   TRAVELLED WAY. The portion of the roadway for the movement of vehicles,
exclusive of shoulders and auxiliary lanes.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 75.03 CLASSES OF ACCESS.
   All entrances and approaches shall be divided into five classes as follows:
   (A)   Class I. Private Access. Raised curb used.
   (B)   Class II. Private Access. Shoulder only, no raised curb.
   (C)   Class III. Commercial Access. Raised curb used.
   (D)   Class IV. Commercial Access. Shoulder only, no raised curb.
   (E)   Class V. Field Access. Either raised curb or shoulder only.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 75.04 PERMIT APPLICATIONS.
   (A)   Form required. Application to the Board for permits to construct any
entrance, driveway or approach connecting with any street, alley or highway
right-of-way or to cut any curb along the street, alley or highway or to
construct a crossover on the street alley or highway shall be made on the form
as prescribed by the Board. Reasonable fees for processing driveway permits may
be established by appropriate Board action.
   (B)   When required. Relocation, alteration, or remodeling of an entrance
approach, driveway or crossover, or any change in the character of the use of
the entrance, approach, driveway, or crossover shall be considered the
construction of a new entrance, driveway, approach or crossover for which an
application or permit for a wholly new entrance, approach, driveway, and/or
crossover were being applied for. The granting or denial of such application
shall be governed by the same rules and judged by the same standards as an
application for a permit for a wholly new entrance approach, driveway, and/or
crossover.
   (C)   Person making. All applications shall be made by the property owner.
Other interested parties shall be listed for other than private access permits.
Other interested parties shall include all adjoining property owners, lessees,
purchase option holders and others willfully intent on developing the property
or adjoining property. All such persons listed shall sign and consent to
restrictions imposed as consideration of the request being approved, or unless
specifically waived by the Board, the application shall be denied.
   (D)   Disclosure of intended use for or with adjacent parcels. All
applications for permits shall disclose the present and proposed use of the
parcel for which access is requested. Any intended use of the access in
conjunction with any adjacent parcel, whether owned by the applicants or by
others or to be purchased or sold by the applicant or others, shall be
disclosed in the application. All adjacent parcels owned or controlled by the
applicants, whether intended to be used in conjunction with the requested
access or not shall be disclosed in the application. In the case where
applicants own or control adjacent parcels, the Board may require applicants to
dedicate easements for driveways to facilitate the use of combined entrances so
that the number of access points along the highway may be controlled to ensure
the public a safe and convenient means of travel consistent with the right of
the adjoining landowner to have access as provided by law.
   (E)   Designs. All applications shall be filed in accordance with the
standards, specifications and design requirements of the Board. The permittee
agrees to make the improvements in accordance with such standards,
specifications and design requirements of the Board.
   (F)   Commercial application; engineer’s attestation. All applications for
commercial purposes shall be signed by a registered professional engineer, and/
or registered land surveyor, attesting that the applications as proposed,
conform with all Board rules and standards, except as he shall note in such
attestation. All exceptions shall be accompanied by an explanation as to why
the exception should be granted.
   (G)   Other laws. Approval of a permit application shall be subject to the
permittee obtaining all necessary approvals involving land use from the zoning
board and/or Plan Commission having jurisdiction or authority and complying
with all applicable laws.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 75.05 PLOT PLAN REQUIREMENTS.
   Listed below are the plot plan requirements which must be met before any
driveway permit applications can be accepted for review.
   (A)   Applicant must submit two copies of plot plan.
   (B)   The plot plan must be certified by registered professional
engineer, architect or land surveyor unless otherwise waived by the Board.
   (C)   A vicinity sketch must be shown on the plot plan at a scale of not
less than 1 = 2,000, and must indicate the location of the property to major
arterial streets, railroads and the like.
   (D)   Standard engineering scales (i.e., 1 = 20, 1 = 30) must be used.
   (E)   Use of each access point must be specified: entrance only, exit only,
entrance and exit.
   (F)   Adequate description of proposed use of property must be included.
   (G)   The plan must show the width of existing and adjacent driveways,
streets, alleys and right of way 150 feet beyond property lines on both sides
of the street, plus the plan must show the location of all utilities and any
other pertinent topography.
   (H)   Location and geometrics of proposed access points, and location and
size of existing or proposed building must be shown.
   (I)   Location and details of permanent signs must be shown.
   (J)   Cross-sections for pavement widening and curbs must be illustrated, if
applicable.
   (K)   The plot plan must include proposed parking arrangements with
anticipated number of vehicles.
   (L)   Plot plan must show all existing and proposed drainage structures,
including pipe, catch basins, head walls, and the like, necessary to provide
adequate drainage.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 75.06 STANDARD SPECIFICATIONS.
   All construction and materials used within the public right-of-way must
conform to the City Engineer “Standard Specifications” which shall be kept on
file at the office of the City Engineer.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 75.07 BONDS REQUIRED.
   The Board may require a performance bond to be filed along with each
application for a commercial driveway with an amount to equal the estimated
cost of that part of the project on the public right-of-way. The Board may also
require adequate bond to be filed in any non-commercial application. Such bonds
are required to insure compliance with all terms of the permit and shall in the
case of non-compliance, provide in addition to any damages suffered thereby,
all witness and court costs in collecting the same, together with any
attorney’s fee professional engineers; fees or land surveyors’ fees reasonably
due, and shall be released only when the work described on the permit has been
completed to the satisfaction of the Board.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 75.08 LOCATION OF CROSSOVERS.
   Permits for private or commercial crossovers will not be approved unless the
distance to the nearest existing crossover is in excess of 400 feet, unless the
applicant can prove to the satisfaction of the Board that the location of the
crossover will not be detrimental to the safety of the traveling public.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 75.09 DRIVEWAY STANDARDS.
   The most common examples of driveways and approaches are available from the
City Engineer, entitled “Driveway Standards.” These standards will apply in
majority of cases because many conditions can be derived from each figure.
However, there will be exceptional situations and borderline cases where the
standards and guides do not apply. In such instances, alternate standards will
be used. The next lowest functional type will serve as the alternate dimensions
for each functional type (i.e., the alternate dimensions for arterials are the
dimension for collectors). The use of alternate dimensions will be subject to
the approval of the City Engineer and such approval should precede the filing
of permit application. Additional standards which will be required are as
follows:
   (A)   Entrance and exit only driveways.
      (1)    This type of driveway is not highly recommended for a divided
roadway. However, the entrance and exit driveways do have a purpose and when
warranted use the following dimensions:
         (a)   Minimum width = 11 feet.
         (b)   Maximum width = 17 feet.
      (2)   In order to control entrance and exit drives, they must be properly
signed. This shall be the responsibility of the property owner.
   (B)   Number of driveways and spacing. Driveway spacing is largely dependent
on land use and zoning, and as a result, it is difficult to develop definite
standards. Although from past experience and a literature review on this
subject, not more than two driveways are generally needed to serve a tract of
land. Additional policies are as follows:
      (1)   Arterials. Frontage roads are encouraged but where this is not
feasible a minimum spacing of 150 feet is required between adjacent property
owners. Also, as a general rule, if the frontage is 100 feet or less, only one
driveway will be permitted.
      (2)   Collectors. A minimum spacing of 100 feet is required and generally
only one driveway per 100 feet of frontage will be allowed.
      (3)   Local. No minimum spacing is required; however, only one driveway
per lot will be allowed.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 75.10 VISIBILITY; TRAFFIC DEVICES; LOCATION OF PROPERTY LINE.
   (A)   All entrances and approaches shall be located so as to provide
adequate sight distance in both directions along the alley, thoroughfare or
highway for safe access to same without interfering with traffic.
   (B)   No entrance or approach shall be located or constructed so as to
interfere with or prevent the proper location of necessary highway signs or
other traffic-control devices.
   (C)   No approach radii shall be so constructed that any part of the same
extends in front of property belonging to persons other than the permittee
unless both property owners sign a joint application for the permit.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 75.11 DRAINAGE REQUIREMENTS.
   All improvements authorized by the permit shall not interfere with drainage
of the street or highway, nor cause an additional area to drain onto the right-
of-way. However, part of the improvements within the public right-of-way may
drain toward the street or highway, subject to the approval of the Board.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 75.12 WORK TO PROCEED SUBJECT TO CONDITIONS.
   Upon receipt of such permit the permit tee is authorized to proceed with the
work covered by it, subject to the conditions imposed by the Board and these
rules. If the application is approved with conditions, all of the signatories
to the original application shall indicate their consent to the conditions in
writing.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 75.13 FINAL APPROVAL OF THE PERMIT.
   A final approval of the permit shall be issued upon completion of
construction as covered by the permit to construct in accordance with the plans
and specifications filed in the application as amended by the Board; together
with any special conditions set forth by the permit; together with an
acceptance inspection by the City Engineer.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 75.14 LIMITATION OF ACCESS.
   The permittee shall at the time of receipt of a permit to construct sign a
copy of a “Limitation of Access” instrument, if so required by the Board, which
shall be obtained and left with the Permit Clerk of the City Engineer’s Office,
for recording in the deed record, together with a check payable to the County
Recorder covering the cost of recording the instrument. The Permit Clerk shall
immediately cause the limitation of access instrument to be recorded and send
acknowledgment thereof to the permittees.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 75.15 NOTIFICATION OF CITY ENGINEER.
   Before beginning work under any permit to construct, the permittee shall
notify, in writing, five days prior to start of work, the City Engineer of the
date he will begin such work.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 75.16 DISPLAY OF PERMIT REQUIRED.
   The applicant’s permit complete with drawings and special provisions shall
be on the job site at all times so that it can be shown, if requested.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 75.17 IMPROVEMENTS TO BE COMPLETED WITHIN CERTAIN TIME PERIOD.
   All improvements authorized by a permit must be completed within one year
after the permit is issued; otherwise, the permit will be cancelled unless an
extension is requested, in writing, by the applicant, and the request is
approved by the Board. However, all construction authorized by the permit on
the right-of-way must be completed within 30 days after starting the
construction, unless otherwise expressly approved as a special condition.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 75.18 LIABILITY OF PERMITTEE.
   The permittee shall assume all responsibility (during the time from the
beginning of the work covered by any permit until final approval of the work)
and shall furthermore be obligated to save harmless the city from any and all
injury, loss or damage occasioned to or by persons or property resulting
directly or indirectly from such work; the Board, in its discretion, require
the permittee to provide liability and indemnity insurance for the use and
benefit of the city.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 75.19 CONSTRUCTION NOT TO INTERFERE WITH STRUCTURE IN RIGHT-OF-WAY;
ENCROACHMENT OF SIGNS.
   (A)   The construction of all improvements authorized by the permit shall
not interfere with any existing structure on any city street, alley or
thoroughfare without specific permission in writing from the Board or other
owner thereof. Any structure or traffic-control device affected by the proposed
construction shall be relocated at the applicant’s expense as directed.
   (B)   The permittee shall not erect or maintain any advertising sign on or
over the right-of-way or any portion thereof in violation of any law.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
§ 75.20 EXISTING ACCESS.
   Any person, who by law, has an existing legal right of access to a street,
alley or thoroughfare shall, if he desires to improve, relocate, alter or
remodel the same or if he has applied for and been issued final approval of a
permit under these rules, if he desires to make any change in the character of
the use of such right of access, shall as a condition of the issuance of any
permit and in consideration of the same, agree that such rights of access, then
existing or granted thereafter with respect to such real estate shall be
subject to these rules as the same may from time to time be amended by the
Board.
(Ord. 5-1984, passed 2-13-84)
